SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill continues the practice of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sitting of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments to legislation.

Some of the amendments made by this Bill tidy up, correct and update existing legislation. Other amendments are of minor policy significance or are matters of routine administration. None of the amendments made by the Bill has any significant financial impact.

The amendments proposed in this Bill are, for the most part, a reproduction of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1987 which lapsed after the second reading debate in the House of Representatives earlier this year.
The current Bill is different from Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) (No. 1) in two respects.

Firstly, it contains some further changes to amendments previously included in the Bill. Some of these are necessary because of the effluxion of time, for example, the amendments to the Honey Industry Act 1962, and some are minor drafting amendments.
Secondly, this Bill includes amendments to the following Acts which were not present in the earlier Bill:
Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976;
Acts Interpretation Act 1901;
Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979;
Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918;
Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904;
Currency Act 1915;
Customs Tariff (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1987;
Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966;
Foreign States Immunities Act 1985;
Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981;
Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (Consequential Amendments) Act 1987.

Many of the proposed amendments will be self-evident or sufficiently explained by the Explanatory Memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to addressing mainly the new amendments included in this Bill, and amendments that were queried in relation to the lapsed Bill.
Acts Interpretation Act 1901

The amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act are intended to advance the policy of simplifying the language of Acts of Parliament. For this purpose the amendments will permit some standard forms of words to be shortened, or omitted from Acts, by making appropriate amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act.

The amendments will also make it clear that regulations may be expressed to commence at the commencement of a specified Act, even if the Act is to commence on a proclaimed date. It is also necessary to provide that regulations may be expressed to commence at a specified time on a specified day.
Anglo-Australian Telescope Agreement Act 1970

The Anglo-Australian Telescope Agreement Act currently restricts the functions of the Anglo-Australian Telescope Board to those specified in the Agreement annexed to the Act. The United Kingdom and Australian Governments have now agreed that it is desirable for the Board to assume from the United Kingdom authorities responsibility for the future management of some additional facilities already in place at Siding Spring. The amendments will enable the Board to undertake other functions as prescribed by regulations and so assume those res-ponsibilities without the need for amendment of the Agreement.
Audit Act 1901

The amendments proposed to the Audit Act in this Bill are aimed at improving the efficiency of the Commonwealth's financial administration and allowing the Auditor-General a discretion in reporting minor breaches of legislation.

From the point of view of financial administration, one amendment will simplify the pro-cesses by which funds that have already been appropriated by law are subsequently distributed to Departments and will save administrative effort. Financial administration will also be improved by another amendment to enable the Minister for Finance to approve methods of performing accounting functions which do not involve written signatures.

The amendments will ensure that Departments report to Parliament on their special ope-rations-a requirement which has not existed previously. The Auditor-General will also be given some discretion on which matters are included in his reports.

The Auditor-General, when so requested by a Minister, will be able to audit the financial statements of bodies such as incorporated companies controlled by the Commonwealth. Currently there is doubt whether the Act permits such an audit, as the existing provision refers to the audit of accounts and records only.

Other amendments will enable regulations to be made to re-establish a policy, adopted by previous Governments and arising directly from the policy of self-insurance, that the liability of Commonwealth drivers for the cost of replacing or repairing damaged vehicles should be the same as for a driver in the private sector who is covered by motor vehicle insurance.
Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979

Amendment to the Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979 is proposed in order to extend the current marketing arrangements for canned deciduous fruits undertaken through the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation (ACFC) for one year until 31 December 1988. The Government is aware of current efforts by canneries to amalgamate their activities in order to improve efficiency and reduce costs, and extension of the marketing arrangements by one year will facilitate industry discussions on cannery amalgamation.
Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918

The proposed amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act is designed to put beyond doubt the power of the Electoral Commissioner to direct Australian Electoral Officers, Divisional Returning Officers and other officers as defined in that Act. The amendment also puts beyond doubt the power of Australian Electoral Officers to direct Divisional Returning Officers and they in their turn to direct officers under their control.
Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904

The amendment of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is intended to remove doubts about the certification of rule alterations. The Act requires that certain rule alterations made by organisations registered under the Act do not take effect unless certified by an Industrial Registrar as not contrary to law, the Act and regulations, an award or the rules of the organisation.
Some doubt exists about the power of a Registrar to certify only part of a rule alteration submitted to him.
The proposed amendment is intended to remove any doubt as to the validity of any partial certification made by a Registrar in the past and any doubt as to the validity of the rule alteration.

The provision will not operate to alter any prior decision made by a court regarding any such certification or to pre-empt any decision in a proceeding before a court at the time the sub-section takes effect. A court will, however, be able to hold that a partial certification was valid if the court considers that it is just and equitable so to find.
Currency Act 1965
The proposed amendment of the Currency Act will permit the issue of coins of the same denomination with differing characteristics and dimensions.
This will facilitate the issue of special commemorative coins in 1988.
Dairy Produce Act 1986

The amendments to the Dairy Produce Act will prevent persons who are members of the Executive Council of the Australian Dairy Conference, which is the peak policy council of the dairy industry, from being appointed as members of the Australian Dairy Corporation. This change is in accordance with the Government's policy that, where a statutory marketing authority is required to account to the peak industry body, the members of the executive council of that body are not to be eligible for appointment as members of the authority because of the possibility of a conflict of interests.
Honey Industry Act 1962

The proposed amendments to the Honey Industry Act will enable the Minister to reappoint the immediate past members of the Australian Honey Board to hold office until the end of 1988. The Board is to be restructured with the new membership.

Under the Bill which lapsed at the end of the last sittings, the tenure of Board members was to be extended pending the restructuring of the Board. However in the intervening period the Board members' appointments have expired.
Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965
The Bill proposes a number of minor amendments to the Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965. The most important of these fall into two areas.

The first will allow greater flexibility in the appointment of a person to act as Chairman and Managing Director of the Corporation. Under the proposed amendments, the Treasurer will be able to appoint someone to act as chairman in the absence of the Chairman. This will overcome difficulties that have arisen when the Deputy Chairman's position has been vacant.

The second area of amendment will allow the Corporation to enter into reinsurance contracts with a subsidiary of an approved lender in respect of loans made by the approved lender and insured by the subsidiary. A recent trend for some lenders to insure their loans through their own newly established subsidiaries, and the fact that the Corporation is currently prevented by its Act from offering reinsurance, have restricted the Corporation's ability to compete for business it has traditionally serviced. The proposed amendments will enable the Corporation to respond to developments in the mortgage insurance market.
Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986; Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986; Intelligence and Security (Consequential Amendments) Act 1986

Several consequential amendments are to be made to these Acts following on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986. The amendments will also make it clear that the Inspector-General may inquire into an act or practice of an intelligence agency that is or may be contrary to any human right, may constitute discrimination or may be unlawful under the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 or the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 where it has been referred to the Inspector-General by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.
Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981

The Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act provides a regime to allow exploration for, and exploitation of minerals from the seabed. Administration, pursuant to the Offshore Constitutional Settlement, is to be shared between the States and the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth.

Although passed in 1981 proclamation of the Act has been held pending passage by the States and the Northern Territory of complementary legislation. The proposed amendment is to allow proclamation of only portions of the Act.

Governments are working on the full set of legislation and administrative arrangements required to implement the regime. Meanwhile, however, while the States and the Northern Territory can consider applications to explore areas to the outer limit of the territorial sea-the ``three mile limit''-in accordance with their existing onshore mining legislation, the Commonwealth is unable to consider applications for the much larger area of continental shelf outside the limit. There have been several expressions of interest by companies in respect of exploration in the Commonwealth's area. The Government is disposed to encourage commencement of mineral exploration activity, though mining would not be authorised until all arrangements are in place. It is proposed to proclaim only so much of the Act as is necessary to allow exploration to proceed.

Given the role of the States and the Northern Territory in the administration of the Act, their views on partial proclamation have been sought. None of them has raised objections in principle. Discussions between officials are taking place.
Navigation Act 1912; Shipping Registration Act 1981
The most noteworthy amendments of the Navigation Act will benefit the maritime industry by eliminating unnecessary duplication of certificating of ships.
The amendments of the Shipping Registration Act are intended to promote the prompt provision to the Registrar of Shipping of accurate information on ships entitled to be registered in Australia.
Pig Industry Act 1986

The amendment to the Pig Industry Act provides that if the Australian Pork Corporation requests that a company auditor be appointed the auditor of the Corporation, the Auditor- General shall advise the Minister on the suitability of the proposed company auditor. At present the Auditor-General is required to decide on the suitability of a company auditor.

Another amendment removes the restriction on the Australian Pork Corporation selection Committee which prevents it from nominating for appointment to the Corporation anyone who is a member of the executive of an eligible industry body, that is, the Australian Pork Producers' Federation or the National Meat Processors Association. A person will still be ineligible for actual appointment to the Corporation if he or she is such a member.

Removal of this restriction will mean that such a person will need to resign his or her position in the Federation or Association only if and when offered appointment to the Corporation by the Minister. This amendment will bring the selection procedures for the Corporation into line with those for other statutory marketing authorities.
Wine Grapes Levy Collection Act 1979

The proposed amendments to the Wine Grapes Levy Collection Act update the penalties and revise some of the offences. The amendments as they now appear differ from the original version of the Bill introduced earlier this year to rectify a defect in a provision removing the right to refuse to provide information on the grounds of self-incrimination. This matter was raised by the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills.

I have not dealt with most of the amendments proposed by this Bill which were contained in the lapsed Bill. The Explanatory Memorandum has been revised and expanded in relation to all these amendments and Honourable Senators will be able to find details of these amendments, and the new amendments, in that memorandum.
I table the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective Budget deficit in 1987-88 together with the associated prospective deficit in the consolidated revenue fund.

Legally, payments from the consolidated revenue fund cannot exceed moneys available to that fund. In order to meet any prospective deficit in the consolidated revenue fund it is customary to seek legislative authority to charge defence and other consolidated revenue fund expenditure to, or reimburse the consolidated revenue fund from, the loan fund. This Bill therefore seeks authority to borrow money in 1987-88 for defence and other purposes and to enable certain other expenditures to be met from the loan fund rather than from the consolidated revenue fund.

In addition, and for the first time, the Bill provides for continuity of that authority by the inclusion of a supply clause. In the past, borrowing authority under the annual loan Act ceased to be available on 30 June until the next loan Act was passed; usually by urgent passage in the Budget sittings. Borrowings authority during the supply period for next financial year will be limited to the amount included in the Supply Act (No. 1) 1988-89 for defence purposes; that Act having been passed by the Parliament prior to the end of the 1987-88 financial year.

Apart from a comparatively small amount attributable to the expenses of raising loans under the authority of this legislation, the Bill does not authorise defence or other expenditures additional to those otherwise authorised by Parliament under annual appropriation Acts and under Acts providing for special or standing appropriations. The Bill is simply a machinery financing measure-the provisions of the Bill in fact explicitly prohibit borrowings for expenditures additional to those authorised by the Parliament.

Successive governments have, for many years, introduced legislation in the form of an annual loan Bill to authorise the issue of moneys from the loan fund to meet defence expenditures or to reimburse the consolidated revenue fund from loan fund in respect of certain non-defence expenditures.

In the Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that the Budget deficit in prospect for 1987-88 is estimated to be some $27 million. This gives rise to a prospective deficit in the consolidated revenue fund of around $2.4 billion-the consolidated revenue fund differs from the Budget deficit as some CRF expenditures and receipts are classified as financing transactions in the functional classification of Budget outlays and, for purposes of the Budget figuring, certain Budget outlays are met direct from either the loan fund or the trust fund.

Existing standing authorities enable some $1.2 billion of expenditure to be charged to loan fund in 1987-88 leaving a shortfall of some $1.2 billion for which separate funding authority is required. This Bill seeks authority to borrow moneys accordingly.

The amount of borrowings that may be undertaken pursuant to the proposed legislation is, in the case of defence expenditure, the amount for which appropriation is sought for defence purposes in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1)-some $7.1 billion in 1987-88-and any moneys for defence purposes that may be appropriated in the Supply Act (No. 1) for next financial year. The effective limit in 1987-88 is likely to be significantly less than appropriations as defence expenditures cannot be charged to loan fund until the legislation is enacted.

The legal limit for borrowing for non-defence purposes is determined by the level of borrowing authority approved by the Loan Council. It is estimated that the 1987-88 limits will be sufficient to enable the financing of the consolidated revenue fund deficit. In concluding, I emphasise that the Bill does not in any way impinge upon the Parliament's prerogative to appropriate public moneys but simply provides a mechanism for financing expenditures previously approved and appropriated by the Parliament.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Budget is a fraud. It has been revealed as such. Its cover has been totally blown, not only by the Opposition but also by commentators in the newspapers. People such as Mr Ross Gittins have exposed the nonsense of the so-called balanced Budget and have revealed the divisions between members of the Government-for example, between the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-over the pace of economic recovery and the appropriate nature of the reconstruction required to get Australia out of the mess. The Government was guilty of a fraud with this Budget. The Treasurer set out once again to deceive the Australian people and, in particular, to deceive those foreigners on whom he depends to balance his books in what has now been clearly shown as a monumentally phoney way.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the extent to which it is now clear that this Budget is a fraud and the Government has set out to deceive the Australian people. We saw in the Treasurer's Budget Speech self-satisfaction and excessive confidence. As Senator Walsh said, the Budget was clearly over-sold-not by just a touch; there was an immense dose of complacency. Australia, according to the Treasurer, in the only nation in the world in step, the only nation with the capacity to do it right. According to the Treasurer in his Budget Speech:
. . . our economic strategy is now bearing fruit.
He said:
Our external deficit, although falling, remains too high.
He admits that. He said also:
To reduce permanently our debt burden we must go further in reducing our dependence on overseas savings by lifting the level of Australian savings.
He said further that if we are:
to sell more abroad-and if our manufacturers are to win a greater share of the domestic market-we must ensure the goods we produce are priced competitively.
Well, that is accurate, but the Government is not doing anything about it. But here is the irony. He said:
. . . we must make sure that labour costs in Australia are competitive with those of our trading partners.

Of course, the figures that are available in the Budget Papers on page 29, table 7-an international comparison of compensation per employee-show just how inadequate and how short of these targets the Budget falls. The targets set by the Treasurer himself are, in fact, not being met because this Budget does not do what the Treasurer claimed it would do either in achieving a real balance-he has claimed it is a balanced Budget-or in setting an appropriate pace of reconstruction. I did not have the opportunity before to show this document to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Evans), since we have just begun today's sitting; but I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard table 7 from page 29 of the Budget Papers which is an international comparison of compensation per employee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It will be evident from that table of official figures that back in 1983-84 the increase in wages in Australia-this is according to the statistics-was 4.9 per cent compared to the average of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) of 4.4 per cent. So Australia was only 10 or 11 per cent worse, in terms of increasing labour costs, than the rest of the world. I say `worse' in an environment where we are having to compete strenuously, struggle to survive, in a tough trading world. This Government has set out to improve our capacity to compete. It has done so `well' at that-I use the word `well' in inverted commas-that instead of being only 11 per cent worse in 1983-84, it got up to 21 per cent worse in 1985-86. Last year, 1986-87, as a result of this Government's ludicrous economic policies, ludicrous wages policies and ludicrous inflation policies, instead of being 11 per cent worse as it was in 1983-84, it was 43.2 per cent worse. This is regarded by the Government as an incredible victory.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's compensation per employee has increased by 6.3 per cent in the last year as against the OECD average of 4.4 per cent. This is because Australia is, according to the Treasurer, the only nation in step. He makes the point clearly in the Budget Speech. He says:
We could have reacted to this trade deterioration by pushing all the economic policy levers into reverse.
That has been tried in the past, both here and in other countries.

And where it has been tried it has not produced the quick results hoped for and it has resulted in sharply higher long-term levels of unemployment, declining living standards and destructive social conflicts.
We have rejected that path and the events of the past 18 months have shown that we were right.
We have turned the corner and the big gaps in the trade accounts have begun to close.
Australia is the only nation in step, according to the Treasurer. It reminds me of a booklet about the achievements of the accord which was put out a couple of years ago in which the Government said:
In following this course-
that is the accord-

in contrast to many other countries, the Australian Government is determined not to revert to the orthodox response to devaluation of using contractionary economic policies to reduce inflation. It also rejects calls for the dismantling or destruction of our wage indexation system. Wage indexation systems overseas have been recently interrupted or suspended, with no one system escaping unscathed through the 1980s.

The reality is that while we may be the only nation in step, it has meant that we are going broke, that we are unable to compete and that, in fact, we have a situation here in terms of compensation per employee which is far worse now in relation to the average of the OECD than it was in 1983-84, than it even was in 1985-86. This is damaging our capacity to lift our economy out of the crisis that it has been brought into under this Hawke Government. If we are going to be able to compete-as the Government says is our policy; its strategy is to get us to compete more-we have to become far more realistic about what we are entitled to, what all of us are entitled to in Australia, than we clearly have been in the past. That is a point that was made by Senator Walsh. I shall return to it in a few moments.

It is interesting that Australia is the only nation in step, according to the Treasurer. We can see the consequences of that by looking at the International Comparison of Consumer Prices which is available from the Monthly Economic Social Indicators put out by the Parliamentary Library. We see that Australia, as a result of being out of step, as a result of deliberate Government policy, has an inflation rate of 9.3 per cent-according to the figures available for the last 12 months-compared to Germany, one of our trading partners, which has a rate of 0.2 per cent; compared to Japan which has no inflation rate whatsoever; compared to the United Kingdom which has a rate of 4.2 per cent which is less than half that of Australia's; compared to the United States which has a rate of 3.7 per cent, just over a third of Australia's; compared to the average of the European Economic Community which has a rate of 3.1 per cent, exactly one-third the level of Australia's inflation rate and the OECD average of 3.4 per cent, just over a third of the Australian average. That is the price of being out of step. Of course, that raises the interesting question of the extent to which, within the Government, there is conflict over the reality of whether the Government is adopting the appropriate policies to fix up this mess.

We have heard from Senator Walsh quite a bit in defence of his very interesting speech to the Labor lawyers in Western Australia. That defence from Senator Walsh has been total bunkum. It would be worth while to examine in detail what he really did say and get it on the record in this place so that Senator Walsh will no longer with a straight face be able to pretend that he did not express strong disagreement with the policies or the rate of change, and indeed the bringing into effect of the policies that he says are his Government's. I quote from the transcript of what Senator Walsh said in Perth:

On the macro situation Australia is certainly not out of trouble. Indeed I'm a bit worried that the Budget might be oversold and that it will, even if the Government's not complacent, make the public complacent, and think that we can ship back into our old slothful ways and we don't have to worry any more.
He goes on:

Certainly, if there was another commodity price slide, the International Monetary Fund will be knocking on the door again. And I think we all know what would happen to the welfare sector if we are pushed to that point.

Julian Disney . . . correctly identified our problem with the current account deficit. A country which has a high level of foreign debt and a continuing large current account deficit is a country which has few options.

I interpose there to say that under this Government foreign debt has trebled as a result of deliberate Government policy and, of course, the balance of payments crisis just blew out under this Government. Senator Walsh went on:
The private borrowings-
which were referred to by Mr Disney in a previous paper at this conference-

are a symptom of our problem and not the cause. The fundamental cause is that current account deficit. The fact that for a number of years Australia has been consuming more from abroad including, of course, the interest that we have to pay abroad, than we have been selling abroad.

He then went on to say that Mr Disney had mentioned in his paper the analysis that the Economic Planning Advisory Council recently did about who gets what out of government expenditure. The conclusion was that the middle class or upper middle class couples tend to get more from total government expenditure than a lot of poor people on welfare. Senator Walsh went on to say:

That could be, I suggest, an argument for the introduction of means-tested fees for tertiary education because that is where a great deal of the money spent by governments and collected by the upper middle-class finishes up-in the provision of free tertiary education.
I wanted to put that on the record to make certain that Senator Walsh does not seek to wriggle out of that as well. He went on:

The suggestion, however, that wasn't made here but has been made before, that there should be a billion dollars collected in tax from the earnings of superannuation fund income and transferred to the welfare sector, has a very serious macro-economic flaw, and it is this: It is, of course, a proposal to divert a significant stream of savings into consumption-in other words, the precise opposite of what the country must do if it's going to get out of its economic problems.
If there are to be greater payments to welfare, they have to be payments which divert somebody else's consumption, not somebody's else's savings.
That is a very sensible comment from Senator Walsh and I think it is important to get it on the record. He continued:

Around about 1970, there was a middle-class push for non-profit, taxpayer-subsidised child care, preferably and usually, centre-based child care. Since the Hawke Government has been in office and when the 20,000 places child care policy has been completed, the number of child care places in the taxpayer-subsidised total will have almost doubled.
Many honourable senators opposite would congratulate the Government on that achievement; Senator Walsh does not. I will go on to say how he handles that problem. He stated:
As this industry becomes more unionised and professionalised-
that is the child care industry-
there will, without doubt, be demands to employ speech therapists, trained nurses, and whatever you can think of. And the costs per capita will increase as long as they remain on the public chit.

I ask the welfare sector to think about this. The sort of money that's going to be required to make this service at its present cost universal will not be available. The money could be found for a means-tested voucher system-that is, which people could present at private child care centres-which would then remove child care from the public sector and send it back to the private sector from whence, I believe, it should never have been enticed away.
Senator Walsh is now on the record in this place about privatising child care, and he is right. Senator Walsh continued:

We've been a lucky country for a long time, not so lucky any more and if we don't challenge most of the absurd notions that the majority of Australians have about what they are entitled to and what's essential to them and what isn't then we are going down the Argentinian road.

In effect Senator Walsh is arguing strongly for the sort of taxation and government spending policies that the Labor Government rejected when they were put up by the Opposition in the recent election campaign. The Labor Government viciously attacked the sort of concept that Senator Walsh presented. I think that underlines the extent to which there is major division and recognition within the Labor Party that its performance has been abysmal, that to a large extent the economic problems we now face are the direct result of the Labor Government's own indolence and, according to Senator Walsh, its lack of guts. Senator Walsh recalled the following anecdote of the Federal Labor Party Conference held last year. He said:

I was being proselytised and some bloke said what this is all about is to identify all those areas of government spending where . . . economic efficiency and social justice didn't justify the program . . . the Government should set up a unit to assess it.

Well I said in the Federal Government we have a unit already that does that, it's called the Department of Finance and if you want it, I can give you 200, a list of 200 bloody programs off the top of my head that can't be justified by social justice, equity or economic efficiency grounds, and the reason we haven't abandoned them is because we don't have the political courage to do so.

Senator Walsh said that and it is something from which he cannot escape and let us recognise this. As I outlined the other day in a notice of motion, when Senator Walsh refused to acknowledge in this place that there were still `200 bloody programs' that he could establish off the top of his head that should be cut and when he refused to outline what they were he was, in effect, admitting to this chamber that, in essence, they remain and that the Government still has not acted on them. If the point Senator Walsh made last year was accurate then, it is equally accurate now, and until he does something to demonstrate that action has been taken on these matters we, as an Opposition, have every right to regard Senator Walsh as a phoney when he pretends that he is no longer seen to be in conflict with the Government because this statement was made over a year ago. Senator Walsh says, `We have cut a lot of things since then'.

I ask Senator Walsh, as Senator Newman asked him the other day: will he reveal to the Senate the extent to which the Government has rejected or accepted his recommendations to cut the 200 programs he has targeted? If he is fair dinkum, will he indicate to the Senate the impact that such cuts would have made on the 1987-88 Budget and on Australia's economic outlook?

We now know that this Budget is inappropriate, that it does not do enough. Even worse, the Budget decisions are in conflict with what is required as outlined in the Budget Papers. The Budget Papers give clear indications of the things which should be done but which will, in fact, not be done. Mr Ross Gittins, in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 19 September, when talking about Budget Statement No. 2's conclusion, which he described as a `she'll be right' conclusion, made the following point:

This is an example of a Treasury trick used several times in the white paper on tax reform: a rigorous and highly persuasive exposition of the case for doing something, followed immediately by a conclusion that there was no need to do it after all.

We can see this kind of argument, for example, in the stated need to do something about the very slow rate at which improvement is expected in the current account deficit in the balance of payments which dominates Australia's economic situation and which may well pose an enormous risk to our economic future. The current account deficit has fallen as a percentage of gross domestic product from 6 per cent-an intolerable figure-in 1985-86 to about 5 per cent last financial year. This year it is projected by the Government to fall to about 4 per cent.

The Treasury Statement asks whether this pace of improvement is adequate and, in particular, whether practical policies could be implemented to achieve more rapid adjustment. The Treasury Statement then says that the more rapid the adjustments of policy instruments, the greater the risk of wage break-outs, of businesses being too uncertain to invest, and of short term recession and rising unemployment, which could make the strategy unsustainable. Ross Gittins refers to Treasury's `two-handed economists' who say one thing, and then give the totally opposite view. The Treasury Statement says:
. . . the longer the adjustment period, the greater is the build up in foreign debt and the greater the call on future income to service the debt.

Prolonging the adjustment period also means greater vulnerability to further shocks that are adverse to Australia's external performance (for example, a further deterioration in the terms of trade or export demand), and involves a more searching test of the patience of foreign creditors.

In other words, the Treasury outlines very clearly just how disastrous and serious is the failure of the Government to proceed much more rapidly down the correction road and how much more likely Senator Walsh's Argentinean road is to be followed if the Government continues with this failure, this masquerade, this dishonourable style of pretending that the Budget is solving the problems when the Treasury's own statements clearly indicate that it is not.

However, let us not depend just on the Treasury or on Senator Walsh for an analysis of what is wrong. Let us consider the annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia, a most revealing document. One of the things that it certainly reveals very effectively is just how phoney the balanced Budget is. The balanced Budget depends on a $2.6 billion payment from the Reserve Bank to the Commonwealth. That, of course, is an extraordinary amount. It is extraordinary because, in fact, it is unlikely that the Reserve Bank's profit will total that amount this year. Not only is it unlikely; it is certain it will not. Let me instance why. Out of its total profit of $2.6 billion in 1986-87-that is, last year-$1.9 billion came from net gains from sales of foreign currency. That is a temporary addition to the revenue of the Bank which will not be repeated if the Bank has anything to do with it, and that is shown very clearly in the bank's report. For example, the report states:
In the result-
that is in 1986-87-

the scale of the Reserve Bank's participation in the markets, and the consequent impact on the free operation of those markets, was much greater than the Bank would think appropriate as a continuing practice.

In other words, it does not want that level of intervention to continue. The report reveals-and this is even more dramatic-the Bank's gross turnover in the foreign exchange market was $US13 billion, compared with only $US1 1/2 billion in 1985-86. The report states:
Total market turnover doubled in 1986-87.

Those sorts of volumes are incredible and are of a once-off nature. They will simply not be repeated unless, of course, the Australian dollar comes under massive pressure. Maybe that is why the Government is expecting the Reserve Bank profit to remain high-because the Australian dollar is going to come under massive pressure. The Reserve Bank says:
In the course of providing a steadying influence-
that is, to the value of the Australian dollar-
the Bank's involvement in the market can be very high at times of strong pressure. This was the most important factor in the high volume of the bank's foreign exchange operations in 1986/87.

So, according to the Bank, it does not want, nor does it expect, that kind of volume to take place in the current financial year-a year from which the Government is expecting to bleed slightly more profits out of the Reserve Bank than it took last year. Not only that, but at this stage there is no profit in the currency holdings of the Reserve Bank to be taken in the event of sales. This, of course, is a vital issue. In its annual report the bank says:

Over recent years these increases have been substantially due to gains from the sale of foreign currency by the bank at prices (in Australian dollar terms) higher than those at which it was acquired. The average price at which the bank's present portfolio was acquired is close to the average market price and transactions at current prices would accrue little or no profits.

In other words, if the Bank went into the foreign exchange market now and sold its holdings of foreign currency, it would make no profit whatsoever. For the Bank to be able to earn a profit in foreign exchange dealings it has to be able to sell now at the current price, buy again later if the Australian dollar collapses and, if and when the Australian dollar rises again, sell those and make a profit. In other words, the only method by which the Reserve Bank can earn the sorts of profit that this Government is relying on is for it to take advantage of massive fluctuations in the value of the Australian dollar. If the Australian Government, the Commonwealth Treasury, the Treasurer, and the Minister for Finance expect that kind of massive fluctuation in the Australian dollar, let them come forward and honestly say so. Otherwise let them not take in a profit which will depend on massive Reserve Bank intervention in the foreign exchange market. I now comment very briefly on some of the other things the Reserve Bank said about the Government's economic policy. It says in respect of the latest financial year:
With other policy instruments less readily adaptable, for most of the year a heavy burden fell on monetary policy.

Let us just stop there. That means that the Go-vernment was not doing its job. Fiscal policy was inadequate, the Government's economic policies were a failure and, as a result-I repeat the bank's words-
With other policy instruments less readily adaptable-
in other words, the Government was not doing it-
for most of the year a heavy burden fell on monetary policy.
The Reserve Bank had to do the job again. The bank goes on:
High interest rates, and at times substantial involvement by the Bank in the foreign exchange and domestic money markets, were prices that had to be paid for this.

Let us get this clear. The Reserve Bank is saying that the huge interest rates of last year were the result of a failure of the Labor Party's economic policies. Let us also recognise that the reductions in interest rates that have taken place this year have nothing to do with Government policy. The Reserve Bank says:
Australian interest rates and exchange rates consequently are increasingly influenced by developments abroad.

Do not let the Government try to fool the people of Australia that the current reduction in interest rates is the result of some reward for good behaviour by this Government on an economic level. It is not. It is the result, as the Reserve Bank says, of pressures from overseas, of the fall in the American dollar and of the need for international people to find a temporary home for their money. That temporary home at the moment in Australia. When that international situation is reversed-as it must be-we will face the risk of massive outflows, and the Government's sham in this Budget will be totally exposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak in a Budget debate after Senator Michael Baume. Honourable senators on this side of the chamber will remember how well he assisted us during the election campaign just past. This is a sound Budget. It is far better than any Budget which would have been brought down had there been a different result at the last election. I do not intend to speak about the actual details of the Budget. I want to use this opportunity to speak about some educational matters. Education is mentioned in the Budget and it was mentioned recently in a statement by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), so it is pertinent that it be mentioned in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last decade Australia's education system has experienced a period of considerable growth and change. I intend to remark on some aspects of the changing educational environment, especially in relation to tertiary institutions. Before I address matters pertaining to universities and colleges, however, I shall make some remarks about the secondary level, where schools have been forced to adapt to the changing requirements of students. Secondary schools once had a comfortable existence and a well defined role. That role was to educate students to year 10, offering them a choice of courses-academic, manual, commercial or home science. Better students were then taken to years 11 and 12 and prepared for higher education. That role is now altered. As retention rates have increased more students, especially those at years 11 and 12 level, have required non-academic courses. The schools and their teachers have faced a period of adjustment, a process in which there is often a certain degree of discomfort. From my observations, teachers have adjusted to their new role and some are providing exciting courses which were unheard of some years ago.

The higher education sector has undergone a similar transformation. Enrolments in institutions of higher education have increased by approximately one-third, and a large proportion of this growth has occurred in advanced education. The number of students participating in full time study has increased, but there has also been significant emphasis on part time external study. Graduate and post-graduate studies are receiving more attention. There has been a movement away from teacher education towards business studies, science and the technologies. These changes in the numbers of students and types of courses they undertake have been reflected in changing patterns of participation in higher education. For instance, there is now a higher proportion of women students enrolled in institutions of higher education. Progress has also been made towards increasing participation rates for disadvantaged groups.

The new patterns of enrolment are the result of changes in community expectations and demands being made of higher education. The primary role of institutions of higher education has been to teach the able and for teaching staff to engage in research. This, too, has been a comfortable role. Unfortunately, some staff made their role even more comfortable by concentrating on neither teaching nor research. But the vexed question of tenure is not a matter I should pursue today. Increased enrolments, however, have focused attention on the quality of teaching and the types of courses being offered by universities and colleges of advanced education. The Australian community has a substantial continuing investment in higher education. About $2 billion to $3 billion is provided by the Australian Government to fund 19 universities and 45 colleges of advanced education (CAEs). This is over $7m a day, 365 days a year. The investment in buildings and equipment approximates $5,500m. The interest on this investment would be almost $2m per day. This is a massive expenditure and is often overlooked when people criticise the Commonwealth contribution to higher education.

The Commonwealth Government is indeed being asked to provide even more funds to build universities and colleges and to extend existing facilities. As student numbers increase, the recurrent funds required to operate institutions of higher education also rise. Before providing additional funds it is essential that the Commonwealth ensures that existing facilities are being used efficiently and effectively. Funds for tertiary education come from the taxpayer and it is incumbent on governments to use those funds wisely. As well, any funds made available for education obviously are not available for the many worthwhile purposes to which money may be directed. Therefore the Government should be congratulated that in 1985 it requested that the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission-CTEC as it is normally known-initiate an inquiry into ways of improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the higher education sector. A committee was established to assist the Commission in the review, and last year that committee released a report entitled `Review of Efficiency and Effectiveness in Higher Education'.

The committee's task was to inquire into ways of improving the efficiency and effectiveness of higher education in Australia. The committee approached this task by first reviewing the nature and extent of changes in the utilisation of resources since the Commonwealth assumed full funding responsibility for higher education in 1974-at a time of a previous Labor Government, it should be recalled. It then considered a number of areas identified in the terms of reference in which further improvement in efficiency and effectiveness may be possible. These included the utilisation of facilities, use of new technologies, staffing mechanisms and delivery of courses, as well as measures to monitor performance and improve accountability.

I intend to comment on the committee's examination of the potential for achieving better utilisation of resources. This topic is covered by Chapter 4 of the committee's report. By way of introduction the committee described the nature of higher education facilities and their patterns of utilisation. Higher education institutions operate a vast number of facilities to accommodate a range of activities. Approximately half the total floor space takes the form of classrooms and laboratories. Teaching facilities range from conventional classrooms or lecture theatres to various types of laboratories and workshops. Offices for academic staff account for some 10 to 20 per cent of space. Academic services, encompassing areas such as libraries, central computing, audio-visual facilities and the like, account for a further 10 to 15 per cent of the space. The remaining space, some 20 to 30 per cent for most institutions, is used for central administration, maintenance areas, student and staff facilities and sporting facilities. Table 4.1 of the committee's report summarises the way in which space is used at universities and CAEs.

On average, the teaching activities of higher education institutions extend over 58 hours per week with some institutions operating for up to 70 hours a week. The academic year operates from February to November and normally includes between 30 and 35 weeks of teaching. Facilities are used more intensively over the academic year than during the period between academic years, since most students are absent over the summer months. Activities which cannot be undertaken or which would be difficult to undertake during the academic year are scheduled for this period. Teaching staff revise and update course material, develop new courses, arrange for course accreditation and prepare teaching aids. Technical staff set up laboratory experiments. Maintenance is also carried out. With the reduced demand on library facilities, culling, reclassifying and recataloguing is scheduled for the summer period. The time of peak activity in student administration also occurs between the academic years. To investigate the potential for increased use of teaching facilities during the academic year, the Committee commissioned a study to:
determine measures of utilisation, to assess levels being achieved by institutions and to examine time-tabling procedures and other factors which may affect utilisation.

The purpose of the survey was to `collect the information necessary to calculate utilisation measures for each institution'. Such measures can be used to assist institutions in assessing how well they are managing physical facilities. Two measures are in use in the United States of America: room utilisation, to indicate the degree to which rooms are used, is measured by the average number of hours for which rooms are in use; seat utilisation, to indicate the level of occupancy when rooms are in use, is measured by the proportion of seats occupied for rooms in use. General teaching space in Australian institutions is used on average for 27 hours per week. Specialist teaching space is in use for 21 hours per week. Seat utilisation in Australian institutions averaged 57 per cent for general teaching space and 56 per cent for specialised teaching space. Table 4.2 of the committee's report outlines a comparison between measures for Australian higher education and equivalent institutions in three areas of the United States.

The committee went on to outline those factors which affect rates of utilisation and which could be manipulated to improve the use of facilities. It was, in fact, discovered that certain institutional characteristics affected levels of utilisation, and some of those would not be surprising. Institutions located in or near large population centres have a greater potential for higher room utilisation than do regional institutions. The former usually have longer hours of operation because they are readily accessible for students through public transport systems. Larger institutions can generally attain a higher room utilisation than smaller ones, through the added timetabling flexibility which arises from having a larger number of teaching facilities with a range of room sizes. Relatively new institutions are more likely to have lower room utilisation rates than established institutions. The potential for evening use of class rooms depends in part on the extent of part time enrolments.

The committee also found that other factors can be influenced by the management practices of the institution. The study showed that the pattern of room usage over the days of the week can affect utilisation. Usage is significantly lower on Friday than on mid-week days. In fact, in similar institutions in Queensland hardly anyone can be found on Friday afternoon. Table 4.2 of the committee's report indicated the room utilisation for each day from Monday to Friday and for the weekend. By extending the hours of operation into the evening it may be possible to increase utilisation. In fact, a cost analysis suggested that use of evening classes is a cost-effective way of obtaining additional capacity. Already many institutions use evening hours extensively to conduct classes, largely to meet a demand from part-time students. The committee argued, however, that a greater use of evenings to schedule classes for full-time students may not be feasible or even desirable. This would involve a departure from the standard working day. There may also be transport difficulties for students to gain access to the institutions in the evening. These considerations would also apply to extending teaching activities to Saturday and Sunday. Currently teaching facilities are rarely used at the weekend. The committee recommended that where practicable:
Institutions should seek to meet a demand for weekend classes from part-time and external students where this exists, and endeavour to provide access to libraries and computing services.

By more effective timetabling, institutions would be able to offer a wider choice of subjects and to schedule classes at times most suitable for students. One surprising finding of the committee was that only a quarter of the institutions use computer-assisted procedures for timetabling. I suggest that it is surprising because many universities and CAEs offer courses in computer studies. The application of computer techniques to timetabling may allow institutions to achieve more effective utilisation.

The committee concluded that while `there may be potential for increased utilisation in some institutions, this will not, for the most part, ease the pressure for additional capital expenditure'. It stated that the Government's program for growth in higher education needs to be `planned carefully and directed to locations of greatest need'. The priorities for growth include `outer metropolitan areas which have large populations with relatively poor access to tertiary education, and certain States and regions where it is necessary to overcome relative deficiencies that have developed over many years'. I have no doubt that the State which I represent suffers in its provision of higher education because of neglect in years gone by.

The committee also examined the possibility of achieving better utilisation of facilities through `year-round teaching'. Since the length of the teaching year for most universities and colleges is between 30 and 35 weeks, an extension of teaching activities over a longer period of the year would appear to offer the potential to achieve better utilisation of physical facilities.

Three possible approaches to year-round teaching are considered in the report. They are continuous study, staggered teaching and summer term. If a program of continuous study is adopted courses run continuously through the year with no summer break. If widely adopted, the very nature of higher education would be altered. Many students depend on the summer period to generate income to support their studies. Few students could cope with the concentrated educational load. After the first two years the more rapid growth of graduate numbers could cause unemployment to rise. For these reasons the committee considered that this approach-that is, the approach of continuous study-was not a feasible option.

In the staggered teaching approach, courses remain at their current length but with an additional teaching period introduced within the year. Units are then repeated during the year to achieve a balanced pattern of teaching. There are two forms of staggered teaching-the trimester and quarter systems. Any one student would not attend a continuous sequence of terms or semesters, but on average would be free for one term or semester each year. In the case of the trimester system there are two principal methods. The first assumes three groups of students, equal in number, with group X attending trimesters A and B, group Y trimesters A and C, and group Z trimesters B and C. The second method would admit students by trimesters and simply continue on the assumption that the normal student year is two trimesters. These two methods are represented on page 124 of the committee's report.

Certain benefits could be derived from the staggered teaching approach. Institutions and government could gain from the more intensive use of facilities and, to a lesser extent, service facilities. Some students may be able to complete a course in a shorter time than is possible at present. The economy could benefit to a small degree through a reduction in the time taken for higher education to respond to demands and trends in the labour market. The committee did, however, highlight certain negative consequences of staggered teaching. Unemployment would rise unless graduates were absorbed into the work force at a more rapid rate. Institutions would also incur additional teaching costs. More lecturers may be required. Staggered teaching would also involve significant administrative difficulties as the student intake would need to be distributed over the year.

For these reasons the committee saw little merit in the introduction of staggered teaching arrangements to Australian higher education. It argued that the `potential financial benefits through a more intensive utilisation of facilities are likely to be illusory, being more than offset by additional teaching and other salary costs'. Furthermore, `such a change in teaching arrangements would generate significant administrative and social difficulties as well as interfering with many essential activities.'

A third approach, the summer term, was also examined. In this case the current semester or term system would be retained, as would be the existing pattern of teaching over the traditional academic year. An additional teaching period would be introduced during the long vacation to meet particular teaching needs. Activities currently being undertaken during summer term include: continuing education, external studies, remedial courses, bridging courses, language courses, professional upgrading, special interest seminars, cultural, sporting and community activities. While there is a wide range of activities, the overall utilisation of teaching facilities over the summer period is low for most institutions. The committee therefore recommended that `institutions examine the potential for offering additional courses outside normal academic periods to facilitate academic progress and improve access, particularly for disadvantaged students.'

The major conclusions drawn by the committee, with regard to the utilisation of resources, may be summarised as follows. On the issue of year-round teaching it was found that there was `no scope for major economies in institutional operations'. The introduction of year-round teaching would `increase costs rather than produce savings'. The committee argued, however, that there is scope for institutions to use their resources more efficiently if they `continue to take advantage of opportunities to extend teaching activities beyond traditional teaching times, where this is appropriate.' The committee concluded that improved performance by higher education institutions in the management of their resources could be achieved only if they engaged in `forward planning on a systematic basis.'

The reaction to the report has been favourable. A number of higher education institutions have established committees to consider various aspects of it. Others have begun studies into the management and utilisation of resources. As the committee considered that year-round teaching offered no scope for major economies in operations, nothing more has been done in this regard. However, certain recommendations concerning the extension of teaching activities beyond the traditional times have been adopted. For instance, the committee suggested that the Commission review its policy on the calculation of student load-which is, of course, the basis for funding-in relation to enrolments in bridging courses. I understand that this recommendation is being acted upon.

I have concentrated my remarks on the teaching role of universities and CAEs. It should not be interpreted that I regard the research roles of higher education institutions as unimportant-far from it. But with more and more students going on from Year 12 to universities and CAEs, it is important that the teaching role and the utilisation of teaching facilities comes under scrutiny.

Although the committee did not make any breakthrough in the way in which institutions of higher education can manage their facilities, it did identify areas where the institutions' administrators should direct their attention. It is important for each institution to gain value for the funds it receives. Similarly, it is important for the public to obtain value for their tax dollars which are used to fund universities and CAEs. The Government should therefore expect that, before calls are made upon it for more funds, institutions are doing everything possible to use existing funds efficiently and effectively. The committee appropriately remarked:

How well institutions manage and use the resources available to them affects the number of places which can be provided for Australians to participate in higher education and influences the quality of teaching and research activities.

Mr Acting Deputy President, before I conclude, I take this opportunity, albeit probably late, of congratulating you on taking the chair for the first time. I did not do so at the beginning of my speech because at that time you were not there. Now that you have taken the chair, it is pleasing for me, as a Queenslander who ran on the same Senate team in the last election, to be able to be the first to congratulate you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator.

—In conclusion, I look forward to institutions of higher education making increasing efforts to use their existing facilities efficiently and to allocate their recurrent funds wisely. I also look forward to the Federal Government stressing that additional funds will be provided only when it is persuaded that current funds are being applied in the best possible way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been basking in the sunshine of some favourable Press interpretations of the Budget that Australia is now on the road to recovery. A few simple but very worrying facts tend to query this smug assumption-or at least they tend to cast a few shadows across those abundant rays of sunshine. It is true that we welcome a nearly balanced Budget, the first for many years. But I warn honourable senators: do not judge this very large book by the glossy cover or the initial interpretations. We also welcome the lesser reliance on monetary policy and a slow but perceptible move towards fiscal restraint. Indeed, I would go so far as to venture that the Keating Government has taken a turn off that Argentinean road.

SPEECH.PARA: I contrast this Federal Budget with our own Tasmanian State Budget that was brought down yesterday. The ingredients and the contrasts are notable. Firstly, Tasmania will generate more wealth. Federally, the Australian Labor Party Government is putting emphasis on collecting more and more revenue-taking more and more overall from the people. The second important principle of the Tasmanian Budget is that the State will live more within its own means. What is happening federally? More and more money is coming in from overseas to prop up the current account deficit. Australia is selling the farm. Our land prices and stocks and shares, in terms of the yen, are at bargain basement prices. Many Australians are becoming very worried at increasing amounts of property and real estate, including beachside resorts-I am not just talking about prime central real estate in the central business district-that is being bought by overseas people. The Government has thrown out the Foreign Investment Review Board, and Australia is being bought up day by day by overseas people. In other words, we are not living within our means and, as a result, we are cheapening the prices of our assets and ourselves.

The third feature of the Tasmanian Budget is that Tasmanians will become entrepreneurial. On the other hand, I remind honourable senators that I have been on the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for something like 10 years now and I am rather disturbed at all the reports I read from Federal Government departments and statutory organisations about their lack of commitment towards setting attainable goals. True, they set out some broad objectives in their charter, but each year there is a failure to show how they perform against measurable standards of performance. These departments and statutory bodies just plod along without an entrepreneurial direction and without proper performance standards being reached.

Fourthly, the State of Tasmania is going to make the best use of its resources. Tasmania seeks a balance between development and conservation. In other words, this recipe of the State's reliance on enterprise is, I think, a feature that the Hawke-Keating Government could well adopt as a recipe for Australia's recovery.

Let us look at some of those simple but very worrying facts that tend to cast some doubt upon these smug assumptions that Australia is now on the road to recovery. If we go outside Canberra into the real Australia, into the suburbs and on to the farms, we will find that real household disposable income has actually fallen. That is the figure that has some meaning to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to me and to the ordinary Australian. It might not mean much to the bureaucrats or the newspaper editors, but it is important to the ordinary Australian. The fact that our real household disposable income actually fell last year is a worrying sign. This is the first fall in 30 years. We did not see that mentioned in the Budget Papers, did we? Even under the policies of the Whitlam Government we did not see this sort of thing happen. People's living standards are declining. This is a result of the policies of this Hawke Labor Government. These facts are being pushed under the carpet. They have not been highlighted by the Press; they are not on the first page of the Budget, but every Australian knows that he is worse off than he was in the previous year. How has this come about? Per capita consumption went down by one per cent, the first fall in 25 years. In fact, it is the first fall since 1961-62.

Let us look at the breakdown in what is termed per capita consumption. The non-durable element went up by 1.7 per cent. Again, it is an element that has not been publicised by Mr Keating. That element having gone up means that the overall figure is so much worse. Food consumption fell by 1.3 per cent. In other words, people do not have the same capacity as they had before to spend the same amount of money on food. The consumption of durable goods went down by 8.9 per cent. I suppose that is because people do not have the ability to own their own homes as was once the case. This feature of home ownership has been something for Australians to be proud of, to boast about over many years.

Overseas perceptions about the unstable state of Australia were brought home to me only three weeks ago when I was privileged to dine with some bankers in South East Asia. I was introduced as `The good Australian senator from down under'. The South East Asians are very polite, but I suppose that was the most flattering thing I heard all night. They followed that comment by saying, `The good senator comes from Australia, the big land down under, where they pay themselves more to go on holidays than when they are at work'. The laughs of derision made me feel somewhat uncomfortable. Apart from their jealousy of our wide open spaces and our abundance of natural resources, there was not much else in their conversation that was really comforting to me coming from Australia. The reality is that never have the people of this country faced such a depressing year in terms of a decline in living standards and economic pro-gress. The important thing to realise is that the last year was not a statistical aberration as some would suggest because real average earnings have contracted by nearly 7 per cent since March 1983 when the Hawke-Keating Government was elected. One might say that all these are pretty dry figures but they do show that Australia is in a very much more fragile state than the Trea-surer and most of the media, and even Senator Walsh, would care to admit, although I must say that of late Senator Walsh has had the temerity, or may I say the honesty, to try to put a little bit of dampener on the policies. He can see certain dangers in going along the path suggested by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). There are flaws in the strategy of this Budget. While we welcome, as I said, this move to a more balanced Budget, the means of achie-ving this are suspect.

My background is in accounting, and one of the first accounting principles that I was told about was that when there is an abnormal, a one-off or an unusual item it is not to be included in the net profit, it is to be shown below the line and it is explained to the world, as it were, as an extraordinary item. We have two significant items that really should have been below the line or that deserved special mention as extraordinary items. My colleague Senator Michael Baume spent some time talking about that extraordinary profit that came from the Reserve Bank of Australia amounting to several billion dollars. There is also the sale of assets. In other words, we create wealth by selling assets. The Budget Papers also revealed that we are paying off some of our international indebtedness but at the same time we are having to borrow to pay back that indebtedness. What a contradiction in terms. Fortunately, that one did not go down too well. There are a lot of other weaknesses within this Budget.

The Budget Papers are not as accurate as one would have us believe. I would like to mention, for example, the $5.7m which was allegedly given by this Government to the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology in the Budget on Tuesday night. But it was snatched away 24 hours later. The Institute noted the unexpected grants, so naturally it contacted Mr Keating's office. But the Treasurer, his staff, and officers of the Commonwealth Department of the Treasury could not shed any light on the matter. By the Wednesday evening following the Budget, the Treasury phoned the Tasmanian Institute of Technology and apologised for what was referred to as a careless typographical error. Even if it was a typographical error, where has this not insubstantial amount of almost $6m been reallocated to? Who has got it? I submit that there are other items of this nature which indicate a high degree of carelessness within the Budget.

The real clue to our economic recovery is surely to try to seek out and develop strategies that will lead to a versatile manufacturing and services area. This is essential in order to offset the higher level of imports. But the policy that the Government is now pursuing is leading to a rise in the value of the Australian dollar which is giving greater encouragement to imports, entering Australia and therefore competing more effectively against Australian made products. When the Australian dollar was down in the low 60c range against the United States dollar, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, warned against the dollar entering the 70c range.
