TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney would have been all the more convincing if he had told the truth about Senator Walsh, whose signature was alongside Mr Keating's on the Budget that was delivered here last Tuesday week. As has since been found out, there is a vast conflict within the Government and the Cabinet as to the direction of economic policy in this country. Only last Sunday, Senator Walsh absolutely exploded the myth that this was somehow a great Budget. He destroyed any concept or understanding in the popular mind that somehow Mr Keating had defied gravity and brought peace in our time in the economic world. Senator Walsh told the truth about the economic situation. He pointed to the basic and fundamental imbalances that have been generated under the Hawke Labor Government since it came to power in March 1983.
—There is a Rastafarian up there about to jump on you.

—The Acting Deputy President had better watch out, in that case. The fundamental point has to be made that the Walsh statement of last Sunday has destroyed all credibility in this Budget and in the economic policy of the Government. That is where I would like to start my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that over the last several years we have seen fundamental changes, not only in the Australian economy, but also in the world economy. When we talk about the world perhaps the most significant factor to bear in mind is that there has been a major redistribution of international wealth, firstly to the nations of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, with the oil price rises of the mid-1970s, and secondly, to Japan. These profound movements in wealth ownership, together with the dramatic changes in the way in which the international financial system has been operating recently, have altered the entire basis of world trade and business dealings. Moreover, in the last few years we have seen these changes threaten the standard of living of all Australians and, potentially, the fabric of Australian society.

The relative stability of the period from the end of World War II until now has fundamentally changed to such an extent that we now operate in a highly unstable, and increasingly unstable, world financial environment. The implications for Australia as a small trading nation are profound and go to the heart of government policy making. Senator Walsh was honest enough to refer to that in his remarks to the Labor lawyers conference last Sunday. It is imperative that the Government firstly recognises the significance of the recent changes in world trade and the world economy and, secondly, tackles the difficult economic problems facing this country.

The Australian economy suffers from at least four specific structural problems to which I will now refer. Firstly, the recent change in the structure of the Australian economy has been dramatic. In 1950 the agricultural sector accounted for 24 per cent of our total production. Today that is down to a mere 4 per cent of total economic activity. At the moment the mining industry accounts for about 5 per cent of our total production. Its relative importance has more than doubled over the past 25 years. However, those two sectors together represent a very small part of the overall economy in Australia. The vast bulk of Australian economic activity is generated in the tertiary or services sector covering such things as commerce, finance, community services, tourism and entertainment, transport, communications and building. Any government's policies which are designed, for example, to increase our exports must take account of the way in which that fundamental change to our economy has occurred.

The second point is that we still face intolerable burdens from inflation. We know that the inflation rate at some 9 per cent at present is two to three times greater than that in countries such as Japan, the United States of America and the United Kingdom.
Senate Maguire-They were up to 6 per cent this morning.
Senate MESSNER-Yes, I did hear that this morning. I noted that with a great deal of interest.

The third key problem results, at least in part, from the high inflation rate and it relates to the structural problems of low rates of investment in new plant, new equipment and new businesses in this country. In any period of recession or sustained high inflation businessmen will always face a massive disincentive to invest in plant. That has been absolutely true since this Government came to power as there have been successive years of decline in investment in new productive enterprises. That is a fact of life and it has been driven chiefly by a lack of incentive deriving from high interest rates and, of course, from very high inflation relative to the rest of the world. That means that fewer job opportunities for Australians will spring from increased economic activity in the future.

The fourth point I make is that the balance of payments problem in this country has now been recognised as chronic. In the 37 years since 1950, Australia has recorded a current account deficit in all but four of those years. But that deficit has grown dramatically over the last 10 years or so. For instance, since 1980 the proportion of gross domestic product taken up by the current account balance of payments deficit has doubled to 5 per cent. In each of the last three years under the Hawke Labor Government-from 1985 to 1987-the current account deficit has actually been above that level at around 5.2 per cent. To make up that deficit, Australia has had to borrow. Consequently, the level of our borrowings has lifted dramatically in that time. As we know, those borrowings are now $109,000m compared with about $30,000m in 1983.

All of these things, and those four points in particular, indicate that we have a serious structural problem in Australia which has yet to be addressed. The Opposition agrees wholeheartedly with the analysis of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) at the Labor lawyers conference last Sunday where he indicated that this Government does not have its policy objectives right and that it has not set in train the processes by which it will achieve success in the long run. Indeed, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) now stands alone as one proclaiming bravely in the face of all the storms that the Australian economy is in the best state that it has been in for many years and looks good for the future. That was the message of his Budget as it was sold last Tuesday week and now Senator Walsh has put that concept down totally.

I now turn to the question of the international economy and where Australia sits in relation to that. There is no doubt that in recent years there have been many different strands to international economic development. Most of these are interrelated. Firstly, I refer to the volatility and the changing structure of world trade which has led to Japan's meteoric rise, alongside the United States of America, to pre-eminence as the major powerhouse economy in the world. Japan is now the world's largest creditor nation, a position which it has secured rapidly over the last few years-that is, it is owed a great deal more money by the rest of the world than it owes to the rest of the world. By contrast, the United States is in exactly the opposite situation. It has moved from being the world's greatest creditor nation in the early 1970s to a debtor nation. Most of its debt is being funded by the Japanese. These fundamental changes are reflected in our trade figures world wide. In 1986, whereas Japan recorded a current account payment surplus of $US65,000m, the United States recorded a deficit of just over double that figure. The latest figures show a dramatic continuation of this situation, with Japan expected to record a current account surplus of almost $US100 billion in 1987 and the United States a deficit of $US145,000m.

It is quite chastening to note that the net cash inflow to Japanese financial institutions from the ordinary savings, bank accounts and stock market investments of the Japanese people, amounts to $633,000m this year. To put the figure into some perspective, it represents 20 per cent of the capitalised value of all companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Twenty per cent of the value of companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange is represented by the savings every year of the Japanese people. Japan's high trade surplus, together with the thriftiness of the Japanese, who typically save around 17 per cent of their annual income, has meant that the Japanese economy is literally awash with surplus money.

Japan faces a liquidity crisis in reverse of a magnitude never before experienced in the industrialised world. It is so awash with cash that there are simply not enough domestic opportunities for investment. Most of that excess cash will find its way overseas in search of investment opportunities. About one-third of that $600 billion net cash surplus in Japan will be invested overseas this year. In order to understand the value of that money, let us consider that the gross production value of Australian goods and services is $260 billion. So the amount of Japanese funds which are available for investment is getting very close to the total production of the Australian economy. Other statistics highlight this growing problem in the world economy. But there is no doubt that the world, particularly the United States and, increasingly, Australia, is becoming more and more dependent upon the use of the funds generated within Japan by Japanese savings institutions.

The second part of this growing change in the world economic scene concerns the huge amount of excess liquidity in the world's financial markets, the largest of which is Japan. The fact is that the vast and rapidly growing amount of credit available throughout the world is the root of current instability in exchange rates and the movement in world currencies. The origin of this unprecedented explosion of credit facilities which now brings into question the world's economic system goes back to the Bretton Woods agreement after the end of World War II. At that time, as we all remember, the United States dollar was given the status of an international reserve currency. But for decades, and particularly since the early days of the Vietnam War, successive American governments have simply created additional United States dollars to finance the balance of payments deficit. An ever-increasing amount of United States dollars is accepted by its world trading partners.

That has led to the rapid growth of the Euro-dollar market, which almost rivals the Japanese market in terms of funds available for investment throughout the world. Those funds totalled about $48 billion in 1983 but the figure has now reached $136 billion. That is a staggering increase. But the total amount outstanding in Euro-bonds now-that is, money eventually to be repatriated to the United States of America-is $550,000m. That is just as much of a meteoric rise as the expansion of the Japanese savings that I referred to earlier, but those huge cash surpluses are part of a larger problem. It boils down to this: there is a huge amount of excess money in the world which is simply not finding its way into productive investment in order to develop job opportunities throughout the world. Australia, of course, cannot be immune from these developments.

To put the matter into perspective, in 1985 the total amount of world credit available for various means of investment was sufficient to finance the world trade total some 25 times. Therefore, the amount of money washing around the world equals world trade multiplied by 25. When we have that volume of money moving, as it does, almost at the speed of light through electronic transfers, we can understand the effects that might be having on various economies.

The challenge is how Australia can adapt itself to take advantage of this situation. We are seeing unprecedented investment in Australia from various overseas sources. We are seeing money from Japan particularly pouring into real estate development and into the stock market. We must note that that is not, as it appears, a temporary aberration; it is clearly something which is continuing to grow and develop and which we need to take account of. The challenge is not to say, `Okay; we must set about regulating this flow of money'. That is not the answer. The real question is how this country can generate new productive investment in new plant and equipment and new businesses to generate job opportunities for Australians. That is the challenge ahead of the Australian economy.

I return to the original point. This country, under the Hawke Labor Government, has seen successive years of decline in productive investment. That decline is continuing. That needs to be addressed, and it certainly has not been addressed in the Keating Budget. I reiterate that Senator Walsh has said that. He, as a co-author of the Budget, has as much as said that the Budget does not represent a proper appraisal of the economic problems facing Australians. He said that he thought the Budget has been oversold as to its good points and consequently was not addressing the main issues ahead of us. I think he is right. The truth is that we need to make sure that our policies are correct. We need to develop an alternative strategy designed to generate more jobs and future opportunities for Australians.

I would like to deal with a point raised by Senator Cooney. He always gives most interesting speeches. He referred to the ID card. He gave us a rather interesting but long discourse on the constitutional history of the card. What has happened in the last day or two boils down to one simple thing: the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who had the carriage of this legislation for about two years, overlooked entirely the fact that, although his piece of legislation, he may have thought, was adequate when it was first written back in 1986 for the purposes of being put before Parliament, everything changed when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) decided to call a double dissolution and to go to an election in July. The Bill was not suitable to be put into place when the Prime Minister knew that the Australian Labor Party had no chance of gaining a majority in the Senate, where the regulations to be set up under the legislation could always be disallowed. That is a major fault of the Hawke Labor Government. The row of geniuses, as they are supposed to be, on the other side have finally been found out by the Press and the people of Australia. They simply do not understand, as we in the Opposition have known for a long time, how hopeless they are in getting their legislative machinery right. The classic case of that is the unholy mess of the capital gains tax legislation which they enacted in a great rush about a year and a half ago. Of course, there are plenty of other examples.

Those things need to be remembered by the people of Australia. The people of Australia had an enormous victory yesterday when it was discovered that the identity card legislation will not and cannot be put in place. I believe that as many as one-third of the members of the Labor Party are secretly supportive of that move and glad that it has occurred. I think it can be welcomed by the members of the Liberal and National parties as well. The people and certainly the Parliament will know that we have opposed this piece of legislation ever since it was first announced in September 1985, and that we maintain that opposition. It behoves the Opposition, which has given a commitment to the Australian people to oppose such heinous legislation, to do everything in its power to stop the legislation being put into effect, and that includes rejecting the kinds of regulations that would have been established under the legislation.

I finalise my remarks by saying that the Budget is not the appropriate Budget for Australia in these times. I have tried to give an outline of the reasons why I believe that. It is not the huge success, the brilliant message for the Australian people, which the Press in some cases have tended to characterise it as. It is wrong. Senator Walsh is right and should be pushing within the Cabinet with all his power to make sure that the Government adopts a proper policy line in its economic deliberations.

We face an exciting possibility in Australia as we move towards the training of that human capital. Many people in Australia, including business people, are interested in the capital equipment and all the physical things that make up industry and our service industries, but at the same time fail to develop human capital.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Employment, Education and Training in his statement recognised that Australia's economic potential has been held back by an inadequate commitment to skills formation and deficiencies in training arrangements. The Budget initiatives in this regard include increasing participation in education and training; improving the quality and structure of courses and training arrangements; seeking more efficient commitment and contribution to training; providing employment and training opportunities for the unemployed and the disadvantaged. One of the other characteristics in referring to human capital in Australia is that for so long we have wasted the unemployed and the disadvantaged in our community.

I was pleased to be at the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) congress a few weeks ago when that historic meeting adopted the Australia Reconstructed document as a theme for its activities. This shows the closeness of thinking between the Government and the trade union movement as both move to make sure that there is a reduction of poverty and that education and training are improved. These are the essential planks of the Australia Reconstructed document. The document was the final report of a joint ACTU-Trade Development Council mission to Western Europe. It was a significant report and contains, in the words of John Dawkins:
Observations and recommendations of one of the most important missions mounted on Australia's behalf.

The Minister said that at the launch of the document and it is absolutely true. That mission went to the successful countries of Europe. It visited Sweden, Austria and West Germany. The trade union leaders were able to see how other countries integrate and plan their economies. This is very close to the style of this Government in encouraging tripartite initiatives. Australia Reconstructed is a creative report and shows the depth of commitment to maintaining Australia's international competitiveness and tackling our balance of payments problem. John Dawkins, in an almost parallel move this week, has issued a document which enables us to examine our educational facilities, with the aim of trying to bring them into keeping with the needs of both industry and commerce. It also seeks to ensure that our academic institutions are in a position to take us through the next decade-a decade which will have many challenges.

The essential point that must be emphasised in the packages that this Government has successfully negotiated is the theme of trying to look to the development of human capital. These ongoing projects-including the steel industry plan, the textile clothing and footwear plan and the heavy engineering plan-represent this Government's aim to make sure that the training of our work force is improved, and that people who are not in the work force will get the opportunity to be trained for it.

It is significant that the ACTU delegates who went overseas were impressed with the fact that a country such as Sweden has the reverse ratio to Australia vis-a-vis unemployment payments to training payments. The ratio in Australia is still heavily biased in paying unemployment benefit, whereas in Sweden the whole emphasis is on training. There is a move in this Budget to change the emphasis so that people will not be left to stagnate, but will be given the opportunity to enter the work force. This is particularly true of those who are most disadvantaged, particularly women and people who have been out of work for any length of time. These proposals contain the essential elements of an active labour market policy. I refer to skill formation including skill flexibility, adaptability and capacity for innovation and job placement-in other words, matching supply and demand.

As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade, I know that that Committee had a great deal of evidence placed before it to the effect that in many areas there are not the skilled people available to fulfil the demands of industry. It is an indictment of our system that we have not co-ordinated our system sufficiently to train people for the needs of industry and commerce. I welcome as part of the Budget process Mr Dawkins's statement-indeed his demand-that Australia should shake itself out of its lethargy so that we integrate our country. Often we have been prepared to accept a system involving State rivalries, rivalries between institutions and have not been able to get the maximum benefits for the casualties of our system-the unemployed and people who have not been trained so as to be able to advance through industry to take higher positions in industry.

Australia has an exciting opportunity in the next few years to change the direction in which we have been moving so that we may develop the capital that we have been wasting for so long. This has happened because we have been prepared to take a laissez-faire approach to the labour market and to allow people to do their own thing. If people are unemployed, they are left to their private suffering. Unfortunately, there are people on the conservative side of politics who condemn and denigrate the victims of society, the people who have not been able to obtain work.

Under the Budget the payment of unemployment benefit will be the last resort, and surely that is what we must try to aim at. The Australia Reconstructed document produced by the ACTU, and endorsed by the trade union movement, involves a move towards this policy. It says:
The most striking aspect of active labour market policies is the emphasis placed on skill formation, skill enhancement, skill flexibility and overall training.

Another aspect that this approach encompasses is to make the transition from school to work as smooth as possible. That may seem very trite, yet at the moment it is not done as effectively as it should be. We also need to combat labour market segmentation to lessen the imbalance in the labour market and to lessen disadvantage to women, the aged and the disabled. Some people fail to see the cost to Australia of our not using women, the disabled and the aged, although the age of people in the aged group is dropping each year as middle aged people have difficulty staying in the work force. That is a challenge to Australia and it is one that this Government is fully cognisant of, and this Budget attempts to correct the situation.

The implementation of the report's recommendation in relation to vocational education complement other existing forms of education which are important for the development of a vital economy alongside a vibrant culture, and the recommended growth in research and development and more innovative manufacturing show a maturity in perception that could enhance tripartite co-operation. Many people criticise the development of tripartite discussions, but due to the work of the Australian Manufacturing Council, and from the development of the Government's packages, we now have an identification of the problems and a mutual search for the solutions to those problems that has not previously occurred.

If Australia is to compete in a world in which commodity prices for our agricultural and mineral products have dropped so dramatically, we must be more scientific in the way we address those problems. Until now, the conservative parties in this country have believed that we can let everything rip and allow a jungle-like situation to develop. If we look at the debate during the last election campaign, we see that the Opposition was following the Thatcher model-a model of pitting the wealthy against the poor; a model which has meant in England that in vast regional areas high unemployment is the order of the day, and most people there face a very bleak future because there is no positive culture and no positive approach to a revitalisation of manufacturing generally because the Thatcher Government has no plan to encourage people to develop their skills and an attitude which would help them to revitalise their manufacturing industry. Significantly, this Government is rejecting the Thatcher-type New Right model that some people in the Opposition support. It is seeking to develop all the resources of our country so that we can reduce our unemployment level, which is still too high, even further.

The other aspect of the Government's approach to developing our human capital is its magnificent initiative of trying to eliminate child poverty. I will return to this theme a little later, but for the moment I just want to say that we cannot hope for a successful economy if we do not make sure that our children are not living in poverty. No child can be expected to live in poverty and then to have an equal chance of success in society.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the context of both the Budget that is under consideration and the statement that was made in the Senate the other day on behalf of Mr Dawkins, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, entitled `The Challenge for Higher Education in Australia', I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate the anomaly that the new Northern Territory University College has not at this stage been picked up by the Government for adequate or proper financial support. SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that Senator Susan Ryan would be well aware of the very generous grants to, and indeed the very high student servicing costs at, the Australian National University in her electorate, and the fact that the Government has made very sympathetic funding arrangements for universities. I am sure that Senator Ryan, in her previous capacity as Minister for Education, would also be well aware of the many initiatives taken and points of view that have been put for the tertiary students from the Northern Territory who are forced to travel thousands of kilometres interstate to study. changes in attitudes, to reflect national imperatives and to ensure that the education system is more flexible and capable of responding quickly and positively to national needs;
changes in processes, in the way of doing things, to enhance our ability to produce quality graduates with necessarily limited resources;
changes in structures, to remove impediments to change and barriers that dampen innovative approaches.

Well over 200 students have taken up positions this year at the Northern Territory University, and it is anticipated that over 400 will take places next year. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in rising to participate briefly in this debate in response to the Government's Budget. It is a very important debate. I believe it is taking place in both Houses. I commence my remarks by saying that the 1987-88 Budget will be looked at for some considerable time ahead. It is the wrong Budget for Australia at this time. It is a soft options Budget from a government without the political courage to take the correct and tough decisions. If the Government does not believe my words about its failure and inability to take the tough decisions and to exercise political courage, I need only to refer it to the remarks of its own Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, made in Perth at the weekend. I will come back to that matter later on.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1987-88 Budget is also a product of deep divisions within and between the different factions of the Australian Labor Party. That is an important reason why the soft options have been adopted in this Budget rather than the tough decisions. The factionalisation that has taken place within the Labor Party in Canberra and throughout the Labor Party generally in recent times has produced great difficulty for the Government in producing responsible economic management. One of the basic reasons for that difficulty is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) now has his eyes set very firmly on the Prime Ministership. He has therefore thrown the whole concept of politics into the arena, along with economics. Any Treasurer who aspires to the position of Prime Minister, as the present Treasurer, Mr Keating, quite blatantly does, poses very difficult problems for himself and for responsible economic management in this country, because the political aspects of aspirations for the Prime Ministership will divert his attention from the necessary, often tough, economic decisions. Without any doubt at all, the nation will suffer while the Treasurer continues with his machinations to become Prime Minister of this country.

I give the Government credit for the way that it has managed to keep under control the factionalism that has been evident in the Government in recent times. But since the last election in particular, the factionalism has become increasingly evident, threatening the very unity and stability of the Hawke Government. I do not think there is any exaggeration in saying that. It is evidenced day by day in this Parliament and outside. We need only look at the dismissal, in effect, from the Ministry of Mr Barry Cohen; the remarks this week of a very senior Minister, Mr John Dawkins, about the problems that have been caused for the Government in sorting out its committee chairmanship allocations; or the comments yesterday of Mr John Gayler, the honourable member for Leichhardt in Queensland, which have also highlighted the great depths of the difficulties and divisions that the Party has.

As an earnest of the problems that that situation will cause in the future, the left wing of the parliamentary Party was reported yesterday as having decided to campaign actively against proposals for reduced company taxation, arguing that higher than expected revenue reflected in the Federal Budget should go to improving Australia's social wage. Mr Deputy President, you may remember that in the Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that there would be a review of the whole area of company taxation. It was a very surprising statement, given that only two or three weeks earlier he had said that the whole matter of tax reform had been dealt with, the measures had been put in place and no further reform was in prospect. Nevertheless, he announced in the Budget Speech that the Government would be reviewing the whole area of company tax, obviously with a view to trying to reduce the rate. Now, within a week of that announcement, the left wing of the Government has decided actively to campaign against those proposals. The factionalism also has been evident in the debate that has been taking place on the ID card. Obviously, a large number of members of the Government Party are very relieved at what has now been seen as the demise of the un-Australian ID card proposed by the Hawke Government.

The Budget in many ways is a fraud because it is misleading. The rhetoric of the Budget simply does not match its performance. The Budget demonstrates once again the Government's capacious desire to present things in a way other than the way they really are. The Government has claimed that it has balanced the Budget. It claims that it has exercised restraint over spending, that it has reduced the burden of taxation and that it has set Australia on the road to economic recovery. The Government has sold that line with great skill. I was intrigued at the way the media had became so adulatory of the Budget the following day. The headlines were absolutely stupendous for the Government in terms of public relations. One paper said `A near perfect Budget'. `Keating triumphs' was the headline all over the Melbourne Press, and so it went on. A very interesting explanation of how all that happened came in an article by Ross Gittins, the economics editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, published a few days later. I quote from his article. He said:

There is a subsidiary reason why the media and market reaction to the Budget was so approving: Mr Keating has converted the Budget lock-up from an aid to time-constrained journalists to an instrument of media management. Stage one was to exclude business economists from the lock-up-not in pique at the jaundiced commentary of the Macquarie Bank Joy Boys, but to cut journalists off from any source of independent professional analysis on Budget night. Stage two was to fill this vacuum by supplementing the usual junior Treasury advisers in the lock-up with a bevy of deputy secretaries.

These gents worked the tables assiduously-with opening gambits such as ``not much to criticise, is there?''-trying to knock down objections before they got up. The subtlety of their technique seems to have stopped it working in my case.

So says Ross Gittins, one of the few commentators who were rightly critical of the Budget. It was an enormous public relations exercise. However, it has not taken long for the gilt to fall off the Budget and for the glitter to fade. There have been several reasons, of course, for that. The most important one is that we have now had time for closer analysis. It was always on the cards that the Budget would be illusory in many ways. In the lead-up weeks to the Budget the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance all claimed that a balanced Budget was simply not on. At the end of August Mr Hawke regarded a balanced Budget as inappropriate. He was reported in the Australian newspaper of 27 August as saying that a balanced Budget was inappropriate for Australia's economic circumstances. The article also stated:
The Treasurer, Mr Keating said that the Government could not get near a balanced Budget `on our current figuring' but hoped to get close to a deficit of $1 billion . . .

The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, rejected the idea of a balanced Budget in theory and in practice. He said on 5 August, just a month or so before the Budget was introduced, that he would be satisfied with spending cuts of about $400m in the Budget, provided they involved larger quality savings in later years. He was reported as saying that he did not think a balanced budget would be the appropriate target for this year because it would involve a `major change' from one year to the next. Those statements should have alerted us to the fact that, when the Government claimed to have brought in a balanced Budget on 15 September, it was phoney-and phoney it was.

As well as the close analysis that the Opposition and others now have been able to give the Budget, we have also benefited from the very frank assessment given by the Minister for Finance in his address to the Labor lawyers in Perth last weekend. Senator Walsh made it absolutely clear that he did not agree with the adulatory descriptions of the Budget emanating not only from the media, but also from his own Prime Minister and Treasurer. Senator Walsh exposed the Budget for what it really is-that is, a soft options Budget, a complacent Budget, a very smug Budget and a Budget quite out of tune with Australia's economic situation and economic requirements. Senator Walsh said that he could think of 200 programs that are not justified on social or equity grounds, but they are programs that will not be abandoned because the Government does not have the political courage to do so.

The only extraordinary thing about Senator Walsh's speech was that he said he thought he was not being reported. If that is a reason for defending what he said it is an extraordinary way to go about things. If Senator Walsh really believes what he says-and I think that he does-the fact that his remarks were released to the Press is immaterial. What Senator Walsh said was very much what the Opposition-the Liberal and National parties-has been saying for a long time now to this Government, and that is that much greater expenditure restraint by the Government is an essential precondition for economic recovery in Australia. It is a precondition that the Government has failed to deliver in this Budget.

We have a situation in Australia today of very considerable economic concern. If we look at what those problems are we will see that they are greater than the problems that have faced our country in the last two or three decades. After five Hawke Budgets, we have a current account deficit which is well above historic levels. It is miles above in absolute terms and well above in proportional terms. We have a record foreign debt which exceeds $100 billion, a foreign debt which is climbing this year even though the Government predicts an improvement in our current account deficit. We are still going to have a deficit, according to the Government, in excess of $11 billion. That is an extraordinarily high figure. Business investment, as a share of our total gross national product, is close to its lowest level in 30 years. The inflation rate is at least double that of our trading partners. Interest rates, despite recent falls, remain at very high levels, historically for Australia and more particularly by international standards, and we have an unemployment rate that seems to be stalled permanently at a figure of something like 8 per cent or more. We have the second largest tax burden in peacetime history, exceeded by only last year's record. We have a further decline in rural output, and over the 4 1/2 years of the Hawke Government we have had an additional 700,000 people living below the poverty line in this country. That is a very sad and serious record because it portrays, particularly through the stagnation of investment, a situation where we can see no light at the end of the tunnel of our present difficulties.

The only way that we are going to improve Australia's economic performance in a sustainable, long term sense is through an improvement in our productivity. The Budget Papers themselves this year show that productivity will in fact fall. But also we will need to have a major increase in investment. The climate for investment in Australia at the moment is not conducive to increased investment. Indeed, it is quite ordinary. I would have very considerable concerns about the prospects for investment if some, or any, of the provisions in the document of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Australia Reconstructed, about which Senator Childs spoke encouragingly and positively, were implemented. We would have an enormous problem in stimulating investment. The whole thrust of that document is to make it a more difficult and rigid environment for investment. So the problems we have are very great. The Opposition has pointed to these problems time and again and has proposed, time and again, an agenda for change. I believe one of the greatest achievements of the Liberal and National parties over recent years is, indeed, to have had our clothes stolen to the extent that we have by the Government. The Liberal and National parties have set the political and economic agenda for this country. The fact is that the Government has picked much of it up and has run with it. We would prefer to be in government implementing those things ourselves. We have set the political agenda for the future and that has been seen in the areas of financial deregulation. Hopefully, we are starting to see it in some of the areas of the labour market, although we have a long way to go there.

If we are to get this country back on the rails in the period ahead we have to reduce the size of government, reduce the overall tax burdens on individuals and businesses, introduce greater flexibility and responsibility in our labour markets and lower the cost structure to industry through increased competition and reduced government regulation. Productivity and investment are the keys to our future. I urge the Government to look again at the economic strategy that it is following in this Budget because it is an economic strategy which has taken soft options, which has ignored the basic need that we have to restrain Government expenditure, to deregulate, to free up the economy so that the private sector has the incentive and the capacity to invest, to produce and to increase its productivity.

In view of the time, I will constrain my remarks. There will be other opportunities for debate on the Budget. I have made the points I wanted to make at this stage. I think there will be an ongoing debate on this Budget over the period ahead as it becomes increasingly obvious that the Government's rhetoric is not matched by its performance and that this is a Budget which has failed to deliver the climate needed. It is a Budget which has let down the Australian people at a time when the Government had a wonderful opportunity to capitalise on the present situation.

I have for some time held that Federal legislation is necessary to rid Australia of rigged boundaries at the State level. INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
A long fall from the mountain top
By martin flanagan
In the moment after the kick, as the Hawthorn players leapt exultantly into the air, all you knew was that this game would be accorded a memory unsurpassed by any other you have seen.

Sport is an event, but occasionally it is more: it is dramatic. In the moment after the kick, in a crowd that had previously been violently vocal, there was a silence and restraint of the sort induced by shock.

We who position ourselves so ardently on the edge of sport are like speculators looking to invest our emotions. It hadn't been hard to invest in Melbourne. In a world of entrenched orders and interests, they suggested values like the irrepressibility of youth. That they included Robert Flower, a player of agility and courage who has enhanced the game as few have done and still been true to its most honourable traditions, seemed the ultimate proof of their worthiness.

Not that anyone outside the club really expected them to win, but no one expected them to lose like that either. How many people nowadays travel such a journey, experience such rigors and exertions, have the desired object within their grasp when the end is officially sounded, and then have it dashed away? It wasn't just that Melbourne lost, it was that they fell from the mountain top.

Melbourne could, if it chose, take consolation from the fact that it lost to the truest opponent the game affords. As a contest, the match had been remorseless and hard; in part, a war of attrition. Hawthorn's attacks were like flight plans, meticulously organised and finely executed. Reason dictated that Melbourne could not withstand such sustained assaults, but the Melbourne challenge has had refreshingly little to do with reason.

That has been its charm, and by mid-way through the final quarter you found yourself wanting to believe in charms. Surely, Whoever or Whatever orchestrates these events would not allow a team to come so far against the odds, to gather such a huge wash of feeling in its wake, to win an ascendancy from which the prize could fairly be said to be theirs, and then deny them? But it was to be worse than that.

That the last fateful act in the drama fell to Irishman Jim Stynes, his parents having been flown to Australia for the match, seemed merely to pull away the last plank of sentiment upon which one might have found a foothold. It was Stynes, running between Gary Buckenara and Rodney Grinter, and thus incurring the 15-metre penalty, who brought Hawthorn's deadliest practitioner of the drop punt within more accessible range of goal.

In the Melbourne rooms after the match, the supporters managed a version of `It's A Grand Old Flag' which made the chamber resonate, but it didn't seem to change anything (perhaps they should have tried `You'll Never Walk Alone'). The players sat alone, white-faced, or moved listlessly to the showers.

VFL football is professional in all but name, and one realised that part of Melbourne's driving force had been the magnitude of John Northey's ambition. He would hear of no consolation and gave none to his players. It had, he said, been the chance of a lifetime.

History suggests that he is right, the last three losers of preliminary finals-Collingwood, Footscray and Fitzroy-having found little joy in subsequent seasons. The game has become too hard, both physically and mentally, too competitive and too sustained for all but the most established powers.

During the last World Cup, the French soccer captain Michel Platini reflected that he had often found more meaning in defeat than victory, but that is scarcely the Australian way. And so it is that we enter Grand Final week with the unseasonable feeling that, for so many, the main event is over.

TALK.START.PARA: —This article tells a story that will one day become legendary. That day in a faraway city of Melbourne there was for one brief shining moment a new Camelot where courage and will took place, where all that is loyal and strong was embodied in the Melbourne Football Club. I wish to say to the captain, Robbie Flower, as he prepares to hang up his boots, `You have given us better than a worthy service. You have given the club's finest example to the young generation of aspiring footballers. You have given great delight to those of us who have followed Melbourne from the time of our youth and the time we used to kick a football around the school yard'.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to say to that Irishman, Jim Stynes, that if he thinks he carries the burden of defeat he is mistaken. He does not carry any burden of guilt or defeat at all. The tragedy of last week's events does not fall upon this man Jim Stynes; rather it is a terrible fate that has fallen upon a great footballer such as Jim Stynes.

In conclusion, I wish to say that there was an event back in 1979 that also dashed the great hopes of the city of Melbourne when a horse called `Reckless' ran second in the Melbourne Cup. That was the last time I felt a feeling like that run through Melbourne when the great Tommy Woodcock, once strapper of `Phar Lap' and now deceased, trained `Reckless' that we all believed could win the Melbourne Cup. `Reckless' sadly ran second and all our hopes and dreams were dashed that day; but we got over it, we recovered. So, I say to Melbourne, `Your efforts of 1987 were cruelly dashed yet it is a grand old flag that will always fly over the Melbourne Cricket Ground. Our hopes-the hopes of the supporters-will never die and the dream will always live on.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do deplore the previous speaker's introduction of controversy into this discussion of matters of public interest today. I would like to refer to something a little more serious-the question of poverty in Australia. Earlier today I spoke of the development of human capital that is reflected in the Budget that the Government has brought down. I think this is long overdue. Unfortunately there has been a development, particularly in the Fraser years, of an increase in unemployment. I do not blame the Fraser Government only for the situation but I think it is something that is a matter of great concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, it is very interesting that in the decade concluding in 1981-82 the number of single parent families headed by women who were living in poverty increased from 38 per cent to 50 per cent. The number of families with two parents, and with three or more children, living in poverty increased from 7 per cent to 20 per cent. For families with four or more children the number living in poverty rose to 33 per cent. Of particular concern is the fact that the number of children living in poverty rose from 8 per cent to 19 per cent in the decade concluding 1981-82. An estimated 800,000 children were living in poverty in that decade concluding 1981-82. So 800,000 children have been suffering in Australia because of the lack of attention to the debilitating aspects of living and trying to study when your belly is empty.

The growing problem of family poverty is due largely to long term unemployment and increased family breakdown rates. Yet the Opposition continues to focus on the welfare situation in its criticism of government spending on welfare. The Labor Party is much more aware, I believe, of the problems of the poor and this is demonstrated in this year's Budget. Indeed, the Labor Party, as one of its basic objectives, states that the abolition of poverty and the achievement of greater equity in the distribution of income, wealth and opportunity is a primary concern. While we have been severely constrained by the difficult economic situation in which we have found ourselves in government, this Party and the Government remain committed to the progressively increasing payment rates additional to the normal indexation arrangements until single pensioners and social welfare beneficiaries receive at least 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

There are no easy solutions to the problems, of course, but the Labor Party has faced up to the task. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) should be congratulated for the family package introduced in the Budget. It goes a long way towards alleviating this very pressing contemporary social problem. The Government has been able to maintain its commitment to social justice within the Budget framework of reducing government expenditure generally.

I would like to draw attention to two aspects of the current Budget, two components of the family package; in particular, the family allowance supplement and the child support scheme. The family allowance supplement will be introduced on 17 December 1987 and will replace the family income supplement. It will be paid at the rate of $22 a week for each eligible child under 13 years of age, and $28 a week for each child between 13 and 15 years of age, after which most students go on to Austudy. If a 16- to 24-year-old does not receive Austudy or other Commonwealth pension or benefits he or she will receive current family income supplement levels of $17. The threshold is $300 for a family with one child. It will be increased by $12 a week for every additional dependent child or student in the family. Hence the threshold for a family with three children will be $324 gross a week.

The threshold income will be reviewed in the 1988-89 Budget. The threshold income, of course, is very important and the fact that it is to be reviewed means that it is part of the Government's attempt to make sure that child poverty will be eliminated in the term of this Government. Other improvements in the package include rent assistance. Many low income working families will be eligible for the $15 a week rent assistance as will many families on unemployment, sickness or special benefit without having to wait six months as they do now.

The child disability allowance is an important initiative that the Government has taken and it will be introduced from 15 November 1987 to replace the existing handicapped child's allowance. The child disability allowance makes no distinction between severely and substantially disabled children and this is a progressive step forward. The allowance will be $112 a month, an increase of $20. Of course, at the same time, the double orphans' pension has been broadened.

As to the child support scheme on 24 March 1987 the Minister for Social Security announced the introduction of new arrangements for collection of child maintenance. A child support agency is to be established next year under the Commissioner of Taxation. The agency will collect sums due under court maintenance orders using mechanisms similar to those used in collecting income tax. The payments will be distributed to custodial parents by the Department of Social Security. The scheme will apply to couples who separate after the date of the introduction of the new arrangements. In addition, custodial parents who are social security clients will be able to have their child maintenance orders collected by the agency regardless of the date of their separation. The changes are extensive and are a decided improvement on the previous schemes.

So what we have is a significant package. The Labor Government has provided $250m to meet our commitment to a family allowance supplement for low income earners. More than a million children will benefit. Up to $15 a week private rental allowance is available to low income families. These are very significant qualitative changes and improvements for those people in poverty or on the edge of poverty. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that the most any of these families would have received under the discredited election tax policy of the Liberal and National parties would have been $20 a week. I think that sums up the contrast between the Government and the Opposition, but I do not want to be controversial. I wanted to place these achievements of the Labor Government on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to take two or three minutes to put on record my objection to a proposed car race around the streets of Hobart, the city where I live and which I represent.
—A beautiful city.

—It is a beautiful city, as the Deputy Whip interjects. Late next year, it was reported last month, Hobart streets could be overwhelmed by screeching cars in an Adelaide-style touring car race around the city. It has been proposed, according to the map that accompanied this story, that it be held around the docks area of Hobart including Salamanca Place and Montpelier Retreat, a bit of Sandy Bay Road, and Davey Street and Macquarie Street would be used to pass the Town Hall and Franklin Square and go around the docks.

SPEECH.PARA: Apparently the organisers are in Hobart this week trying to finalise the arrangements and are quoted in today's Mercury as saying that there is a 90 to 95 per cent chance that the Hobart street race will go ahead next year. I have to say that I find the prospect of racing cars screeching around Hobart streets disturbing and offensive and I think there is considerable disquiet in the community about the plans for the race. There should have been much more consultation with Hobart residents and community groups. I oppose the race as a totally irresponsible event, glorifying fast cars, speed, noise pollution, and wastefulness of resources. I think it is totally inappropriate for Hobart's environment and tourist image in particular.

I think it is a bad example as well, given that the largest cause of death among males aged 17 to 25 is motor accidents. The authorities should think again before approving this race. I think one of the consequences of the Adelaide Grand Prix was a dramatic increase in the incidence of speeding in the local area, and of accidents as a consequence. I would like to know how we can expect to instil a sense of responsibility in young drivers if there is official approval for car racing in city streets. I just hope that the growing public outrage will impress upon the City Council and the organisation Sportsforce International that this proposed Constitution 500 should be abandoned or at least moved to a course designed for motor racing.
