TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity both as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and as the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. In light of the misgivings about the prospects for the Australian economy expressed not only by Senator Walsh but by such economic commentators as Mr Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald and Mr Stutchbury in the Australian Financial Review, and in light of current exchange rates and many domestic factors which are discouraging of investment in Australian manufacturing, can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Government is of the view that a 1.5 per cent across the board wage increase, which has been held out as possible for October, is justified? Will the Government be supporting a first tier across the board increase at the wage case hearing in October? If so, what level of increase?

—We have had discussions in Question Time on several occasions about various people's misgivings about the prospects of the Australian economy. I have endeavoured to answer those questions by saying that the Government is in no way complacent about the situation of the Australian economy and any views which it has and which various Ministers have are reflected in Government decisions from time to time. Insofar as the forthcoming wage case is concerned, I understand that the Government indicated its position on that to the Australian Council of Trade Unions some time ago. To my knowledge there has been no reconsideration of that position but that may well take place if the Government deems it appropriate.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Youth Affairs and Training aware of a recent newspaper report about the supposed pre-Budget threat to the community youth support scheme (CYSS)? Is it true that CYSS was under threat? Is it true, as was reported in that article, that if it were not for the actions of Senator Calvert CYSS centres would have been closed?

—Just wait and see. I was amazed at the suggestion. Did the pre-Budget rumours about the threat to CYSS originate in the Government? If not, does the Minister know where they did originate and did other States express the same level of concern as was generated in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the report in the Hobart Mercury which credits Senator Paul Calvert with leading the fight to save CYSS after pre-Budget rumours that this scheme would be discontinued. Beat-ups abound! For the information of honourable senators, the rumours about CYSS originated from a Press release by Australian Democrat Senator Janet Powell on 26 August 1987 in which she stated that she had information from a reliable source that CYSS programs would be abolished on 31 October this year. This was a totally irresponsible action by Senator Powell. I do not know who her source was but its reliability can be assessed when one sees from the Budget Papers that, far from abolishing the scheme, the funding for the next financial year was increased to $37m. At no stage was the Government contemplating abolishing the scheme in October but because the Budget process was in train it was not possible for the Minister responsible to comment on the truth or otherwise of the rumours.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it quite clear that these rumours were not started by the Government. The only action taken by Senator Calvert was to issue a quickly forgotten Press release based on Senator Powell's rumour and then send a letter to Mr Dawkins, which was received three days before the Budget was announced, asking the Minister to deny rumours sponsored by Senator Calvert and Senator Powell. He can hardly take the credit for averting a threat that did not exist. Senator Powell and Senator Calvert can take credit only for creating anxiety and worry for hundreds of CYSS workers and participants all over Australia. The Government remains committed to assisting Australia's young people to obtain employment and training and recognises the role that community based programs can play in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, relates to the Australia Card. Has the Government already identified a number of provisions in the present Australia Card Bill as requiring amendment, either for policy reasons or for technical reasons? Have drafting instructions for such amending legislation already been forwarded to the Office of Parliamentary Counsel? Is an early draft of a Bill incorporating such amendments already in the hands of the Government? Finally, if the answer to any of these questions is in the affirmative, will the Minister explain to the Senate why the Government has been proceeding with a Bill which, even by its own questionable standards, is defective and which, in a real sense, therefore constitutes a fraud upon the Parliament?

—Senator Stone is obviously very excited by pointing to a well known fact as he did yesterday that the Senate has a disallowance power with regard to regulations. Dr Blewett, the Prime Minister and I have been on the record for some time as saying that, although the Bill in its present form is satisfactory in regard to civil liberty matters, protections, banking procedures and the like, we will retain an open mind on suggestions that come forward from genuinely concerned groups in the community or members of the community about possible improvements. If we get to the stage of making decisions about those issues, they would constitute amendments for an Australia Card amendment Bill. But at this stage I repeat what we have said several times: we retain an open mind and we will consider, as we have considered, matters that are brought before us and are worthy of consideration.

—I refer my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is aware that the Governor-General of Fiji has, in recent times, dismissed the elected Government and appointed a non-elected body in its stead. In light of the Australian experience in 1975 does the Prime Minister acknowledge that there is a potential danger to constitutional stability inherent in the office of Governor-General? Does the Prime Minister support Australian people having an opportunity to express their view by referendum on the question of a republican constitution?

—The short answer to both questions is no. I do not think it has ever been the Government's view that the instability was inherent in the office of Governor-General. It may have been the view of the members of the Australian Labor Party-it was certainly mine-that the instability was there in the occupant of the position of Governor-General in 1975.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer noted that Table 22 A3 of the Treasury's draft White Paper on tax reform arguing the justice and equity case for the abolition of negative gearing which was then supported by the Hawke Government showed that in 1982-83 14 per cent of individuals with negatively geared property would have had taxable incomes of over $100,000 if negative gearing had then been disallowed, while less than 2 per cent would have had taxable incomes below the then average wage? In the light of this, will the Minister explain how the Government's decision to restore negative gearing for rental properties will assist average and low income households who are facing a shortage of affordable rental accommodation in the capital cities when real estate agents, while welcoming the decision, have agreed that it will cause property prices to increase, thus raising rents, and that the decision is unlikely to add much rental stock to the market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note for the record Senator Powell's professed concern about what she sees as tax avoidance when she, the other Democrats and all members of the Opposition protect tax evaders. That is very important as a first answer to the question. Returning to the more specific details, the White Paper was published in May 1985. At that time no capital gains tax was in place; a capital gains tax is now in place, albeit on real gains, not nominal gains. Nevertheless that goes a very long way to restoring the inequity that previously existed. In case honourable senators have forgotten this fact, the decision on negative gearing was operative from 1 July 1985 which was, of course, some 2 1/2 months before the full tax reform package was announced. It took the best part of another 12 months before it was enacted.

ANSWER.PARA: It should also be noted that simultaneously with the decision announced in the Budget on negative gearing, the depreciation allowance on buildings was reduced from 4 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent. On the more general question of the tax reform package and the progressivity of it, it is also important to note that the other measures in the tax reform package-the capital gains tax, substantiation and the fringe benefits tax-have yielded a great deal more revenue than had been anticipated. As I have said, as the White Paper demonstrated, that revenue comes overwhelmingly from people in high income brackets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I again ask the Minister whether he can explain how the decision on negative gearing will assist average and low income households who are facing a shortage of affordable rental accommodation. If he can do that, could he additionally offer any guarantees that if more rental accommodation is provided it will be low cost rental accommodation, even in spite of the fact that statistics show that it is people on low incomes living in private rental accommodation who, in the majority of cases, are pushed below the poverty line by their housing costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again note the sanctimony of the Australian Democrats in their concern for low income households. It is, however, a concern which exists only in the abstract. When it comes to actually doing something that would help low income households-that is, catching up with tax cheats-the Democrats normally use their vote in the Senate to protect the tax cheats against the interests of low income householders.

ANSWER.PARA: I will refer this matter to the Treasurer. I cannot think of any way in which the Government could guarantee that any increased investment from the private sector would be in low rental accommodation rather than medium or any other level of rental accommodation. However, I will refer that matter to the Treasurer to see whether he wishes to make any comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, relates to benefits payable to Australian veterans and other benefits such as treatment for war related injuries. Are there any comparative figures which indicate how Australian veterans are cared for compared with veterans in overseas countries?

—I thank Senator Colston for his question. I take this opportunity to point out that the Australian repatriation system is considered to be one of the most generous systems in the world. In a recent comparison, expenditure on veterans by Australia was 4.8 per cent of total government expenditure. This was considerably more than that expended by other countries, considering the United Kingdom spent only 0.4 per cent of total government expenditure, New Zealand spent 0.5 per cent, the United States of America 3.4 per cent and Canada 1.3 per cent. With the exception of Canada, none of the countries examined have a non-contributory early retirement pension equivalent to the Australian service pension. Furthermore, the Government's commitment to care for war widows, veterans and their families continues to remain one of our highest priorities. This is well demonstrated by the increase in funds available in the current Budget and since this Government came to office. I have some information available that gives comparisons in greater detail than I am prepared to give now. I am happy to provide Senator Colston with the relevant comparisons at the end of Question Time.

—I ask the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health: What preparation has taken place for the introduction of the Government's ID card and how much money has been committed and/or expended on the project?
—I will refer that question to Dr Blewett.

—I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health and it relates to housing issues. In this the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless, can the Minister explain to the Senate what, if anything, the Government has done to alleviate the current long waiting lists for public housing in New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the Senate that the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments have given a high priority to alleviating the situation for those on public housing waiting lists in that State. Total funding made available by the Federal Government for public housing assistance in New South Wales for this financial year will be over $344m. This compares with a total of $150m provided in 1982-83 and $83m in the last full year of the Fraser-Howard Government, which says something about priorities.

ANSWER.PARA: At a time of very severe budgetary restraint, the Federal Government has also been willing to guarantee a minimum of $700m in public housing assistance to the States through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA) for each of the financial years 1988-89 and 1989-90. New South Wales will, of course, receive the biggest share of these funds.

One of the key objectives of the Labor Government's 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement is to maximise the amount of funding for housing assistance by encouraging States to enter into joint ventures and innovative financing arrangements with the private sector. In New South Wales this has already achieved significant results. Recently the Federal Government formally approved the use of CSHA funds to support private sector funding of new home purchase assistance arrangements. As announced by the New South Wales Government in its Budget, this will allow 7,000 families to purchase their own homes in 1987-88. Taking the lead from the Federal Government, the New South Wales Budget for 1987-88 also provides for a $1.5 billion housing assistance package to assist over 22,500 households, including a 30 per cent increase in public housing completions, $67m allocated to the Department of Housing for land purchase and sale to home buyers and an increase of 18 per cent in funding to youth refuges.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and I remind him that the Australian Federal Police Association claimed on 2 July that the Minister had had a report into $4 billion worth of fraud against the Commonwealth for approximately six weeks. I draw the Minister's attention to his statement on 2 July that he would not release the report until after the election because of its importance. In view of the fact that it is now over two months since the election and the Government has sat on the report for over four months, what is the reason for the Government's reluctance to release such an important report and when will it be tabled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the election campaign the Australian Federal Police Association, or at least certain members of its executive, made quite extravagant and outlandish allegations and claims about the substance of a report which had been received by the Government-a review of systems for dealing with fraud on the Commonwealth-which had been carried out by a very high powered interdepartmental committee (IDC). It was not one of the ordinary IDCs but one comprising the secretaries of some 11 departments of the Commonwealth. I have never at any stage-and I do not now-concurred in or wanted to give any notional assent to the idea that that review in any way quantified the extent of fraud against the Commonwealth. It was never part of its terms of reference and was never reported on in consequence.

ANSWER.PARA: The process for dealing with this review, as I understand it, is now in the hands of the Attorney-General and will go to Cabinet very shortly, I would say within the next week or so. As soon as that is done, the Attorney-General will make the necessary report to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. I ask: When does the Government anticipate that it will receive a report from the Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd (ANOP) survey regarding the Australia Card? Will the Government make available the results of that survey?

—The ANOP survey was intended to include both qualitative and quantitative research. The qualitative research is almost concluded and the results will be made available to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I have decided that the quantitative research will not proceed until the Government considers its position. In the event of the Standing Committee deciding to explore issues not covered by the existing qualitative research, the Government would be prepared to consult with the Committee concerning future research requirements.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the continuing industrial disruption of great magnitude in the coal industry and the threat of a continuation of such disruption. I have also noted the demands of the Miners Federation and the Caucus committee that the Government should establish a national coal authority, with or without a marketing arm. I ask the Minister: Will the Government assure the Senate that it will continue to resist the demands for the establishment of a national coal authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a note here which covers some of the issues that Senator Durack has raised. Every sensible person ought to be concerned about the coal industry and, in particular, about maintaining the very substantial export revenue that it earns. I am advised that the New South Wales Government has announced concessions to reduce royalties by 20 per cent, and has removed the super-royalty from underground operations and reduced it in open-cut mines, although a number of coal companies are claiming that that is not sufficient to restore viability.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's position in this area, not just this year but going back four and a half years and two previous Ministers, has been that Australia cannot control world coal prices, and therefore we have not been willing at any stage to set up a national marketing authority that would attempt to do just that. As far as I know, that remains the view of the present Minister, but just in case he is thinking about something else I will contact him about it and let Senator Durack know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked whether the Government would resist demands for the establishment of a national coal authority with or without a marketing arm. Does the same answer apply to the establishment of a national coal authority?

—What's in a name? I suppose we could set up something called a national coal authority and give it important or unimportant, trivial functions to perform. The important question-I believe that Senator Durack would agree with this-is whether the Government is contemplating establishing, or intends to establish, some centralised marketing authority that will determine the price at which Australian coal is sold, or through which Australian coal must be sold. I repeat that that has not been the view of the Government at any time in the past four and a half years. As far as I know it remains the view of Mr Kerin, but I will check it out with him.

—My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State in her capacity as Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health on housing issues. What is the Government doing to help low income tenants facing crisis in the private rental market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very well aware of the need to assist low income tenants in the private rental market. Under the previous Liberal-National Party Government, private renters were the poor relations of home owners and public housing tenants. Our Government has responded decisively on two fronts. On the supply side, we have restored negative gearing, which will provide a much needed boost to the private sector, particularly in Sydney.
—Why did you take it away in the first place?

—Senator Walsh has already explained what the situation was in 1985. Was Senator MacGibbon not listening? The negative gearing provisions and the 2 1/2 per cent depreciation allowance, coupled with reduced interest rates, will restore investor confidence and will result in an increase in the stock of private rental accommodation. The Housing Industry Association announced yesterday that the building of medium density housing will triple over the next year. This might be of some interest to the Australian Democrats, too. It is good news for low income tenants who will benefit from an increase in the overall supply of rental accommodation and the slow-down in rent increases.

ANSWER.PARA: On the demand side, we have also taken direct action. In the Budget we introduced a $15-a-week rent assistance package for low income households in the private rental market, including recipients of the new family allowance package supplement and the unemployed. Privately renting pensioners and beneficiaries already receive this assistance. The combination of increased rental investment, the Government's continued successful downward pressure on interest rates and the provision of rental assistance to low income households is clear evidence of the Government's determination to ensure adequate and affordable accommodation for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What action will the Government take to compensate beef producers who may have inadvertently contributed to beef contamination problems by using Department of Agriculture or Department of Primary Industry (DPI) approved pesticides? Does the Minister not agree that it is not appropriate for beef producers to be forced to accept additional costs of inspection, given that there was no intended negligence on their part? Will the Government help this industry, which is so vital to Australia's export income, by meeting testing costs with a dollar-for-dollar grant?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to Senator Brownhill's reference to DPI approved insecticides or other agricultural chemicals, I thought that the registration and control of those chemicals was under the control of State governments and not of the Commonwealth Government or the Department of Primary Industries. If that is so-I will check it-I do not see how the Commonwealth Government, or any department of the Commonwealth Government, could be held responsible if there have been errors or if there has been carelessness in the past. However, I will have the matter checked out.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of compensation, I noted with some amazement about two weeks ago that Mr Winston Crane, who was at that stage the Acting President of the National Farmers Federation, asserted at a meeting in Manjimup in Western Australia that the Commonwealth Government should provide $200m to buy all the beef that may have been contaminated. He said that that would be a small price to pay for an industry worth $1 1/2 billion a year, implicitly assuming in doing so that without that sort of cash injection the industry would collapse. I do not know on what basis he made that assumption. More importantly, when I heard this I thought, `Surely this cannot be the same Winston Crane or the same National Farmers Federation which was writing letters to me in June and, I think, to most candidates in the election demanding that Government expenditure be ruthlessly slashed'. I thought, `Surely this is not the same Winston Crane, or the same National Farmers Federation, who is now demanding $200m of taxpayers' money ostensibly to save an industry without offering any evidence at all that such a cash transfusion is necessary to save that industry'.

I did write a letter to the West Australian questioning whether this was the same Winston Crane and the same National Farmers Federation. But the West Australian, consistent with its perceived obligations to inform the public of Western Australia, declined to publish it. So I hope it will report the answer to this question. The Government has, of course, acted-and this was announced some time ago-and put a modest amount of taxpayers' money into a co-operative scheme with the States to retrieve the stocks of these chemicals that are still lying around on farms.

I will see whether Mr Kerin has anything to add to that answer. I stress again that to the best of my knowledge, if there have been any mistakes or carelessness about the chemicals which are allowed to be marketed or used on farms, that is the responsibility of the State governments although I believe that the Commonwealth Government has for some time exercised some discipline over the chemicals which may be imported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Minister for Home Affairs, relates to election costs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to statements made by Senator Brian Archer at the Senate declaration in Tasmania concerning the cost of Federal elections? Are the costings, as claimed, accurate and are other claims made by Senator Archer justified? In view of the continuing high House of Representatives informal votes in some parts of Australia, will the Minister examine the cost effectiveness of television advertisements using languages other than English to explain better voting procedures and so reduce the number of informal votes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read a Press release by Senator Archer at the declaration of the poll at Hobart. I must say initially that I never give a lot of credence to anything that is said at a declaration of the poll. On such occasions politicians tend to have a bit of a break-out and say whatever they feel like. On this occasion Senator Archer was, as part of his responsibilities as a front bench member of the Opposition, spokesman on electoral matters. I always got the feeling that whilst he was very much across the issues of primary industry and science, electoral matters were probably third in priority.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Archer in his Press release said that the average cost per vote in the last election was $20. It is very hard to understand how he would have calculated that. If we take it on the cost of running the election, it would be no more than $4 per vote. Possibly Senator Archer amalgamated every possible item, going back to the previous election, that the Australian Electoral Commission would have costed. But even on that basis the cost would have been only $14 a vote. We also have to remember that the Electoral Commission runs 150 to 200 industrial ballots a year. It is also into many other areas of electoral education for schools and other bodies. It is possible, of course, that Senator Archer just rounded off his figures and went from $14 to $20 for the sake of convenience. That is not an impossible mistake to make.

Senator Archer also went on to say that the informal vote jumped very substantially in the last election. Indeed, he said that in the Senate the informal vote rose by 8 per cent and in the House of Representatives by 135 per cent. We should note that his claims relate to the period 1984 to 1987. In actual fact, the Senate informal vote was 4.06, which is down from 4.68 per cent at the previous election. We should remember, of course, that this time we had a double dissolution which meant that more candidates were involved. So once again the Senate informal vote has dropped. There has been a decrease-in my view not a satisfactory decrease-in the informal vote for the House of Representatives. I do not think the decrease is large enough. However, it is down to 4.92 per cent compared with 6.38 per cent. I am sure that Senator Tate is most impressed by that decrease.

Senator Archer went on to say that on this occasion the counting was slower and more expensive and that we should thoroughly investigate bringing in the Hare-Clark system. I point out that the results for the Senate this time were known much sooner than they have been in the past, especially bearing in mind that we had a double dissolution. We were able not only to carry out a complete Senate count but also to invoke section 282 in a half Senate count before this chamber assembled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then throw it out.

—And throw it out here later on. That again indicates how quick the Electoral Commission was. Senator Archer went on to make some remarks about redistribution and how unfair the electoral system is. I have answered that in reply to a previous question. The tragedy apparently for those opposite is that they got a swing in our safe seats and there was a slight swing to us in the marginals. That is what the whole election was about. The result had nothing to do with the redistribution at all.

ANSWER.PARA: In the final part of his question Senator Maguire asked whether we would consider redirecting some of the election resources towards non-English advertisements. I think that is a good suggestion. However, I would like first of all to see the analysis on informal voting that is being undertaken by the Electoral Commission and which will be available in the next couple of months. If that analysis shows that there is some correlation with a high non-English speaking population, I think we should give serious consideration to redirecting some of the electoral expenditure into that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Justice, follows answers he gave to Senator Jones earlier this week in which he acknowledged the role of the corrupt former Queensland police Assistant Commissioner Parker as the liaison officer for Queensland with the National Crime Authority (NCA). I ask: Who determined that Mr Parker would be the liaison officer for the Queensland police? Does the NCA simply accept the nominee of the State or does it carry out its own investigations as to who would be suitable or unsuitable? If it does not, will that practice be changed? Through `operations conferences', would Mr Parker have learned from the NCA the names of Queenslanders who might be NCA informers or prospective witnesses? If such is the case and the NCA has provided such information to Mr Parker, will the Commonwealth advise the witnesses accordingly and apply whatever resources are necessary to guarantee the physical security of such witnesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first part of the question asked by Senator Hill-and I acknowledge the gravity of the matters that he has raised-as I recall it, the first appointed liaison officer between the National Crime Authority and the Queensland police force, undertaken at the direction of the then Minister for Police, was the predecessor to Assistant Commissioner Parker. I cannot recall his name. He was to take control of liaison, not only with the NCA but also with the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. The Queensland Minister for Police determined that one person within the police force should be the exclusive conduit for the flow of information and arrangements between the Federal law enforcement authorities and the Queensland police force. So the original appointment of a liaison officer from within the Queensland police force was made at the instigation of the then responsible Minister within the Queensland Cabinet.

ANSWER.PARA: Upon the departure-perhaps it was retirement, I am not too sure-of the occupant in I think, early 1986, Mr Parker was appointed to that role. I do not know whether it was by direct intervention of the then Minister for Police or whether he was just filling what was then a vacant liaison officer role. I would assume, and have assumed, that Commissioner Sir Terence Lewis made that appointment to fill the role of liaison officer.

Whilst the NCA obviously takes very meticulous steps to screen those officers who are seconded to it, whether from the Australian Federal Police or from State or Territory police forces, it does not undertake the same scrutiny of liaison officers, such as the liaison officer who is appointed by the Queensland Minister or Police Commissioner. That led to my suggestion, which was I think incorporated in a Four Corners program on these matters earlier in the week, that more tick-tacking and more mutual collaboration needed to take place between the National Crime Authority and the respective State or Territory police force before a liaison officer was appointed. That collaboration and mutual agreement as to a person I hope will emerge from discussions at the Police Ministers Council meeting in Hobart in late November. I have already written to Mr Pearsall, the Chairman of the Australian Police Ministers Council, requesting him to get such a process under way.

In relation to the second part of Senator Hill's question, I have already indicated to the Senate that Mr Parker was present at three operational conferences, in July and September of 1986 and May or March of this year, and that, keeping at arm's length as I do from operational matters, I certainly have not been made privy, and have not sought to be made privy, to the discussions that were there undertaken. Nevertheless, in general discussion with Mr Justice Stewart, the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, I have asked him to take whatever steps are required to make an assessment of any compromise of National Crime Authority operations that may have been occasioned by the access which Mr Parker had to information disclosed at those conferences. That would incorporate any suggestion that witnesses may be imperilled by the passage of such information.

In respect of witness protection, the National Crime Authority, as is to be seen in the reports tabled in this Parliament, has taken a particularly vigorous view that the protection of witnesses is an absolutely key element in its obtaining of intelligence. The protection of witnesses is something which I know Mr Justice Stewart is very conscious needs to be undertaken in any situation where there is a hint of their being in jeopardy or in peril. Nevertheless, I will specifically ask Mr Justice Stewart whether in this particular instance he feels able to inform me-and he may not-whether any particular witnesses may have been put in jeopardy and, if so, what steps have been taken, or at least what assurances he can give me in relation to any such jeopardising of witnesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Given that yesterday was the deadline for regional television licensees to tell the Government whether they wished to move to aggregated services, can the Minister inform the Senate of the outcome?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure, as I know it would my learned predecessor, Michael Duffy, to be able to inform the Senate that I have now received indications from the majority of regional television licensees in all four approved markets, covering Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria, that they wish to move to aggregated services. This means in essence that more than four million Australians living in eastern mainland regions are now a very important step closer to gaining access to television programming which is comparable to that already enjoyed by viewers in the capital cities.

ANSWER.PARA: The equalisation process will give most country viewers the choice of three commercial channels as well as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) while retaining local programs such as news, sport, weather and community announcements. It is envisaged that a viewer in Cairns, for example, whose viewing choice is currently limited to the ABC and just one local station, will, after this aggregation, be able to tune into any of three local services, each of which will be offering basically the network programming of one of the three major channels-channels 7, 9 and 10. This situation will obviously represent a very significant expansion of programming choice, with a wealth of previously unavailable sporting, drama and current affairs programs becoming available to viewers.

Yesterday was the deadline by which regional licensees were to inform the Government whether they preferred to opt for aggregation or instead to move as an interim measure to multi-channel services. Licensees in the southern New South Wales approved market unanimously elected to move to aggregation. In each of the other three approved markets of northern New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria there was only one licensee in each case who preferred the multi-channel service approach. I am today in the process of advising all licensees of this outcome. Aggregation has always been the Government's preferred option for equalisation, and on behalf of the Government I commend the licensees for their overwhelming endorsement of this approach.

Under the Government's aggregation timetable it is anticipated that the necessary broadcasting infrastructure will be in place to enable approved market C, covering southern New South Wales, to begin equalisation by 1989, followed by approved market A, Queensland, by 1990; approved market B, northern New South Wales, by 1991; and approved market D, Victoria by 1992. Of course, it is open to licensees jointly to begin aggregated services earlier than those timetabled dates, should they so choose.

Perhaps I should say a final word about the situation in the other States. The smaller regional populations in Western Australia and South Australia mean that it is simply not possible to move immediately to three competitive services in those States. However, I can assure regional viewers in Western Australia and South Australia that the Government will shortly be taking up with the relevant licensees proposals for the provision of additional commercial services in those States. Because of the smaller regional populations in those States, aggregation there would need to be on a basis that included Perth and Adelaide to ensure an adequate population base. Finally, the situation in Tasmania, where there is an existing monopoly, is also being addressed and I am hopeful that a second independent commercial service will be available within the next two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce whether he is aware that the proposal by Worksafe Australia to impose limits on manual lifting above 16 kilograms has been estimated to cost the Australian construction industry $1.2 billion every year and that submissions from other industries point to cost increases as large or even larger. Can the Minister give the Senate an assurance that, at a time when an increase in national productivity is absolutely crucial, the Government will not accept any recommendation which imposes an arbitrary and inflexible restriction on lifting and which will as a consequence reduce workplace efficiency and productivity?
—Yes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Can he provide the Senate with information on the arrests and large illicit drug seizure made in the last two days by the Australian Federal Police (AFP)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Federal Police has for some time been investigating an international organisation which it is alleged has been responsible for the importation of illicit drugs into Australia. The syndicate allegedly consists of both United States and Australian citizens. Honourable senators may be aware of Press reports over the last 24 hours indicating that, following extensive covert inquiries, a number of search warrants were executed by the Federal Police in Queensland and New South Wales. Approximately 160 kilograms of hashish were found on a Nerang property and over $400,000 in cash was seized. Ten people, both US and Australian citizens, have been arrested on charges relating to the importation of illicit drugs, and further arrests may be expected.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the general public over the last year or so has become increasingly aware of the very important role played by the Australian Federal Police, as the Federal Government's premier law enforcement agency, in tackling the question of organised crime and drug trafficking. When this Government came to office it gave to the Australian Federal Police a charter which made it clear that its priority objectives were to tackle organised crime, particularly in relation to drug trafficking. I believe that these sorts of arrests and charges and the subsequent convictions, of which the general public is becoming aware, as a result of these AFP operations are a tribute to the way in which that organisation has responded to the charter of objectives given to it by the Government, along with the devotion of considerable resources from the Government to the Australian Federal Police including, since we came to power, an increase of over 600 in the personnel operating within it. That is an increase of some 25 per cent in the personnel available to the Commissioner in his directing of Federal Police resources in the fight against organised crime. It is also the case that in this instance civil remedies action is being currently taken against the syndicate's assets, which include real estate, boats, motor vehicles, safe deposit boxes and bank accounts. These assets are estimated to be valued at several million dollars.

I say from my experience during the election campaign that if there is one thing the general public appreciates above all others in the package of legislation passed through this Parliament, with co-operation from the other side, in the last weeks of the autumn session, it was the proceeds of crime legislation. In general it is thought throughout the community that upon conviction-I am not saying whether these persons who have been arrested and charged will be convicted; that is a matter for the courts to decide-of a drug trafficker the general community feels, and this Parliament has agreed, that it is not adequate that the person suffer a gaol sentence of even four, five, 10 or 15 years if at the end of that process they can come out of gaol and enjoy the fruits of their nefarious activities. As far as this Government has been concerned, it is important that the profit motive, which often is the motive behind engaging in these activities which lead to death, destruction and degradation, particularly of our young people, is attacked by stripping convicted criminals of their proceeds of crime. That will be undertaken vigorously by government agencies.

This operation is a tribute to the Australian Federal Police not only in its technique of targeting principal crime figures, but also in demonstrating the high degree of liaison and co-operation between law enforcement agencies which characterised this operation. Both the Australian Customs Service and the Director of Public Prosecutions have been closely involved in the operations. At the international level the Australian Federal Police liaison officers facilitated very good and effective contact with law enforcement agencies overseas, all of whose co-operation was essential to the success of this operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. Was the Government aware before yesterday of the defect in its Australia Card Bill so far as the introduction of regulations was concerned? If so, when did it first become aware of the defect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it rather astounding that Senator Short and other members of the Opposition try to characterise one aspect of the drafting of the Australia Card Bill as a defect. What they are saying is that it is a defect to write into a Bill that there may be regulatory powers. It is an absurd claim given the list of legislation an arm long that has similar provisions. Will they turn to every piece of Commonwealth legislation since 1901 that depends for its operation on regulatory power and say `that it is all defective' and that they want it all withdrawn? It is an absurdity. How can honourable senators opposite, who like to uphold the powers of the Senate, say that it is defective to put into a Bill a regulatory power?

ANSWER.PARA: I have not counted the number, but I know that since 1901 there have been dozens of pieces of legislation and indeed in my 12 years in the Senate many pieces of legislation have been introduced, where the principal Act was contained in legislation and other details were to be determined at a later date by regulation. It is a fact of life that regulations go before the Senate which has the power of disallowance. All legislation before the Senate goes to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and that Committee did not find any defect in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is untrue.

—On this particular point. That Committee did not regard the perfectly conventional and normal fact that there were regulations for setting the date of various matters within the Bill as a defect. What is Senator Short saying about his colleagues on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee? If he regards it as a defect, why did his Senate colleagues not regard it as a defect? It is absurd. One cannot have an honourable senator rising in this place and saying that it is defective drafting to have a principal Act setting out the main parts of the legislation and then having the minor parts, such as the setting of dates, a matter of regulation. It happens time and again in legislation and has happened on numerous occasions with major pieces of legislation since 1901.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me return to Senator Short's question. We were alerted to one fact yesterday for the first time. That fact was that it was the intention of Opposition and Democrat senators to fly in the face of 87 years of Senate practice, to fly in the face of section 57 of the Constitution which sets out precisely and for good reason mechanisms by which a Bill that has stalled between two Houses may come to resolution. For the first time we heard yesterday that it was the intention of the Opposition senators and Democrat senators to throw out 87 years of convention and practice in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Menzies would turn in his grave.

—Absolutely; Menzies would turn in his grave. It never happened in his time. They intend to overturn a principal Act by the use of a Senate regulation power. That was what we learned for the first time yesterday, and that is what rightly has caused me and my colleagues to characterise honourable senators opposite and the Democrats as constitutional vandals.

—I put a supplementary question to the Minister. In view of the Minister's non-response to my question, I again ask her-and if she does not like the word `defective', I will change it: when was the Government first aware that its Bill was vulnerable in respect of its regulatory powers?

—The same answer goes to Senator Short. It is not a supplementary question, even though he has sensibly withdrawn the word `defective'. The vulnerability of the Government does not arise from using the practice of 87 years. The Government's vulnerability arises from the threat of the constitutional vandals opposite to destroy a principal Act by the use of a regulatory power.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FORMER SENIOR QUEENSLAND POLICE OFFICER: EXTRADITION

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Justice been drawn to media reports that suggest that the Queensland Government is moving to approach authorities in the United Kingdom to extradite Mr Jack Herbert, a former senior Queensland police officer, now believed to be living in the United Kingdom? Is this the same Mr Herbert that the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Brisbane would like to give evidence before it? Has the Queensland Government made any approach to the Federal Government for assistance in this process? Does the Queensland Government have power or authority to undertake such an extradition appeal process in its own right, or does the Queensland Government require the help of the Commonwealth to make the process effective?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report in the Age of 23 September 1987 which suggests that the Queensland Government may approach the Government of the United Kingdom seeking the extradition of Mr Jack Herbert, a former senior Queensland police officer now believed to be living in the United Kingdom. I do not think that I should answer the question in any particular way, but I inform the Senate that the extradition process is available only to secure the return of persons charged or convicted of extradictable offences, and the process is not available to secure the return of persons who are wanted only as witnesses. For example, if the request was for the return of Mr Herbert to appear as a witness before the Fitzgerald inquiry, on that basis extradition processes would not be in order.

ANSWER.PARA: To date, the Queensland Government has not made any approach to the Attorney-General or his Department seeking assistance in securing the extradition of Mr Herbert. Neither the Queensland Government nor any other State or Territory government has the power or authority to invoke the extradition processes in its own right. Extradition arrangements are entered into on either a bilateral or multilateral basis by sovereign nations. In recognition of this Australian extradition legislation designates the Federal Attorney-General as the person who may make a formal request of another nation for the surrender of a person wanted for trial or to undergo punishment in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to his description, in what has been reported as a rambling speech-or was it tired and emotional?-to last weekend's Labor Lawyers conference, of the new Parliament House as `another scandal'. I ask the Minister whether, in using the word `scandal', he was referring to the scandalous absence of effective cost control of the project under his Government, revealed by the Waste Watch Committee and confirmed by the recent Auditor-General's report on the project's construction phase, all of which took place under the Hawke Government? Or was he referring to the huge cost imposed by his Government on the project by enormous design changes and political interference since March 1983, recognising that $934m, or 93 per cent, of this $1 billion project has been or is being spent under the Hawke Government? What does the Minister intend to do about what he has described as a `scandal', particularly as $300m is still to be spent this financial year on the new Parliament House?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At about half past ten this morning, when I was having a haircut, I heard the Senate bells ringing. I needed to know whether they were ringing for a quorum or a division. I therefore asked the hairdresser to turn up the speaker, and I heard a rambling speech coming from Senator Michael Baume. I did not really mind the fact that it was a rambling speech, but I take this opportunity to say that I did object-the Standing Orders prevent my using the most appropriate word-to the highly misleading assertions that Senator Baume was making when he said that I had in fact endorsed the Opposition's election policy. Apart from the fact that I would be reluctant to endorse anything that had a $2.5 billion or $1.5 billion arithmetical error--
—Or a Patrick Partner involved.

—An error of that magnitude would be nothing compared to a Patrick Partners prospectus. I certainly would not endorse any proposition or document that had errors in it if I knew about them, and I think I would have been careful enough to make certain that it did not contain errors of that magnitude. Leaving aside the Opposition's inability to do simple arithmetic, nor, of course, would I have endorsed-and I have said this on the public record on many occasions-what the Opposition essentially proposed, which was that the country could go on a consumption binge via unaffordable tax cuts. That was the big con line which Senator Baume, in his days on the front bench prior to his relegation, and the rest of the Opposition, in particular, the Leader of the Opposition, tried to put over the Australian electorate. The Opposition believed that the people should ignore the difficult external circumstances imposed upon us and that the country could go on a consumption binge via these huge tax cuts and the $2 1/2 billion worth of blue sky on the expenditure cuts.

ANSWER.PARA: It may have been better, on reflection, to say that the cost of construction of the new Parliament House was extravagant, rather than a scandal, but I suppose that is a matter of opinion. However, it is a matter of fact that the fast track construction method-the term could be simplified or perhaps slightly over-simplified by describing the method by which the concrete is poured at the same time as the engineering plans are being drawn-was a decision made by the Fraser Government, as indeed was the management system, which again I think was somewhat defective.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Patterson asked me a question without notice concerning the loss of Department of Social Security microfiche records in Melbourne earlier this year. It is true that in April Department of Social Security records were found in a suburb of Melbourne. It is also a fact that the Department of Social Security sent an officer to the scene and that this officer found additional microfiche records. An inquiry to ascertain how the loss of the records occurred was carried out immediately. The inquiry found that the loss of the microfiche records occurred due to an error on the part of the contractor responsible for their destruction. Some microfiche collected by the firm became mixed with non-security waste and were lost in transit for disposal.

ANSWER.PARA: New arrangements with the firm have been made to ensure that such an incident does not recur. The contractor undertook to store the material in the firm's security vault prior to sending it by sealed container for supervised destruction. The Department is also investigating the options for alternative collection and destruction, expected to be offered shortly by the Department of Administrative Services. Further, the Department is well advanced with implementation of a new automatic data processing (ADP) system-Stratplan-which provides far greater security of client information. Most offices in Australia are now equipped with the new ADP system and most remaining offices should have this facility by the end of this financial year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: KANGAROO PRODUCTS: EUROPEAN COMMUNITY AND UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Puplick sought the Government's reaction to the adoption by the European Parliament of the Muntingh proposals regarding the import of kangaroo products into Europe, and asked what steps the Government would take to procure the defeat of the Mrazek proposal for the prohibition of kangaroo imports to the United States of America. Senator Puplick will be aware that Mr Muntingh visited Australia in 1986 at the invitation of the Australian Government and during that time he met with representatives of Government and non-government bodies having an interest in kangaroo management. As a result of that visit Mr Muntingh was able to understand better the complexity of the situation and to appreciate the improvements made in kangaroo management as a result of Commonwealth initiatives in recent years. The European Community is a major importer of wildlife, including products derived from kangaroos, and sees itself as having a responsibility to ensure that imports of wildlife are not detrimental to the survival of the species in their native lands.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Muntingh has sought to provide protection for kangaroos by utilising existing European Community regulations developed to implement the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. If implemented, the Muntingh resolution, as adopted by the European Parliament, would effectively ban the import of products of 45 species of kangaroos, but not of the red and the eastern and western grey kangaroos which constitute the bulk-over 90 per cent-of the trade. For these three species import permits would be required. The Commonwealth Government is pleased that Mr Muntingh and the European Parliament now recognise that the Australian Government has taken effective measures for the management of kangaroos and that the main species commercially harvested are not endangered, contrary to the claims made by some groups.

Whilst the Australian Government welcomes the intent of the European Parliament to better regulate the importation of kangaroo products, and sees this as complementing Australian export procedures and statistics, there is concern about the proposed use of regulations specifically dealing with endangered species since the species commercially harvested in Australia are not endangered. The Australian Government is also concerned that the import of products of commercially harvested species, such as the euro and whiptail wallabies, will be prohibited even though abundant and under no threat.

If the resolution of the European Parliament is to come into effect, it needs the support of the Council of the European Community, the European Commission and the governments of the member states. In responding to the Muntingh resolution Commissioner Clinton Davis is reported as indicating the Australian kangaroo management programs are considered adequate and the Commission was not proposing to follow that part of the resolution calling for the listing of kangaroos in European regulations implementing the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. I hope that the Commission and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service will work closely together to develop complementary arrangements with regard to trade in kangaroo products.

The kangaroo issue has generated a considerable amount of interest in the USA as well and a Bill introduced by Congressman Mrazek with 116 co-sponsors-this is the third time I have seen the brief; the number was 110 eight weeks ago, 112 three weeks ago, and it is now 116, so there is work to be done. That Bill is pending consideration in the Fisheries, Wildlife Conservation and Environment Sub-committee of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee. I understand it is unlikely that any action on kangaroos will be taken by the Sub-committee this year. The Mrazek Bill goes much further than the European resolution in that if adopted, there would be a complete ban on the importation of kangaroo products into the USA.

The Senate may be aware that my predecessor, the Hon. Barry Cohen, met with Congressman Mrazek earlier this year and invited him to visit Australia to see the kangaroo situation at first hand. I understand his Press Secretary is planning to visit Australia later this year and the opportunity will be taken to brief him. Considerable background information has been provided already to Congressman Mrazek, the US Fish and Wildlife Service and the Library of Congress and others. It is planned to direct further information to members of the appropriate sub-committee and committee. If a hearing is scheduled for the legislation, a detailed submission would be prepared and it may prove desirable to send a team of experts to the US to deal with it.

Curtailment of the industry through a ban on imports to Europe and the USA could result in less humane killing of kangaroo and less control over the number of kangaroos killed since non-commercial killing would increase. No practical alternatives to the current system of commercial harvesting are available.

DEBATE.TITLE: VIETNAM VETERANS: NATIONAL WELCOME HOME PARADE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Reynolds)-by leave-proposed:
That the Senate-
(a) recognises the importance of the National Welcome Home Parade of Vietnam Veterans in Sydney on 3 October 1987;
(b) notes that the Australian Armed Forces served with great distinction in Vietnam between 1962 and 1972, earning great credit for themselves and for this nation;
(c) pays tribute to all Australian men and women who served in that theatre of war and honours the memory of those Australians who died in Vietnam in the service of their country; and

(d) expresses its appreciation and the appreciation of the Australian people for the individual and collective commitment, effort and sacrifice of its sailors, soldiers and airmen, men and women alike, who took part in the Vietnam conflict.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I merely wish to signify the very great satisfaction of the Opposition that the Government has brought this motion forward. It was a matter that was promoted with the Government by the Opposition because we believe that, as the organisation of the Welcome Home Parade itself indicates, there is a need for a public acknowledgment of the personal sacrifice made by so many Australians during the Vietnam war.
