Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate maintains and asserts its right and duty to disallow regulations which are against Australia's interest and censures the Government for
(a) its attack on the Senate's determination to exercise its Constitutional responsibilities;
(b) proposing to force through a Joint Sitting legislation which it has admitted needs amendment; and

(c) wasting taxpayers' money by persisting with legislation which would abuse personal privacy beyond limits acceptable to the principle of democracy and individual rights sacred to the Australian community.
I am determined to bring forward this censure motion because of the attitude which has been evident--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, as a matter of courtesy, I wonder whether we could be provided with the terms of the motion.
—Copies of the motion are currently being circulated by the attendants. The honourable senator will have a copy in about 10 seconds.

—My desire to bring forward this motion was considerably increased by the effort of Senator Ryan during Question Time to repeat the sort of nonsense which has been expressed in the other place today that in some way what happened in the Senate yesterday threw out some 87 years of convention and that there was some extraordinary principle which prevented us from moving disallowance of regulations which might have the effect of defeating the operation of a Bill. I bring forward that argument because I believe that it has no substance at all. It is simply being brought forward by the Government in an attempt to intimidate the Senate and to confuse a public debate in the normal way in which the Government deals with these debates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has attempted to occupy the high moral ground on this issue. I simply wish to remind the Senate that it is the Opposition which has occupied the high moral ground along with those other opponents of the Australia Card Bill. When we set out to oppose the identity card legislation a year ago we did so knowing that at the time 70 per cent of the Australian people had been convinced by the Government that the Australia Card, the identity card, would be a good thing. It took a great deal of political courage to take the principled decision that the Bill should be opposed. We continued to oppose the Bill. We defeated it twice in the Senate and we will defeat it a third time if it comes back for a second reading here.

The fact of the matter is that the Government will be unable to produce any evidence that there is a practice of 87 years, that in some way we should be constrained in the use of our constitutional power, our legal power, to disallow regulations which are made under an Act. We reject this pathetic attempt at moral and constitutional outrage which we have seen expressions of last night, this morning and this afternoon in both the House of Representatives and in the Senate. We reject those pathetic attempts at moral and constitutional outrage, and we express very firmly our view that as senators we will do our duty by Australia and we will cast our votes in a way which we believe is in the national interest.

The proposition that the Government is putting forward and attempting to force upon the Senate is that a Bill, which has been defeated by this Senate twice and which may well be defeated on a third occasion, containing a regulation making power should have its regulations protected by some mysterious constitutional convention. It seems to me to be an absurd proposition when we consider the normal circumstances in which this Senate, often on the motion of Senator Ryan herself, has disallowed regulations and ordinances. We as a Senate have always exercised our power to disallow regulations even in cases where we as a Senate have supported the principal legislation.

The practice of this Senate is quite clear. We have the clear legal right, and practice shows that we have exercised that right, to disallow regulations which are made even under a Bill which we as a Senate have supported. And now the Government is trying to advance the proposition that where there is a Bill which the Senate has never supported we are in some way obliged to support the regulations. That is, on the face of it, absurd. When we consider the rationale for giving the Senate and the House of Representatives power to disallow regulations, the absurdity of the Government's argument becomes apparent.

We worry a lot about different issues in this Parliament. We worry about privacy, freedom of information and many of the issues which have become current in the last decade. But in the 1920s, the possibility of the oppression of the people through delegated legislation was a matter of enormous political moment. We found academics and politicians in the 1920s asserting the need for parliament to retain the control of delegated legislation. It is the new despotism-that is what it was called back in the 1920s-that Ministers could make laws without parliamentary control. So the principle is enshrined in our legislation that when Ministers make laws through regulations, either House of parliament must have the power to disallow them, unless the Parliament itself expressly provides otherwise. We are protecting the fact that the parliament-the whole of the parliament; the two Houses of Parliament-is required to act if laws are to be made which infringe the rights of the Australian people. The Government is asserting that in this Senate, because of the double dissolution and the prospect of a joint sitting, in some mysterious way by a convention that has never been spoken of before and cannot be demonstrated by precedent, our right to protect the rights and privileges of the people of Australia has been removed. That is why this motion is important. It is an assertion not merely of our desire to censure the Government for its approach and for its failure in this area, but of our desire to reassert our right as a Senate to carry out our constitutional and legal duty. The high moral ground on this matter is occupied by the Opposition; it is not occupied by the Government.

If the Government wished to achieve a different result, it had a perfectly simple mechanism available to it. It was open to the Government to bring the legislation into this chamber on the basis that the requirements of the law, the Acts Interpretation Act that gives us the power to disallow regulations, should not apply to this legislation. That is a provision which could have been included in this Bill. It was not included.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they were competent.

—There are two possibilities. Senator Michael Baume, the nimble-footed senator from New South Wales, has got in ahead of me with one of the possibilities-simple incompetence. It is very likely that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and his advisers simply were incompetent. But let us give them the benefit of the doubt. Perhaps they were noble and principled.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not like to ascribe good motives to the Government but perhaps it was not minded to remove from this Parliament the right that we have to scrutinise delegated legislation. Indeed, there is some evidence that the Government acknowledged that right. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills reported to the Government that there were breaches of the rights and freedoms of individuals inherent in this legislation. What did Minister Blewett do? He did not deny the rights of the Senate. He wrote back and said that he would introduce amendments to this legislation. Minister Blewett said that he would introduce amendments to the legislation that would extend the power of the Senate to scrutinise the legislation. Honourable senators should note the variation in the approach adopted by the Government when the Scrutiny of Bills Committee reported on the defects. At that time, in April 1987 Minister Blewett was offering to extend the power of the Senate to scrutinise this legislation. Now the Government tells us we have no power to scrutinise this delegated legislation. But in any event the position is that the Government has put up a totally fictitious argument. The Opposition is censuring the Government for its attack on the Senate's determination to exercise its constitutional responsibilities. We will not be a party to the argument; we will not accept the argument that in some mysterious way the powers of the Senate and the responsibilities of the Senate have been diminished by what has occurred with respect to this Bill.

We have had an accusation from the Government that we in the Opposition have been hypocritical in our approach to this legislation. That allegation was repeated in the House of Representatives this morning by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I again reject that allegation and draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that we chose to deal with this legislation in an utterly principled way. When the Government floated the idea of an identity card, before it produced the specific proposal, the Opposition did not declare its final position on any legislative proposal. What we said-this is a matter that has been repeated over and over again-was that we would examine any proposal that the Government put forward on the basis of a series of tests that needed to be applied. We said that any proposition would need to be effective in combating welfare fraud; that it should help to control illegal immigration; that it should facilitate the collection of taxes due for payment and that the system proposed should be cost effective. Finally and most importantly, we said that we would test it against the proposition that there should be adequate safeguards for personal privacy and civil liberties.

Again, there was no knee-jerk reaction from the Opposition on this. We sent the matter to a parliamentary committee, composed of representatives of all parties in this Parliament-the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Democrats. All of those parties were represented. I wish that the result of their work could be read by every person in Australia because the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card produced a quite straightforward recommendation. I will quote from this report because it preceded any final determination by the Opposition of its position with respect to any particular proposition of this Government. Members of all parties joined in the Committee's recommendation. I think the honourable senator opposite who was interjecting was one of the minority who did not join in but Labor, Liberal, National and Democrat members all joined in saying the following:

Having considered the Government's proposal for a national identification system as well as alternatives such as the use of photographic cards and the extension of the use of the current tax file system, the majority of the Committee rejects all proposals for the issuing of identity cards, with or without a photograph.

This debate is not the time to canvass all the arguments which have been canvassed extensively in this debate and which are canvassed so superbly in this document. Again, I wish that every person in Australia who is not able to read the whole of the report would read the 40 to 50 pages penned by Senator Chris Puplick on the fundamental objections that he found after examining those hundreds of bits of evidence that were put before the Senate Committee. Time does not permit that. But, happily, those key arguments are getting through to the Australian people. The 70 per cent support for this proposition, which we faced as an Opposition when we determined to oppose this legislation, has withered away now to less than 40 per cent. A clear majority of Australians are outraged by what this Government is trying to foist upon them.

Yesterday in my city of Perth between 20,000 and 40,000 people-estimates vary-walked from the city to Parliament House. The beginning of that march arrived at Parliament House before the end of it had left Barrack Street. That does not mean a great deal to some honourable senators who are unfortunate enough not to live in Western Australia. But that was a massive demonstration of public concern. Our opposition to this card merely reflects the public concern which crosses party boundaries and which reflects the threat to Australia which this identity card legislation represents.

The hypocrisy and abuse of the Constitution in this matter is the hypocrisy and abuse shown by the Government. I wish to make it quite clear why I regard with contempt the approach that the Government has adopted to this legislation. It is trying to use the constitutional provisions for a joint sitting to bring about a constitutional fraud. After the passage of this Bill-as I have already reminded the Senate-the Minister, in response to this chamber, wrote and said that the legislation required amendment. Minister Blewett, not only in response to the Senate, announced that there would be changes to the Australia Card Bill. But on 5 February he issued a Press release from Canberra saying that `the Federal Government has decided to amend the Australia Card Bill before it is reintroduced into the coming parliamentary session'. Minister Blewett was speaking on behalf of the Labor Party-of honourable senators opposite-including the two honourable senators at the table today who have professed moral and constitutional outrage.

I profess moral and constitutional outrage that this Government said in February that the legislation would be amended before it was returned to this Parliament for consideration. Why was that not done? It was not done because the Government wished to create the circumstances for an early election, for a double dissolution. It broke its word; it put back into this Parliament legislation which on its own admission required amendment. We as senators were asked by the Government to vote for legislation which could then be passed into law yet which on the face of it, on the Government's own admission, required amendment.

What is our duty in those circumstances? This Government does not control the two chambers and it cannot guarantee amendments to any legislation. Our duty is not to pass legislation which we believe is defective. Quite apart from the objections of principle which have been made so clear in the debates in this place, the Government admits that there are technical deficiencies in the legislation. We were told that we must vote for this legislation. Of course we refused to do so. Again, the Parliament faces the same choice. We are being told to vote for legislation which in our view is outrageous not only in terms of the threat to civil liberty, privacy and all the rest of it but also because it is ineffective, costly and unduly bureaucratic, and because the failure of a few State governments to co-operate may well render it worthless. We are being asked to vote for it over and above our own strong conscientious objections. We are also being asked to vote for it even though the Government admits that as it stands it requires change. This Government is saying that it will take that same defective legislation into a joint sitting and use the Constitution to achieve the passage of that defective legislation.

The Opposition will not be blackmailed, cajoled, abused or forced into supporting this legislation on the basis of the sorts of specious arguments that we have had from the Government over recent days, months and over the last year. This third attempt at the passage of this legislation is fraudulent. It is a fraudulent act by this Government; it is an abuse of the constitutional processes. Where are the amendments that we were told by Senator Ryan, since the second defeat of this Bill since her Government was returned, we would see? She said, `Amendments have been drafted', and the Prime Minister said that those amendments would not be made available to us. So we are not in possession of the amendments at a time when we are being asked to vote on this legislation. I place very little blame on Senator Ryan for this. The views of the Opposition are that the Minister who was responsible, Minister Blewett-and this is not the subject of this motion-should have resigned. Had he not resigned, he should have been sacked.

It is typical of the shoddy behaviour of this Government that it left Senator Ryan carrying this dead cat around. Senator Ryan, because of her differences with her colleagues over recent years, seems to have been left with a sad ragbag of responsibilities. But to be left carrying the can for Dr Blewett's incompetence, to be asked to sell this unsalable proposition: who could be critical of Senator Ryan? One can only commiserate with her for the position she has been put in by her colleagues.

I reject any suggestion that we have done other than to use our constitutional power in an appropriate way. We have done our duty, we have assessed this legislation in a most careful way and we are prepared to take part in a detailed further inquiry which can direct itself to the specifics of this legislation. I remind the Senate that we set out to defeat this legislation in the teeth of public opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Government senators laugh. It was a decision taken when the Bill had 70 per cent support. There could be no simpler proof of our bona fides in this matter. Before concluding my speech I want to say a few things about this Bill to remind honourable senators why we regard it as so important that it should be dealt with in the most careful way. There are no guarantees under this legislation that some government will not come forward and try to extend it so that the centralised register of information can be used in different ways. There is no guarantee under this legislation that there will not be corrupt use.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank Senator Walters for drawing my attention to an interview on AM this morning in which a former official of the Health Insurance Commission, now a practising solicitor in Queensland, was interviewed by John Highfield about allegations that the police used Medicare computer systems to locate people. That is a terrifying account of how, according to Mr Kinloch Oliver-an ex-employee, now a solicitor-in response to the assistance given by the Australian Federal Police in the prosecution of cases of Medicare fraud, information is provided to police from the Medicare computers. Whatever legal guarantees one has, they cannot prevent the corrupt use of information.

Just a week or so ago we were reminded in my home State of Western Australia about the corrupt use of information when a Western Australian credit union got into difficulties and the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia had to become involved. In the Parliament of Western Australia the Premier and a senior Minister told the people of Australia of the financial transactions of the President of the Liberal Party. That was splendid use of supposedly confidential information for the basest of political motives. Let me declare a personal interest, because a few days later the Minister involved said, `And Senator Chaney was involved, in four meetings of the Liberal Party in April to plan a run on that credit union'. All I can say is that I am glad the Press took the trouble to check the records of the April meetings, because I was at none of them. I was doing my parliamentary duties in April and I had some time off for Easter. I attended none of the meetings that these people talked about. This week Senator Kay Patterson-Liberal, Victoria-came forward with information that microfiche records from the Department of Social Security had been found in a suburban street in Melbourne. Legal guarantees are fine but they are no guard against corruption; they are no guard against carelessness-and we are not prepared to see this sort of power vested in individuals.

This censure motion is important because it is the defence against an attack by the Government on the Senate's determination to exercise its constitutional responsibilities. It is important because the Government is trying to use the constitutional process to force through a joint sitting legislation which is defective, and that is clearly unprincipled. It is important because the Government is wasting taxpayers' money by persisting with legislation that would abuse personal privacy way beyond the limits that are desired by the people of Australia. I have moved this motion expressing my contempt for the tactics of the Government. I believe that the Senate should carry this motion to make it clear to the people of Australia that we, as senators, will do our duty.

Senator Chaney is a person who prides himself on observing the proprieties of the place. A very urbane person is Senator Chaney. Senator Chaney has obviously been stung to the quick by our rightful allegations of constitutional vandalism. It is not the sort of thing that Senator Chaney likes to be accused of. Senator Chaney does not like to be reminded of the fact that in 87 years of Senate practice, never has the Senate used its disallowance powers over a regulation to nullify the effect of a principal Act which has been secured. We have all sorts of legislation which depends, for its day-to-day capacity to be administered on regulations. All go to policy issues which the Opposition is opposed to, but it never sought to use its Senate regulation disallowance powers to stop them. It is not unusual, in a very long and complex Bill, for there to be some minor technical and drafting amendments that could be made. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) indicated, and I have indicated, that because of the concern whipped up in the community, the disinformation, the fearmongering and so on, we would have an open mind and an open approach to civil liberties groups, the banking sector and the private sector about minor improvements and that, if improvements could be made, we would be willing to make them. But we never at any point said that the Bill was defective. We never said that the Bill needed substantial amendment. It does not. I hope I have put this so-called amendment issue at rest, although so threadbare is the Opposition's position on this matter that no doubt other speakers will get up and rehash it.
