I have dealt with paragraphs (a) and (b) of the censure motion that Senator Chaney has inflicted on us this afternoon. In paragraph (c) we are accused of:

wasting taxpayers money by persisting with legislation which would abuse personal privacy beyond limits acceptable to the principle of democracy and individual rights sacred to the Australian community.

We have heard lots of words like `sacred' flung about, most inappropriately I might say, in the course of this debate. The greatest example of hypocrisy in a period which has been characterised by extraordinary hypocrisy by honourable senators opposite is this alleged concern for privacy. There are problems in respect of privacy and individual liberties in our community right now. As Senator Macklin would know, huge amounts of data are kept in the private sector by banks, lending institutions, companies that offer credit card systems and so on. There appears to be misuse of that data. Certainly, there is every reason why citizens should be worried and concerned about the degree of information that is held about them in the private sector. At this stage there are no remedies for that.

But what does the Opposition do? Have we had a campaign by the official Opposition or by the Peter Garretts of this world asking us to bring in legislation to protect individuals against the abuse of data which is held in the private sector? No such campaign has been run. Why do not the self-styled heroes of the Australia Card campaign who organise rallies, collect petitions and so on, demand privacy protections for individuals against people in the private sector?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we have.

—Senator Macklin says it has happened. If it has happened, it has happened in a very weak and ineffective fashion. Why did they have to restrict their great outrage and their great desire to rant and rave on television every night to a piece of legislation which for the first time gives those protections?

SPEECH.PARA: In the whole of this debate I have not heard members of the Opposition address themselves to the new, strong, very important provisions to protect individuals that are set out in the Data Protection Agency legislation. I have not heard them address that. I have not heard them say, as would be consistent with their professed interest in individual liberties, `We are very interested in the Data Protection Agency. This is a good measure. This is a good move. It is time we had protections against, in the first instance, information databases in the public sector. We are interested in this. We support this. We will take it seriously. We may even make suggestions about improving and strengthening it'. Why did we not get this response from honourable senators opposite if there is any sincerity at all in their professed concern for civil liberties?

Why would not members of the Opposition give serious consideration to the Data Protection Agency? Why would they not give serious consideration to the way in which we are attempting to write into legislation for the first time ever provisions such as `a citizen has a right to know what information is being kept about him or her by a government in the Australia Card database'; `a citizen has the right to demand an investigation by the Data Protection Agency if there is any misuse of that data or any suspected misuse of that data'; and `a citizen has a right to demand that information kept on his or her Australia Card file can be changed if there is an investigation and it is shown to to incorrect'? Why do we not hear them saying, `These are good measures. These are moves in the right direction. We are a party concerned with civil liberties. We can see that for the first time ever civil liberties are being written into the Data Protection Agency? I would not mind if members of the Opposition said that. I would welcome them saying: `Yes, these are good measures but you could do it better. Why don't you do it this way? Why don't you do it that way? Why don't you formulate the provision in such a way that it is even stronger?'

We invited the official Opposition and the non-official opposition to join with us in the task of providing protections for civil liberties. We have offered the best protections that we were able to develop with all the advice that we received. We had under consideration suggestions which have come from civil liberties groups and so forth as to how the protections could be improved. I must say that there has been some constructive behaviour by some of the civil liberties groups in the community. They have come to us with suggestions and those suggestions are receiving consideration. Certainly, as Dr Blewett and I have indicated, those suggestions are receiving careful attention by us.

But what did we have from the Opposition? We had no constructive approach at all. There was no attempt to work with the Government in this most important task of reforming the taxation system, of getting the frauds out of the taxation and social security systems. We have had no constructive behaviour at all from them and, of course, today is just another example of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you released the fraud report we could give you some answers.

—Senator Vanstone, who is so lacking in any ideas about how this legislation could be improved, says, `Oh, we have to tell you everything we have ever thought of and then you will tell us back'. She should try a bit of activism for a change. The honourable senator is a lawyer. Why does she not look at the Data Protection Agency provisions and tell us how she thinks they could be improved? We would welcome that. But do we get any co-operation? Do we get any constructive assistance? Do we get any proper use of the Senate's scrutiny and revision powers? All we get is grandstanding, fearmongering, misrepresentation and distortion.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say a few things about that fearmongering and distortion. I have been quite horrified at the way in which persons in responsible positions have been prepared to use their positions, the credibility and the authority that they have in the community, to work up all this fearmongering and irrationality. It is a very frightening thing in a democracy, where we try to operate on the basis of rationality, reasoned argument and open discussion and debate, to see crowds of people swept away in an atmosphere of fear and irrationality. We all know because recent history has instructed us-history that the Opposition has seen fit to bring into this debate such as what happened in Nazi Germany-what happens when rationality flies out the window, when people allow themselves to be worked up into a frenzy of fear, hate and scapegoating. We all know the tragedy that ensues when rationality goes out the window.

As a politician, seeing mob psychology in action is one of the most frightening things I have ever witnessed. I am not frightened for myself. I was not frightened that the citizens of Launceston, whom Senator Walters was so busy working up, would leap up and jump on me or shoot me. I am not frightened for my own physical safety. But I am frightened to be reminded, as I was at the Launceston meeting and as I have been by reports of other meetings, of how easy it is to work people up-ordinary reasonable well- educated people who one might think would behave in a rational way-into a state of total irrationality. We get people saying things like, `This is the mark of the beast as revealed in the Book of Revelations'. When this was said, 400 citizens of Launceston cheered as if something sensible and meaningful had been said. It is absolutely dreadful to see people in responsible positions like Senator Walters encouraging the citizenry to go out of its collective mind, to get into a mood where it would do anything. We have seen a disgraceful performance by people who should know better.

I am not going to stand up in the Senate or any public forum and say that everything our Government does is perfect. I am not saying that we have introduced legislation which is new and far-reaching; which deals with civil liberties in a way that has never happened before; which is absolutely perfect; and we do not want to hear any more about it. That is not my stance-it never has been. My stance is this: in trying to make far-reaching reforms in an area in which I think everyone would acknowledge that far-reaching reforms are needed-namely, tax evasion and welfare fraud-our Government has tried to do the most effective, fair and workable job that could be done. That is what we have tried to do. We have had good intentions; we have had good faith in this matter from the very inception.

I have been very disappointed that although we have this massive problem of tax evasion, although we have this massive problem of fraud, although we have this terrible decline in public morality, manifested in the willingness of so many citizens to rip off the system and pass the bill to the person next-door, we have received not one iota of help or co-operation from honourable senators opposite in bringing forward an effective measure to deal with these massive problems. When we came forward with very well considered legislation designed to stop tax fraud, to weed out the cheats from the welfare system and to return to the people of Australia the billions of dollars of which they are being defrauded, what did we get? There was no rational consideration, no co-operation, no attempt to say, `The Government is trying to do something that has to be done. It is a very hard thing to do because these bad and fraudulent practices are so widespread and so deep rooted'.

This is a very difficult thing. It is a great challenge to us but it is a challenge from which we will not resile. But we could have hoped for some co-operation, some constructive criticism. We could have hoped for more from the Australian Democrats, who like to talk about the poor and about the need to spend more money on the poor, on housing, on education, on roads and so forth. They love to say that the Government should be spending more money on all our social programs. But when the time comes for us to introduce a measure which would assist us to do those very things, to have a more just and equitable society, to have more generous welfare measures, what happens? They turn into populists. They see that the Peter Garretts of this world are getting a lot of media coverage and they think, `We will horn in on this act. We will get in there. We can go on television too and use such words as ``freedom'', ``sacred'', ``liberties'' and so forth, in a totally meaningless fashion, even if it means that we will mislead people as to the Government's intention. We will do that, because, after all, what matters to us is having our faces on the front of the newspapers every day or being on television'.

The Liberals, the people who used to like to be the upholders of tradition, the upholders of the forms of the Senate and so forth, now have stumbled upon a well known fact of Senate history, namely, that the Senate has the power to disallow regulations, and they have found that there are regulations in the Australia Card Bill which will allow the Government to set certain dates for bringing certain provisions into effect. They are prepared to use this minor regulatory power, for the first time in Australia's history, for the first time in 87 years of Senate practice, to overturn the principal legislation. Well, it is just pathetic. Their whole performance from day one has been pathetic.

I note as I conclude my remarks that the present Leader of the Liberal Party has joined us. Mr John Howard has joined us in the President's gallery. I am very pleased that he has joined us because I would like, through you of course, Mr Deputy President, to address to him, on behalf of all the senators on my side of the chamber and the Australian public, one question: Mr Howard, if the Bill that we are now discussing is as defective as you claim, if it is a threat to civil liberties, if it is the worst thing you have ever seen and you have to overturn 87 years of convention to stop it at any cost, why did you not tell us about this during the election campaign? Why did you remain silent on all these--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Ryan, it is not appropriate to address questions to people in the gallery, through me or otherwise. You should put the question in more general terms.

—I ask you, Mr Deputy President, what will be on the minds of the people of Australia when they witness the antics of honourable senators opposite, when they witness the performance of Mr Howard in the House of Representatives today. They will ask, `Why didn't they tell us about it when we had the chance to vote?'. There is no answer to that other than political expediency. Members of the Opposition believed that the Australia Card was popular so they were not game to criticise it. Now that they have been able to whip up unpopularity through their campaign of misrepresentation and distortion, they have suddenly decided to exploit that fear and uncertainty. It is a pathetic performance. The censure motion that Senator Chaney has brought before us is pathetic and deserves rejection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The censure motion moved by Senator Chaney reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate maintains and asserts its right and duty to disallow regulations which are against Australia's interest and censures the Government for
(a) its attack on the Senate's determination to exercise its Constitutional responsibilities
(b) proposing to force through a Joint Sitting legislation which it has admitted needs amendment, and

(c) wasting taxpayers money by persisting with legislation which would abuse personal privacy beyond limits acceptable to the principle of democracy and individual rights sacred to the Australian community

Senator Ryan in response has made two major points, the first being that the Senate in some way ought not to use its undoubted power with regard to regulations. I think this is a very odd proposition. The Senate has two major powers: one, of course, being to pass legislation and the other being to scrutinise and deal with delegated legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not proposing to do that to delegated legislation, are you?

—I will get to that in a moment. The Government is proposing that somehow or other the Senate should deny its evident responsibilities in order that the Government can overcome what it must now admit is some careless drafting in its legislation. If the Senate wishes to review those regulations it undoubtedly has the power to do so. Senator Ryan went beyond admitting that power to say that not to exercise it was a convention. Great play was also given in the House of Representatives to this constitutional convention not to do so. Senator Tate yesterday in a similar debate also mentioned something along those lines. The difficulty with conventions, as Senator Tate well knows, having been an active participant in the constitutional conventions, lies in working out what they are. Nevertheless, there are constitutional conventions, and the constitutional conventions have attempted to codify those in some way, particularly in regard to the undoubted latent powers of the Governor-General which everybody discovered belatedly after 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: To say that there is a convention with regard to this power of the Senate is to suggest that there are some examples. The problem with the examples that Senator Ryan gave is that they were all to do with Bills that had passed the Senate. Every piece of legislation that she spoke of was referred to as an Act. An Act is legislation that has passed both chambers. That is an absolute necessity. Every item that Senator Ryan mentioned was as an Act which had passed this chamber.

What we have to look for as examples of this convention are Bills which did not pass this chamber. Which ones are they? I will list all the Bills since Federation that did not pass this chamber but became Acts. They are the Commonwealth Electoral Act (No. 2) 1973, the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act 1973, the Representation Act 1973, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the Health Insurance Act 1973. There was another one, but it was subsequently declared invalid by the High Court of Australia, that being, of course, the Petroleum and Minerals Authority Act 1973. This is the entire corpus upon which we are to base this convention.

Let us go a step further and examine what happened to those Acts in order to establish the argument upon which Senator Ryan relies. We have to do two things. One is to recognise that after the 1974 election the Democratic Labor Party, which combined with the then Opposition, the Liberal and National parties, to defeat those Bills, had gone out of existence. There were no Territory senators, because that was one of the items of the double dissolution. Effectively, the numbers in this chamber were 29 Labor Party, 29 Liberal and National parties-there was also a National Alliance which was a Western Australian linkage of the National Party and the DLP but the senator was sitting with the Liberal and National parties-and there were two Independents, Senator Hall and Senator Townley. I do not want to be unkind to the memories of both those ex-senators. Most of the academic stuff I have read in the very good briefing material that came from the Parliamentary Library says that Senator Townley by and large supported the Opposition; Senator Hall, however, was somewhat more discriminating. It is important to refer to the Joint Sitting to see whether, subsequent to those Bills being passed, this chamber had the power to disallow regulations by virtue of the numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do the numbers make any difference?
—No, but it is rather difficult if one has not got the numbers to disallow the regulation.
—I thought that you were speaking on principle.

—No; I am trying to establish Senator Ryan's argument-Senator Tate is following me-as to whether there is a convention. We have got down to the Bills, we have now found out what they are, we have found their passing the Joint Sitting, and we now come to the numbers subsequent to that in terms of any regulations made on those Bills which were rejected by this chamber. Those are the only ones that count for the purposes of Senator Ryan's convention.
—By your argument only.

—If Senator Coates has any other Bills that will count, that is fine. Unfortunately, Steele Hall's number would have been vital to make the convention. In other words, there needed to be an absolute majority for the disallowance of a regulation-a positive motion-and it needed Steele Hall's vote. Unfortunately, Steele Hall in the double dissolution supported the Bills, and hence subsequent to that he would have supported their implementation. There are no examples in federated history of any Bills being defeated by this chamber where subsequently there were the numbers to deny those regulations. This chamber is the only example of that being able to be done.
—It is unprecedented.
—Yes. There cannot be a convention-there has never been an example in the 87 years of constitutional history where the numbers have been there.
—That is because you are making special mention of those Acts.

—I am only using the Acts which can be used because they are the only Acts that this chamber has voted against. One cannot use Acts that it has voted for. There are many examples of Acts which have passed both chambers where regulations made under them have been disallowed by this chamber. Senators sitting on the Government side of the chamber have engaged in disallowing some motions. Senator Tate has engaged in disallowing some of those motions, as has Senator Robert Ray, and those Ministers are in the chamber now. There are many examples of that-examples which come from the Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. It is a regular feature of this chamber.
—Nothing like a mere date of commencement, though.
—I give you that, Senator. I shall come to that argument. There is not a constitutional convention; let us put that one to rest. That was one of the major planks Senator Ryan was running on.
—Let us call it propriety.

—The honourable senator should not talk too heavily about propriety. I remember during the election campaign your leader, now the Prime Minister, saying that if the Opposition gained power in the House of Representatives, he would try to use the numbers in the Senate to reject Supply.
—When did he say that?
—How about in the Mercury of 11 July 1987:

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP would reconsider its opposition to blocking supply if a Liberal government attached controversial legislation to a supply bill, the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, said yesterday.
Or in the Canberra Times of 11 July:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, warned yesterday that the Labor Party might try to block government Supply Bills . . .

So much for that. At least that story was killed when Senator Haines said the same day that the Democrats would pass Supply, whatever government was elected. Let us be careful about propriety, Senator Coates. Senator Ryan then asked the Opposition parties-although she did not include the Australian Democrats-whether there had been any campaigning. The Opposition parties can speak quite well for themselves on this matter, and Government senators would at least acknowledge that we campaigned on that issue, and we will continue to campaign on the issue.

The next item raised by Senator Ryan was that which has just been raised by way of interjection, namely the frivolous nature of the regulations. Senator Ryan did not make too much of it. It seems to be a matter that Senator Robert Ray was more interested in pushing, but Senator Ryan did raise it. It is an important matter that needs to be addressed and relates to the starting up date. Frankly, the difficulty in addressing that issue is asking the Senate and the members of the Senate who have been elected to oppose the Australia Card to vote in favour of some part of its implementation. It envisages a senator going to the people and saying, `Please elect me and I will oppose the Australia Card', and then coming here and voting for it. In those circumstances people would rightly say, in the true sense of the word, `You are a hypocrite'. That is the definition of a hypocrite-somebody who says one thing in one place and quite another thing in another place. It is not acceptable for senators to get themselves voted into this chamber on the basis of one policy and then vote for the implementation of something different. It is not consistent.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what you are saying is consistent, is it?
—Yes.
—Except that you just refer it to a committee saying in advance that you will knock off the regulations. That is hypocrisy.

—What we did yesterday has made the position very clear. What we were being asked to do by Senator Tate's motion was not to say that we were voting for a regulation, because a regulation was not before us, but to give away our power to vote on that regulation. That is absurd, and that was the motion put down by Senator Tate. He was asking us to give away a power. There is a whole swath of regulation powers connected with the Australia Card; any Bill to get going needs to have a whole host of regulations. There are plenty of senators in this chamber who have been Ministers or who have been in the bureaucracy who know better than I that to get a Bill going there has to be a whole lot of delegated legislation. The Australia Card Bill is no different.
—So you are saying that there is no flaw?
—I have not said there is a flaw.
—There is a flaw in your implementation.

—There is a tactical error on your part, Senator Ray. But in terms of the way the legislation was drafted I am already on record in the media today as saying that I think it is a bit rich to say to somebody who drafted the Bill at that time that they should have been able to foresee likely events about two years ahead. It is not that draftsperson's fault; it is not the Minister's fault.
—If it had been done by proclamation, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would have complained.

—Certainly, and we would probably have sought to amend it to put it back in by regulation. I am on the record as having said that it is not a flaw in the legislation. It is a tactical flaw, and I think even the honourable senator would admit that. It should not have been in there; that is fairly obvious. If this had been recognised as late as last week, the Government could, under the Constitution, have done something about it, but it is a bit late now. It went into the House of Representatives last week, after the double dissolution. The Government could have amended it at that stage. I am not going to press my opinion against the learned Senator Tate in this regard. However, there is-I think the honourable senator will admit this-a disputed opinion about where the amendments and what type of amendments, can be made at that stage. It is not clear cut. Section 57 of the Constitution states:

SPEECH.PARA: If after such dissolution the House of Representatives again passes the proposed law, with or without any amendments which have been made, suggested, or agreed to by the Senate . . .
The only way the Senate can agree to an amendment is if one has been by the House of Representatives. So it is implicit in there that the House of Representatives can make amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the point of the double dissolution.
—It does not say anything--
—Oh!

—I am sorry. I know that it is in dispute, and I am not going to try to be a High Court judge. I am simply saying that there is a legal argument and it could have been attempted. If the Government knew that the regulations could knock it off, it did not have anything to lose. So if it had seen that last week, I reckon that on the balance of probabilities it would have had a go at it.
—We are reasonable sometimes.

—Fair enough. Having seen Senator Ray operate, I know that last week he would have suggested, on the balance of probabilities, `It is good for a run because the whole thing is going to die and if the Government amends it it may have a chance of keeping it alive'.
—A terrible slur.
—He did not think of it.

—I must admit to some chagrin myself for not having seen it. Obviously, the situation is that two years or so ago, whenever the draftsperson did this exercise, I do not think he could have foreseen what was going to occur. I feel sorry for that person; I do not feel any animosity towards him. I do not think that we can say that at that stage he committed a fault because he was not to know that the Bill would not be passed the first time round.
—It is also obvious why it was done that way.

—It is fairly obvious why it was done that way. However, there were possibilities of doing it other ways. In the last Parliament there were a number of occasions. I remember moving amendments arising out of recommendations of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, particularly with regard to Customs legislation, whereby the Government had allowed the implementation of certain parts of a Bill on a ministerial fiat rather than through regulations. I am totally opposed to that, and I am on the record as being so. However, the Government at that stage refused to accept the amendment and it was lost on the voices. So there are examples of where implementations of parts of Bills have been done by ministerial fiat, and others have been done, as an honourable senator was saying earlier, by proclamation, or by regulation. Or, of course, if a mistake had been recognised at that stage-I am quite sure it would have been-the Government could have had a stab at an actual implementation date. So there are and there were ways around it. But I do not want to be drawn into a debate about whether any damage was done at that time. I do not think there was. I believe that the Government made a tactical mistake.

SPEECH.PARA: The other two parts of the motion are very important. The Government has admitted that this Bill is defective in other ways. I am not referring here to those particular regulations. The Government has admitted that this Bill is defective and needs amendment. The Minister then challenged honourable senators opposite with regard to their interest in data protection and privacy. I am quite happy to announce that I, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, introduced a privacy Bill in the last Parliament which went considerably beyond the Data Protection Agency in the Privacy Bill introduced by the Labor Government. In fact, it had an extensive range of additional protections, covering not only government but private data banks, which I readily admit are being abused. Every citizen in this country knows when they get the junk mail through their letter boxes that their names and addresses have been sold by yet another journal to which they subscribe to another mail order house which sends them yet more junk. Everybody knows that is occurring. There needs to be much tighter security, because the linking together of that type of information can create a profile on individuals, such as: `Do they buy or subscribe to the Australian Financial Review or the Sydney Sun' or whatever? They can start building up a profile which is very useful for commercial targeting. It is done in the United States of America and it is now being done here in violation of the privacy of individuals. I accept that it is happening, but there need to be tough laws in regard to that.

I do not see what that situation has got to do with this legislation, because the Government can bring in some tough legislation, and it should have done so quite independently of the Australia Card legislation. That legislation requires it, but there are plenty of other abuses occurring out there. Senator Ryan stood up in here and told us that there were abuses, yet this Government did nothing about them.

Clearly, there are defects in this legislation in terms of the Data Protection Agency in the accompanying legislation on privacy. The Government would have at a later stage, if all of this had gone swimmingly, brought back in here a Bill to amend the Act. It has accepted that this Bill needs amending. It has got the stuff in its hot little hands but it is refusing to tell the Senate what it is. It refused last time to tell us what it wanted to amend.

Lastly, the motion refers to the Government's waste of taxpayers' money by persisting with this legislation. The Government seemingly is persisting with this legislation. I accept that the Government is now in an absolute quandary with regard to what the hell it is doing, but we have heard nothing about it dropping the legislation, getting rid of it for the rest of this term and looking at alternatives which were suggested by the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, of upgrading tax file numbers and following the types of leaders that Senator Tate has from the report from the Australian Federal Police-although he will not tell us what they are.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I take most unkindly to some of the comments made by Senator Ryan, particularly her mention of an inability of people on this side to do anything about the tax cheats. How did the Government manage to bring in all of the Acts it now has in that area? It got them on our vote-the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax; and it even got the legislation regarding the prescribed payments tax due to the vote of the Opposition parties. In fact, it was one of the first Bills introduced along the lines of Fraser Government legislation.

Senators are interested in that. It is a cheap operation. As a result of that bit of thought, Senator Ryan went on to talk about a hysterical campaign. I have publicly admitted that there is a hysterical campaign, but it is being carried out by both sides. But one does not start off a rational campaign by accusing everybody who is opposed to the legislation as being in favour of tax cheats. What type of rational argument is that? Once someone starts an argument by saying to somebody else, `Come over here while I hit you in the eye', and then says, `How is that for a rational argument?', and then hits that other person somewhere else very hard with a foot and says, `That's my second rational argument; now you go away and say something nice', the other person is likely to retaliate in said way, and when people do come back with some of the rather absurd things that they have come back with-Senator Ryan has quoted some of them-that is to be expected. But it was up to the Government, which started this debate, to put it on the proper level. By accusing everybody who was against the proposal of being friends of tax cheats was not to put it on a rational level. So let Government members not complain when they get back some of the stuff they started throwing.

I believe that rational debate on this matter is necessary, and I believe that that took place, at the instigation of this chamber and with the acquiescence of the other chamber, in the inquiry of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card into the concept of an Australia Card. It called for submissions and an enormous number of submissions were made to it. The Committee deliberated, and I believe that this was a very interesting example of people rising above the party line and actually putting forward what they believed. In saying that I refer not only to the Government but also to some Opposition senators. As I understand, from the vote that we took last time on the Australian Democrats' amendment, the Opposition parties are not in support of the tax file number. But some of their members signed that report in favour of the tax file number. A Government member signed it. The Committee's deliberations are a very good example of looking at information before a committee, assessing it and coming forward with a practical, constructive alternative.

At a later stage people can say, `On the basis of further evidence we now don't believe that that is the best'. I accept that. Further evidence can always change one's position. But at that stage a rational debate was under way. Then Senator Walsh and Dr Blewett came in with the heavy boot and put the whole thing out of skew. The debate has, I admit, gone down hill since then, and some quite extraordinary claims have been made on both sides. One such claim made in Queensland concerned an invisible tattoo on everybody's forehead. It is absurd. After all, if we were going to have an invisible tattoo we would put it on the back of people's hands, because the idea of having everybody standing underneath a blue light so that their number could be seen is a bit absurd. But that is the level to which the debate has sunk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this before or after the hand is chopped off?

—I readily admit that it is all pretty stupid. But crucial items are involved in this debate. There is good will on both sides. There is a disagreement. There can be a rational debate and at the end a disagreement. But that kind of rational debate cannot be started by accusing everybody in opposition of bad faith. The Government got what it started with. This motion expresses quite clearly our view and we believe that the Senate should act to protect its responsibilities with regard to delegated legislation. We should not vote to say that a priori, regardless of whatever regulation is brought up on the Australia Card, we are going to love it. We are not and we reserve our right as a Senate to look at every piece of delegated legislation-regulations under this legislation and all other legislation-to decide whether it should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, of course, does not accept the censure motion. That has been made absolutely clear by Senator Ryan. Honourable senators opposite would not expect us to agree with it. But I find it particularly galling that the censure motion should end, in the three subsidiary paragraphs justifying it, by mentioning yet again the charge made by the Opposition that the Australia Card legislation is an abuse of the Australian democratic principles and system and goes beyond the limits acceptable to that democracy and to the individual rights sacred-so it says-to the Australian community. It seems to me that the Australia Card legislation is utterly compatible with Australian democratic principles and with individual rights sacred to the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is not exactly one on which the full debate concerning the Australia Card legislation is appropriate. But I refute any suggestion that the Government has undertaken a series of law making steps which constitute some sort of assault on Australian democracy. To the contrary, we have tried in good faith to bring about a situation whereby the Government of elected representatives of the people, having decided that it was essential to fund certain programs, goes about its job of securing the sinews of government by gathering taxes from those who are required by laws passed by this Parliament to pay them and protecting welfare services against those who would defraud them. There is a series of ways in which that can be done, amongst them, of course, is the misstatement of identity. To say that there is some sort of democratic, long-standing, common law civil right to misstate one's identity in order either to avoid one's obligation to our democracy by refusing to pay taxes as they become due, or else to get from the common purse benefits to which one is not entitled, seems to me to be pushing a concept of democratic and individual rights in our community far beyond what is valid.

This motion speaks also of the Government `wasting taxpayers' money by persisting with legislation' et cetera. The Opposition and the Australian Democrats last night doomed this legislation to utter frustration and failure by saying that they will not pass the regulation necessary to implement it according to a certain schedule provided for in the legislation. They are the ones who are wasting taxpayers' money by sending the legislation to a committee for five or six months. Would it not have been better and more honest for the Opposition to say, `The time has arrived for this chamber, for the third time, to reject this legislation'? At no stage will the committee deliberations taking place over the next four or five months in any way change the eventual outcome. This legislation, despite its passage at the Joint Sitting which will presumably happen one day-I do not know exactly when-will never be fully implemented in a practical way, which requires the setting of certain dates.

It is honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who are wasting taxpayers' money by holding this legislation in a committee with no deliberation process and no hope or expectation that it will be put into effect. Why do honourable senators opposite not say, `We will fail to pass it. We will have a vote on the second reading motion and we will defeat it'. That would have been the more honest way and, since we are talking about wasting taxpayers' money, the more frugal way to go about this process.

Another thing I find particularly galling in the final paragraph of the motion is that it falls from the lips of those who talk about individual rights but who were engaged in the process of raising hysterical objection in the community to the Bill of Rights. I exclude Senator Macklin from this comment. But there are many on the other side of the chamber who brought about within the community a situation where, once again, a piece of legislation designed by this Government-(Quorum formed) We have just had an illustration of exactly what I am talking about. A new senator, in her second week in this chamber, has decided, no doubt on the instruction of her Whip, to frustrate my speaking in this chamber in the ordinary course of debate and the deliberation on this important censure motion against the Government. Rather than allow a Minister of the Government to rise and to put a case in answer to a censure motion, there was a deliberate wasting of my time to put my case to the chamber. For such a person to talk about the rights of this chamber and the rights of citizens to put their case and so on is, I find, totally hypocritical.

To return to the censure motion, it claims that the Government has attacked the Senate's determination to exercise its constitutional responsibilities. I do not think that is correct, and I would like to make a distinction between power and constitutional responsibility. There is no doubt that the Senate chamber is possessed of the power which it has been foreshadowed will be exercised in order to defeat the regulations made under the Australia Card Act when it passes through the Joint Sitting. That is an exercise of power which, of course, is vested in the chamber and is able to be exercised, however bloody-minded that exercise might be. But what we are appealing for and have been appealing for, and what I do not think we deserve censure for, is that the chamber should not exercise that power in a way which is constitutionally irresponsible. I believe that that is what is being proposed by the Opposition and by the Democrats, and that is why it has been the subject of Government criticism.

It was very clear when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) went to Yarralumla and sought from the Governor-General and was granted a double dissolution of the two Houses on the basis that the Senate had twice defeated the Australia Card Bill that we would embark on a process which had as its natural fruition-should the Government have been re-elected by the Australian people as turned out to be the case; it secured a very convincing majority in the House of Representatives-the convening of a joint sitting if the Senate again rejected that same legislation for the third time. One would, therefore, be absolutely correct in saying that the proper constitutional perspective on all this is to say that the elected representatives of the Australian people, having been convened in a joint sitting in a way which is especially provided under section 57 of the Constitution away from the normal method of gathering in two separate chambers and mediating their will as elected representatives, are entitled to carry that legislation into practical effect.

It makes no sense whatsoever to pass legislation at the end of that constitutional process which is rendered utterly void and of no effect by the tactic and device of refusing to prove a regulation which is absolutely essential to its operation. I do not deny that the power is there; I am simply saying that to exercise that power is constitutionally irresponsible because it goes against the natural, practical implementation of legislation which has been subject to all that process leading to a joint sitting and approval by the jointly assembled representatives of the Australian people. I think that it is that particular irresponsibility at a constitutional level which forms the basis of the Government's very real concern about this matter. As always, we find that it is on the other side of the chamber that the conventional proprieties are undermined and we find ourselves in a position of having to defend the Constitution, normal proprieties and arrangements against the Opposition's attacks.

We do not need to go much further in relation to this piece of legislation and the regulation-making power provided for in relation to the setting of dates than the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. It met several times in the very first session in the Thirty-fourth Parliament with Senator Cooney as Chairman. Senator Austin Lewis was the Deputy Chairman. Senator John Coates, Senator Pat Giles, Senator Vanstone and former Senator Reg Withers were on the Committee. That Committee scrutinises legislation to try to decide whether regulations are made in accordance with statute, whether they do not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment and so on. We also had meeting in that very same session the Scrutiny of Bills Committee which I happened to chair. Senator Haines was the Deputy Chairman at the time. Senator Michael Baume, Senator Barney Cooney, Senator Rosemary Crowley and Senator Jocelyn Newman were on that Committee. In none of those committees was there any suggestion that what we were going about was anything but the normal, ordinary method of implementing legislation. Certainly, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in its reports on the Australia Card Bill-and it did have some criticisms of various provisions-never thought to advise the Senate that there was anything at all untoward, unusual or uncommon, or that there was an attempt by way of subterfuge to use this particular regulation-making power. And how could it because it was in very common form and designed simply to provide the practical implementation, the setting of dates, for the operation of this legislation.

So for the Senate chamber to take upon itself the defeat of this legislation other than by way of using the criteria which are used by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in giving its advice to the chamber is to reveal its particular operation as being purely and utterly political. Honourable senators may say that I sound very naive to say that because of course, it is purely and utterly political. It needs to be said that that is what it is and it needs to be exposed as such. Therefore, one cannot say that the Government in making this point is attacking Senate power, but it is certainly attacking, as I said, the irresponsible exercise of that power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't get too heavy on that.

—No. The Government believes that the censure motion before the chamber does not deserve the support of the chamber. It has nothing in it which requires, in my view and in the view of the Government, any great mounting of a defence. The fact is that the Government has merely engaged in what it considers is its duty, to point out to the Australian people that what is being undertaken by the Opposition in foreshadowing that it will refuse to implement the necessary regulations required to give practical effect to this legislation is undermining the proper functions of the constitutionally provided for Joint Sitting and is setting a very bad precedent for the operation of legislation brought into this Parliament on a whole range of matters quite apart from these matters of grave constitutional significance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion of censure upon the Government which has been moved by Senator Chaney and which Senator Macklin has supported. In his remarks in this chamber yesterday afternoon the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who had just concluded his remarks, sought to argue that in this place yesterday the Opposition was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . signalling the intention to frustrate the clear intention of the Constitution, provided for under section 57, that the will of the Parliament be carried into practical effect.
He went on to say:
It would be a nonsense, of course, simply to pass legislation which had no particular effect.
I think that word `particular' should be `practical'. In the same context he said that if a joint sitting of both Houses of the Parliament should pass the legislation:
. . . it would be an expression of the will of the people of Australia . . . that that legislation be part of the law of Australia.

I happen to hold Senator Tate personally in some regard. At the risk of unintentionally damaging his future in the Australian Labor Party irretrievably, I would even go so far as to say that I regard him as an honourable man, not merely in the conventional sense in which that term is quite properly used in this chamber to describe all honourable senators opposite. I therefore agree with Senator Macklin who later in yesterday's debate acknowledged that Senator Tate always makes a good fist of it on these occasions and that he had made a good fist of it on this occasion yesterday. Nevertheless, as Senator Macklin also concluded yesterday, one cannot make bricks with the kind of mere straw with which the Minister's own colleagues-particularly his colleagues responsible for the introduction of the Australia Card, the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, and the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan-have provided him.

I remind Senator Tate that at no time has the Opposition said or even suggested that it would seek to use its numbers, in association with those of the Australian Democrats, simply to pass the Australia Card Bill through the Senate. It has never said or suggested it. Of course, we have moved to have the Bill in its legislative and fully drafted form fully examined for the first time in a committee of the Senate and to have examined also, I add, the many spurious claims which the Government has been making both about the technical operation of the administrative framework which the Bill would institute and about the costs to be incurred and the potential savings to be gained by doing so.

Should those processes still be pursued-in particular, should the Government now fail to take its medicine and plunge on regardless with the Bill, as it seems to be contemplating, rather than withdrawing it-those processes in due time will lead, as Senator Tate quite correctly pointed out, to a joint sitting, presumably during the Autumn session of Parliament. At any such joint sitting, the Government, as it has been happy to tell us ad nauseam, would have the numbers and the Bill would become, in Senator Tate's own words, `part of the law of Australia'. Senator Tate, who is a lawyer whereas I am a mere layman, knows that in matters of law it is very important to use words precisely. In those circumstances the present Bill would become part of the law of Australia; no more, no less. It would not be a Bill with a power to define, for example, the first relevant day or the second relevant day, for the purposes of clauses 40 to 54 of the Bill, by proclamation or by action under executive power; it would be the present Bill with its power to declare such dates by regulation. I see that Senator Tate is nodding; I am glad to have his assent to what I have said.

Senator Tate sought to persuade us yesterday that the constitutional provisions of section 57 go further than this and that the Bill which has been subject to the provisions of that section should be carried into `practical' effect-a word which he interposed twice yesterday in his remarks. In fairness to Senator Tate let me say that he did yesterday and again today try to persuade us of the cogency of his arguments rather than bully us, browbeat us, vilify us or even slander us in the manner of his uncomfortable and increasingly woebegone colleague, the Special Minister of State. Be that as it may, the fact is that what Senator Tate was actually asking the Senate to do-this has been extremely cogently pointed out by Senator Macklin-was to allow the Government to have in practical terms, his words, a Bill under which the executive could proceed to declare `the first relevant day' and `the second relevant day' by executive decision even though, in fact, the Bill provided no such power.

Like Senator Macklin I think it would be an enormous pity if the Government, and particularly the Ministers in the Government allegedly responsible for this Bill, were so to forget themselves as to seek to place the blame for this technical aspect of the Bill on the Office of Parliamentary Counsel and on the instructing solicitor in the Department who gave instructions for the outcome that we now have. As Senator Macklin remarked, at the time the Bill was drafted, no doubt it was thought to be an entirely appropriate way to proceed by way of regulation in that particular area of the draft legislation. In particular, there was no way at that time, I presume, that the draftsman in question could have foreseen that this Bill would become in due course that very rare thing in our constitutional history-that is, a double dissolution Bill.

The truth is that all of this area of the debate was already summed up-actually summed up in advance-in a characteristic pithy manner by Mr Ewart Smith, whose opinion on the Bill was tabled in the Senate yesterday and incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wrote this for him, too?
—As Mr Smith said:

SPEECH.PARA: And why were regulations chosen as the vehicle of fixing such a date, if it was not to allow the subsequent ease of extending, by alteration, that date:
This is the key sentence:
It could have been provided for by proclamation, or by Executive act, which would not be disallowable. Having chosen the means, the consequences flow.

I digress again for a moment to respond belatedly to the interjection from Senator Aulich, who made an interjection similar to that made in this place when I was speaking on the Australia Card last Tuesday evening by a colleague of his. That colleague suggested that I may have had some hand in the drafting of the letter which Mr Ewart Smith had sent to and had published in the Australian of that day. Senator Aulich is now suggesting that I may have had some hand in the drafting of Mr Ewart Smith's opinion. I can only say that not only does that betray an unduly complimentary view of my legal powers, for which I thank the honourable senator, but much more importantly it betrays what I can only describe as a contemptible attitude towards the position of a retired public servant who has given Commonwealth governments many years of honourable, faithful and above all distinguished service and whose name, I can assure the honourable senator, will go down in the history books in this country when that of the honourable senator will be long forgotten.

The clear implication of the Government's arguments yesterday on this matter is that the Senate should abandon its powers to examine and, as appropriate, disallow regulations made by the appropriate Minister irrespective of whether a majority of senators in this place is totally opposed to the outcome to which acceptance of the regulation would inevitably lead. I put it to the chamber that acceptance by the Senate of any such view would represent quite an enormous increase in the effective scope of Executive power over the Parliament of which the Senate constitutes a vital part. The fact that the Government nevertheless propounds such a view both here and in the other place should perhaps come as no surprise to us. In common with most governments-again, in fairness, I should say that this has been true of governments from both sides of the political spectrum-the Government seeks continually to arrogate to itself powers to do what it likes, and to hell with the Parliament.

In the House of Representatives any government generally has, by definition, the numbers, otherwise it would be most unlikely that it would be the government or at least it would not be the government for very long. It follows that so long as it can rule its back benchers there, a government can generally afford to, and generally does, ignore the views of ordinary members of that House. But in the Senate, thank goodness, that is not so. The Opposition side at least has no intention of tamely acquiescing to the request that was put to us yesterday, and which we disallowed, for it to become so.

In short, on the issue of the constitutional propriety of disallowing regulations which are necessary to bring the Australia Card legislation into effective operation, I say first that disallowance of regulations would be a perfectly legitimate action in any circumstances. The power to disallow regulations was, and is, conferred by the Parliament on each of its Houses by section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act. The power is not subject to conditions or restrictions. It may be taken away by Parliament whenever it decides that it should do so. Indeed it often is in the case of particular Acts by specific provisions in the Acts concerned which state that they are not subject to the Acts Interpretation Act.

In passing let me say something very briefly about constitutional conventions, proprieties and matters of that kind if in that context we are to have such tired old refrains as `the constitutional impropriety' of the events of 1975 thrown up at us. The only constitutional impropriety that ever occurred in 1975 was the impropriety of the government of that day and, in particular, the Prime Minister of that day, to seek to govern without Supply and to take the most extraordinary measures to attempt to do so. If Senator Richardson, who is trying to interject, would like me to continue on that subject, I would be very happy to oblige him at some time in the future with as much detail as he would care to have me offer him.

Let me continue. In present circumstances the Government is certainly in no position to complain about almost any measure, let alone a perfectly proper and constitutionally apt measure such as the disallowance of regulations that might be taken to defeat the operation of this Bill. I say that because the Australia Card Bill has been introduced in its present form in this session of the Parliament not because, even as most ardent supporters believe, it is properly drafted-regulation making powers and associated requirements quite aside-or because it does not need amendment, or because it does not need amendment or will not be amended before proclamation. As my question at Question Time today to the Special Minister of State indicated, I hazard the guess-I do not put it higher than `guess' for these purposes at least-that the Government and or parliamentary counsel already have a number of the provisions identified as requiring amendment for either technical or policy reasons. As Senator Chaney remarked in moving this motion earlier this afternoon, if I am right in that conjecture the Bill, is, and was, in a real sense a fraud upon the Parliament. It was, in short, introduced in its present form not because it has, or had, any support in that form but simply because if necessary amendments had been made before its introduction, the Government would have relinquished the right to have it passed at a joint sitting.

This legislation has been brought forward by a government which is accusing this side of the chamber of constitutional impropriety. What absolute humbug! The only constitutional impropriety in this whole sorry affair will be if the Minister for Community Services and Health fails to resign his portfolio or if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) lacks the courage to dismiss him. So much for all that bluff and bluster on the matter yesterday from the Minister who now faces the prospect of applying for the unemployment benefit. So much for the similar bluff and bluster which, I understand, characterised the remarks of the Prime Minister and other Government Ministers in their back-firing effort this morning in another place.

The real question of interest now is why the Government is still proposing to force through a joint sitting legislation which it has admitted needs amendment and why it is proposing to continue to waste taxpayers' money by persisting with legislation which would abuse personal privacy beyond limits acceptable to the principles of democracy and individual rights which all of us, I am sure, hold equally dear. That is in itself, an interesting question.

Senator Tate, in his closing remarks, addressed the final passage of the censure motion to which I have just referred and appeared to take some exception to the fact that yesterday-notwithstanding the events of yesterday in a more general sense-the Senate committed the Bill to a committee for its examination. I do not want to misrepresent what Senator Tate said but he appeared to be suggesting that it was that conjuncture which he found most difficult to understand and, indeed, even to accept. However, I say in all fairness to Senator Tate that, if the Government feels that it is improper or inappropriate under the circumstances that have now emerged for the Bill to be subjected to those processes, it has a possible remedy; it can withdraw the Bill. The Opposition would have to decide at that stage what it would do.

The Government has given not the slightest indication that it might withdraw the Bill and that is, as I have said, a puzzling position. I can only assume that one reason why the Government may not be willing to withdraw the Bill, at this juncture at least, is that the Prime Minister has committed such an enormous amount of personal political capital to it. We all know that when the personal conceit of the Prime Minister is involved, very many irrational outcomes can obtain. Nevertheless, what we now seem to be having represents a very high price not merely for the Government to pay-and it will keep on paying it, I assure it-but also for the Australian people to pay. The Government should be strongly censured for forcing them to continue doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak for only a brief period because this debate has just about wound up. I do not care to comment on the very lengthy statement-I can call it only a statement-made by Senator Stone, who has never been known for either his loyalty or his brevity--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. It appears to me that, as the Senate has voted on this matter, the honourable senator is reflecting on a vote of the Senate. —I ask Senator Aulich to speak to the matter before the Chair.

—I would be delighted to, Mr Acting Deputy President, after having been interrupted twice by the Opposition. Essentially, the will of the Australian people has been thwarted by this chamber and by Opposition senators. Certain principles have been damaged on the way to what is, after all, only a temporary set-back as far as the Government is concerned. However, it is not a temporary set-back for parliamentary procedure, nor for the respect in which this institution is held in the future. What can be done by one side can be done by another on other occasions. I feel sad that today we are seeing a repetition of some of the things that were done in 1975 when some honourable senators opposite could not accept that somewhere along the line getting the majority of seats at an election gives some mandate to the government of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Liberal Party, unlike the Democrats, was not able, willing or courageous enough to go out to the community and seek a mandate for its viewpoint on the Australian Card is not a surprise to me. It is an accident of history which is damaging the whole nature of political debate in this country. That a major political party can go to the people, try not to debate a major issue for eight weeks of an election campaign, run away from that issue and then come into this chamber and indicate that somehow or other it has a mandate to deal in constitutional trickery, as it has, to knock over an issue this Government has stood up for during the last year and a half surprises me. It is damaging to politics and to the way people regard politicians.

On a personal note, I entered politics in 1976 in a State area. I did so because of what happened in 1975. I had a naive view that politicians ought to reflect fairness and equity, that the party that gets a majority gets a mandate to follow through its platform. I have since been disabused of that view. My naivety has again attacked by what has gone on in this chamber over the last week or so.

When the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) approached me to see whether I wanted to chair the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card I said, `Can you give me some time to think about it?'. I did that because I had some concerns about the question of introducing a national identification system, for whatever purposes. I thought about it. I talked with people. I got back to Dr Blewett and said, `Yes, I will agree to chair the Committee, but I am not going to rubber-stamp a Government proposal. I will not make a public statement about my viewpoints before the Committee comes down with its recommendations or hears the evidence'. Honourable senators will not find on record from me, at any time before or during that Committee's hearings, any indication of what my personal viewpoint about an Australia Card was-not one sentence. But there were others on that Committee who had no qualms about making their viewpoints known before they had seen all the evidence.

I listened to the evidence. One of the things that persuaded me in the long run that there needed to be an Australia Card, with accompanying privacy protection, was the fact that all governments are going to seek, wherever they can, revenue that is forgone as tax evasion rolls through the community. It does not matter whether we are talking about a Liberal-National Party government or a Labor government. When money is put before a government's eyes, when a government knows that there is revenue to be gained and that tax equity and justice is possible, that government will go after it.

What are the options? Give me five minutes. One does not have to be a genius to work out some scheme whereby one can get that money back. One can get it back, all right. One can get it back from the social welfare cheats. But at what cost? I ask honourable senators opposite to go to the Income Tax Assessment Act and to read carefully what sections 263 and 264 say about the right of the Australian Taxation Office to enter property, to seize records, to examine the personal accounts of every individual in the community and, in many cases, to do so without the individual knowing that the Taxation Office is investigating him. Anyone who has been through a tax audit, or who knows someone who has been through a tax audit, knows that the imposition of governmental powers on individuals can be quite horrendous and, in many cases, can take away a person's civil liberties, as I understand them. Honourable senators opposite should examine the possibilities under the Act. The possibilities under the Act of a tax commissioner being directed and pushed by a government and going further than any of us in this chamber care to consider in terms of breaching people's civil liberties are enormous.

We could go to other areas. We could, for example, go back to some of the horrendous exercises that were carried out by the Department of Social Security years ago, when it tried to find out whether people were living with people they had not recorded themselves as living with, and to the cohabitation rules of examination that prevailed 10 years ago. Do honourable senators opposite want to upgrade them again? Do they want snoops in people's homes again, which is what they would have if they really wanted to stamp out social welfare fraud? Do they, for example, want to use the Medicare system to stamp out taxation and welfare fraud? I could explain to honourable senators in this chamber now-I do not intend to-just how one could use the Medicare system, for example, to cut out tax evasion and social security or welfare fraud. But the way one could use the Medicare system would involve a grosser breach of our civil liberties than anything contemplated by the Australia Card.

All I am saying is that when we make a value judgment about the Australia Card we must also take into account what the alternatives are. I do not believe that the alternatives of the Opposition, that is, the beefing up of the Taxation Office, the beefing up of the audit powers and pressuring the Social Security Department to get into people's private lives, are alternatives that we, as a chamber, ought to find acceptable. When the Opposition calls for an end to social welfare fraud-it never seems to call for an end to taxation evasion-it should think about that. In the long run it would be handing more power to civil servants to invade people's lives than the Australia Card would ever have done.

Another point-I have mentioned this before in debates-is that the Joint Select Committee had a role to play in terms of creating a debate in the community about the Australia Card. On the whole, it did that. We had an enormous response from witnesses. Many honourable senators have already commented on the way the Committee went about its business. On the whole, most people had a chance to have their say. From both sides of the political spectrum, from both sides of the argument, we received submissions and evidence that made one think about the importance of the decision we were making. Yet, following an election at which the Government was given a mandate, the level of debate has declined. It has become a matter of scare tactics, of frightening people. I see that Senator Walters is leaving the chamber again. For heaven's sake leave. The place is smelling of hypocrisy.

In the last few weeks, not only has the nature of the debate changed, in terms of creating hysteria in the community, frightening people who should never have been frightened and ensuring that this major issue eventually has deteriorated into the sort of debate we have had here over the last week or so, but also we have seen constitutional trickery of a nature which I believe sets an unhealthy precedent. Honourable senators opposite know that a mandate was given. They know what the normal procedure is after a double dissolution has been called and the procedures have been gone through by a particular government and parliament. Yet, by simply using constitutional trickery which the average child could have thought up and of which most honourable senators were aware the Opposition has now, in effect, negated the will of the Australian public.

Of course, the Opposition knows that as a Bill gets close, as it hits a particular House of Parliament, as the debate starts to lift in its hysteria and so on and people start to worry about the effects on them, particularly the financial effects, there will be a temporary dip in popularity for that legislation, particularly if it is aimed at cutting out tax evasion. We saw this with the legislation which dealt with the fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and entertainment expenses. We saw it in a number of areas of tax reform in which this Government has engaged. Yet, we hear nothing about those reforms a year or so after they were brought into this Parliament. The Opposition knew that by seizing the right opportunity to try to get away with this constitutional trickery its action would be tolerated, and it has been.

I will not comment to any great extent on the role of the Press in this matter. I think that on the whole the Press did not do its duty during the election campaign to pick up and pursue either the Opposition's views about the Australia Card or the Government's views. Yet, the Press has been very willing to pick up the more hysterical outpourings that we have seen over the last few weeks. In a sense, this is an occasion for a certain degree of sadness. If this chamber is going to operate in this way in the future on all major issues, in the long run the status of politicians in this community will drop even lower than it is now. That should be a matter of concern for people in this chamber. It is not a question of whether we shout at each other in the chamber; is the way in which we arrange the debates in the community on major issues.

The people who engaged in constitutional trickery to get their own way-and to some extent I exclude the Democrats because they did go out and debate this issue; they did say where they stood-and who ran away from the issue during the campaign have a great deal to answer for. It is not just a question of letting the tax evaders and the tax dodgers off; it is what they have done to this chamber. I oppose this censure motion for more reasons than those that relate only to the Australia Card.

It is important that this chamber assert to the Australian people that it will stand by the decisions it took yesterday and will be prepared to stand up again in the same way. Like Senator Vallentine, I regret that the censure motion has taken some two and a half hours but, in reality, that was an assertion which had to be made and I make no apology for bringing it forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank Senator Macklin and Senator Stone for their support of the motion. Senator Macklin made a careful analysis of the Labor suggestion that some sort of convention has now been breached. I welcome the factual material that he put before the Senate. I welcome the contribution of Senator Stone in the same vein. I will very briefly comment on the responses of the Government senators who have spoken. Senator Ryan made what I think can only be described as a limp defence of the Government position. She made a number of claims in common with claims made at the end of the debate by Senator Aulich. She claimed, for example, that the Opposition, until a month or so ago, had done nothing about the identity card Bill, totally ignoring the fact that we have on two occasions over the last year defeated identity card legislation in the terms of the legislation which was sent off to a committee yesterday. She claimed that we did nothing in the campaign. I wish I had met Senator Ryan in the Bourke Street Mall when, with more than a dozen other Liberals, I handed out copies of a booklet warning of various Labor laws including the Australia Card Bill. The booklet, which contained several pages of description of that Bill, was handed to anybody who was in the Mall at that time. That was but one example of the campaign efforts that were made and it was, in response to the interjection from Senator Ray at lunchtime, a week or so before the campaign concluded.

But the most pathetic part of the response from the Government came when both Senator Ryan and Senator Aulich chided the Opposition for being parties to frightening people. I noted that a number of Opposition senators, including Senator Vanstone, interjected during those allegations and reminded the Senate of the scare campaigns undertaken by the Australian Labor Party in the last election campaign and, indeed, going back beyond that. The letters which were written to the aged in Australia threatening their situation and the use of direct mail to frighten people were notable features of the last campaign. That sits very squarely with the scare campaigns which were undertaken by Labor with respect to the issue of privatisation. I have seen many letters signed by Labor Ministers, State and Federal, advising people of the great risks that they were running with respect to privatisation-namely, the loss of their jobs and their livelihoods. Scare campaigns have been very successfully used by the Labor Party.

To suggest that the Opposition, which defeated this Bill twice in the Senate in conjunction with the Australian Democrats, has engaged in scare campaigns is, on the face of it, quite absurd. A range of arguments were put forward. Reference was made to some biblical passage which, I must say, I was not familiar with until it was used in this campaign and I finally got round to reading it. There is a most extraordinary appropriateness in the words which were used in terms of the references to numbering, the carrying on of business and so on. I find the fit quite extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it from Revelation?
—I am not sure which book it was from. I reject with very great ease of mind the allegations that in some way the Opposition has been a party to frightening people on this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin made the very important point that it would be totally hypocritical for those of us who went to election on this Bill, for those of us who were standing behind a policy of opposition to the ID card, to turn around now and say that we would vote in favour of any proposition which would implement that card. That is not a stance which the Opposition will adopt.

The only additional point of any substance that I believe was raised was the issue of privacy. There is, of course, nothing to stop this Government, as was pointed out in the debate, from introducing legislation which will protect the right to privacy to which Australian citizens and others are entitled without the use of this identity card legislation. I think that can be dealt with as a quite separate issue and the Government is entitled to do so.

One last point which I wish to touch on is the issue of the mandate. Government speakers claim that the identity card Bill should be passed because the Government has a mandate. The doctrine of the mandate has been severely knocked around by the present Government, the Labor Party and, indeed, by everybody. It is trotted forth very conveniently. Privatisation, as I have mentioned, is the classic example. One can find a number of Labor statements bagging privatisation and suggesting that it would be a disaster for the Australian people and for the community. Then we find the Government changing course. The Government has not heard from us the cry of mandate.

There are more awkward examples for the Labor Party. The Labor Party had a clear mandate when it was elected to do something about the Aboriginal land rights in every State of this country. Senator Ryan stood opposite me-I was on that side then-and said that the first legislative act of a Labor Government would be to enact land rights legislation for Queensland.

I would have thought, on the arguments I have heard here today, that the Labor Party would be saying that it had a clear mandate for that legislation. Of course, it had in Senator Macklin, who leads for the Australian Democrats on this issue, someone who is more in favour of the Labor platform than even the Labor Party. There has never been a legislative bar in the 4 1/2 years in which those opposite have been in government to their carrying out the policy for which they have had a mandate. I give that as an example of the shallowness of the mandate argument. The reality is that the Government has backed off that legislation, as it backed off the Bill of Rights. It had a mandate for a Bill of Rights and it has backed off. It backed off because it smelt the winds of public opinion.

I reject the talk of a mandate that we have heard here today, because it is so completely out of line with this Government's action. In areas where it clearly had a policy position, on which it had been elected, it has chosen not to act. In other areas, where it had no favourable policy position, it has chosen to go in the opposite direction. So the mandate argument is nonsense.

I do not need to repeat my motion. What is quite clear is that the Senate wishes to assert its right and its duty to disallow regulations that are against Australia's interest. It is clear that the Senate intends to censure the Government for its attack on the Senate for its determination to exercise its constitutional responsibilities and for proposing to force through a joint sitting legislation which the Government itself has admitted needs amendment. I commend the motion to the Senate and I note the failure of the Government to introduce any convincing arguments which would lead us not to put forward this motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.
