TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) congratulates the United States and the Soviet Union on their historic agreement to eliminate short range and intermediate range land-based nuclear missiles and trusts that further negotiations will be successful and achieve mutual balanced and verifiable reduction in strategic nuclear weapons of the order of 50 per cent in the immediate future; and

(b) notes that this historic reduction is a positive outcome of the policy of deterrence practised by the Western democracies whereby some parity was maintained between the nuclear arsenals of the West and the Soviets, thereby allowing mutual and balanced force reductions to take place safely.

It is a matter of great regret that this chamber spends so little time debating great issues for this country in relation to national security, defence and foreign policy. I hope that with the big change we have had in the Senate with the many new senators who have joined us since the last election there will be a change of interest and that honourable senators will spend some of our time which the seriousness of the subject demands in debating our ideas in this chamber. Given the Government's views, it is very unlikely that it will make time available. In fairness to the Government of the day, foreign affairs and defence require very little legislation support and therefore not a great deal of time is devoted to these subjects. The opportunities on which we can raise these matters are in general business and adjournment debates. I regret the time that was lost this afternoon, but I suppose if one is sanguine about it, once we start censuring this Government we are fortunate to be able to wind the matter up in as short a period as three hours.

The motion before the Chair deals with the apparent agreement reached between the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United States on the removal of intermediate nuclear weapons. The motion indicates a reduction of 50 per cent in strategic weapons. That is important because this world has far too many nuclear weapons-certainly far more than are required for effective deterrence. The motion also draws attention to the importance of the doctrine of deterrence which has been followed by the Western democracies since the end of the Second World War and which has given us a period of unparalleled peace between the major powers. Having had a long-standing interest in disarmament and arms reduction matters, it is a matter of regret for me that on such an important occasion as this-and I believe it is an historic occasion which ranks with the agreements such as the Antarctic Treaty, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and SALT I and SALT II, to name a few. I have not heard one word of response from people outside who always tell us how many hundreds of thousands of people are marching on Palm Sunday, or from the other professional peace activists in the Australian community. I have not seen one Press release supporting the initiatives taken by the super-powers on this matter. That is a matter of some regret.

The class of weapons that we are talking about are the short range nuclear weapons. Nuclear weapons can be classified in several ways, but here we are talking of a class of weapons with a range of between 600 and 3,000 miles. They are particularly relevant to the western European theatre of operations. Western Europe, the home of the Western democracies, has a large number of countries with a high population density. It borders the satellites of the Soviet Union. Western Europe is characterised by having a highly capable and very large industrial capacity which is coveted by the Soviet Union. With its inability to supply consumer and industrial goods to its own community, it would like very much to acquire those assets in western Europe. That is one of the reasons why there has been such a strong development of Warsaw Pact forces on the border with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries.

Another contributing factor is the insecurity felt by the Soviets. That is understandable when one considers their history. They have a great fear of a united Germany or of a united Europe moving against the Soviet Union. Those two factors working together-the industrial capability and the hereditary fear on the part of the Soviets-have led the Soviets to build up a considerable conventional force structure and a nuclear force structure opposing the NATO countries. Because the Soviets have built up their conventional forces to such a degree, the NATO countries have relied on a nuclear component as an essential part of their defence. I shall return to that topic in a moment.

The Soviets have not been outdone in the deployment of nuclear forces in the European theatre. In the 1960s they deployed about 500 SS4s, which have a range of about 1,200 miles and which fit into the category of short range nuclear weapons. Of those 500 they have now about 100 left. Later they deployed the SS5s. These weapons are essentially deployed reasonably close to the Iron Curtain borders. As a counter to that the West Germans in the 1960s deployed 72 Pershing I missiles. The unusual factor was that the nuclear warheads on those weapons are under the direct control of the United States. They are a much shorter range weapon than the Soviet SS4s and SS5s. Additional to these ballistic missiles both sides have a large arsenal of tactical and battle field nuclear weapons.

The ante was raised in 1977 when the Soviets deployed the SS20. It is a very formidable weapon which has a capability way beyond the smaller and simpler ballistic missiles that were in place beforehand. The SS20, with a range of 1,200 miles, has three warheads which can be independently targeted. It has a reasonably high degree of accuracy. The Soviets have deployed 441 of those, according to intelligence reports. This gives them 1323 warheads-more than enough to cover all the important cities in western Europe. The western Europeans, who were concerned about this, changed their policy and asked the Americans to base nuclear weapons in western Europe. That led to the introduction of the Pershing II and the ground launch cruise missiles.

The fear of the Europeans is that the Americans will not defend them in a nuclear war. The Europeans feel that if American missiles are based in western Europe in the event of outbreak of hostilities by the Warsaw Pact countries the Americans will be committed to fight. They feel that if the nuclear umbrella operates from mainland United States the Americans will not be prepared to retaliate against a Soviet attack and hazard mainland United States. That is the principle of decoupling which has played an important part in international relations in the European theatre. It is as a buttress against decoupling of the United States support from the western European countries that led the NATO countries in December 1979 to develop what became known as the two-track principle. This involved, first of all, the modernisation of their intermediate range nuclear forces (INF) by deployment of the Pershing II and the ground-launched cruise missiles and, secondly, a call on the United States and the USSR to reduce the numbers of INF weapons that they had in the theatre.

Those talks about reduction have had a long history, and it is really the culmination of those talks, seven years later, that we are seeing today, and we hope that they go to a successful conclusion. As well as this, the United States has made unilateral moves to run down its numbers. In 1980, it withdrew 1,000 warheads from Europe, and in 1983 it withdrew another 1,400. The level of United States warheads in Western Europe by the end of 1983 was reduced by one-third of what it was in 1979. In October 1980 the United States and the USSR embarked on preliminary talks on the INF, and in November 1981 President Reagan proposed the zero-zero option, which now seven years later is the proposal that is on the board and looks as though it will reach fruition. The zero-zero proposal simply was that both sides remove all their intermediate range land-based nuclear weapons around the world.

Those talks have had a rocky history. In November 1983 all disarmament talks were broken off when the Russians tried to prejudice the outcome of the presidential elections in the United States. It is not generally recognised that there is quite a large constituency in the United States of the disarmament movement, and no American president can afford to treat that cavalierly, and by breaking off negotiations and blaming President Reagan, the Soviets at that time sought to prejudice President Reagan's re-election campaign; so we had an interregnum for about 12 to 18 months when no serious talks took place. But they have since resumed and apparently they are going to be successful.

Whilst we welcome the reductions, it does mean that the conventional force imbalance in Western Europe remains, and that poses obligations on Western Europe. It is not generally realised that the political leaders in Western Europe, although they do not rush into print to say this, really love the bomb. They love nuclear weapons because they enable them to provide a counter to the great imbalance of the Soviet forces, and to provide it more cheaply than they could do so if they had to provide for conventional forces. They will have to face up to that obligation and put more money into their conventional force structures to counter the lack of these INF weapons.

I will be very interested to find out some of the verification details, because at the moment the details of what is involved in verification by both sides is not clear, and there have been different stories. The initial American proposal was that the Americans wanted not only on-site inspections of missile bases but also inspections of factories. In about August this year the Americans withdrew the requirement to inspect factories. But I did see earlier this week that the Soviets were asking for facilities to have surprise visits to any number of places in the United Kingdom; not confining them to the two sites at which the ground launched cruise missiles are based. It will be interesting to see what sort of final agreement comes out on the verification program.

As honourable senators know, verification is the key to arms control. Agreements that are reached by sitting around a table and talking to delegates from other nations do not count for much unless one can physically go in and see what is being done. It has been the great reluctance of both sides, but particularly the reluctance of the Soviet Union, to allow representatives from the Western democracies to enter Soviet territory to inspect sites, that has been one of the great sticking points over the years in regard to verification. But hopefully, under the Gorbachev regime, we may well be getting to a stage where there is a bit of relaxation in this prohibition of on-site inspections by the Soviets. I guess that some of the hardest horse-trading that is being done in these negotiations turns on those points. But I am sure that everyone in the Senate will join me in congratulating the two super-powers on their achievements so far.

The second part of the motion deals with the movement towards a 50 per cent reduction in strategic nuclear weapons. I put that figure in purely because, although it has no intrinsic merit per se, it happens to be the figure that is on the table for negotiation at present. The numbers of existing nuclear weapons are excessive, whatever way we look at them. But it is very important to get the point across-and the nuclear disarmers cannot understand, comprehend or ever come to grips with this-that the weapons are not the cause of the problem between the super-powers. The weapons are the symptoms of the problem, and until we reach a political rapprochement between the Soviets and the Western democracies, we will have weapons. Until we have some degree of mutual trust and understanding, so that we have some feeling of security between the two blocs, we will always have weapons. To attack blindly the number of weapons and to talk about achieving their total elimination and of total disarmament is to talk of something absolutely unattainable until we solve the psychological problems in the relations between the two countries.

Having made that point, I come back to the point I made earlier: that there are too many nuclear weapons in the world, and probably too many conventional weapons, and we should move towards reducing those numbers. There is a case for an improvement as well as a reduction in the numbers of weapons that are held; there is a case for improving them so that safety and reliability is ensured. If we can guarantee that a weapons system will work, that an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM), will always work, we might need only half a dozen or 10 of them, whereas if there is a failure rate, as we have with any sort of mechanical or electronic equipment, we might have to have four or five times that number to guarantee a deterrent capability so that we know that if we ever need to use them we will get the base number that we need to work. So there is a need for continuing research.

I do not want to get into a long debate about disarmament procedures. It is not appropriate at the moment because I would like to leave enough time to allow some other speakers to make a contribution tonight. All this business about a reduction in numbers has got to be seen in the light of history. What is taking place today did not arise de novo. We have had disarmament talks in relation to nuclear weapons since the late 1940s, and of course, disarmament talks have gone on for probably the last 100 years in one way or another. The original nuclear disarmament talks and arms reduction talks in the 1940s and early 1950s were carried out under the auspices of the United Nations. They differed from the present series of talks insofar as they strove for total disarmament. Agreement was not possible, however desirable it may have been at the time, and both the Soviets and the United States moved into more restricted areas and tried to get limited agreements in specific fields.

That pattern basically still applies today, and the arms negotiations that have taken place can be considered in three broad categories. We have the non-armament agreements, which seek to stop the spread of nuclear weapons to states that do not possess a nuclear capability; we have confidence building measures, which try to stop the outbreak of war through suspicion or false alarms between the two blocs; and there are arms limitations measures, which constrain the development, testing and deployment of nuclear weapons. Those three broad categories came in in about the late 1950s. Of the non-armament treaties, the significant ones, which everyone in this Senate would know, are the Antarctic Treaty of 1959, the Latin American Nuclear Free Zone Treaty of 1967, the Outer Space Treaty of 1967, and in my judgment the most important of all, and the one whose implications are least understood by members of this Parliament-and Australia is a signatory to it-is the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty of 1968. In my judgment that is the most important milestone that has been reached in international negotiations. It is something about which we in this chamber ought to have a lot more debate because people simply do not understand what Australia's obligations are as a signatory to that Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

But the great era of bilateral treaty activism was the period between 1969 and 1979 in which a whole lot of agreements were attained. There was the Seabed Treaty of 1971 in the non-armaments area. In the area of confidence building agreements a number of important measures were agreed. There were the Agreements to Reduce the Risk of Nuclear War between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics which provided for safeguards against accidental or unauthorised use of nuclear weapons and provided for notification when things got out of control accidentally. The Agreement between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on the Prevention of Nuclear War established a code of conduct for both participating governments to sign to reduce the risk of war and committed both governments to consult in the event of developments that might lead to nuclear confrontation. In the area of arms limitation agreements, this was the period of SALT I and the Treaty between the United States of America and the USSR on the Limitation of Underground Nuclear Weapon Tests.

SALT I consisted of two agreements. The first was an anti-ballistic missile treaty, which is still in place with the modification that instead of two sites being allowed to each party the number has been reduced to one. The other part of SALT I was a limitation on strategic offensive arms. It basically sought to limit the number of submarines, platforms and missile systems. To go ahead of the argument a little, it failed because it defined systems rather than numbers of warheads. About ten years later, in June 1979, SALT II came along which sough to correct the lack of control on numbers of warheads that was inherent in the SALT I agreement. That was the situation basically until the Reagan Administration came into power. It took a rather radical view initially to arms negotiations. It was not too co-operative in any way at all with the Soviets. Fortunately, it has matured and taken a much broader and more accommodating view of the problems of world disarmament. It did not take very long to turn around on this matter.

The proposal we are presently looking at-to reduce strategic nuclear weapons by 50 per cent-really grew out of the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks (START) negotiations. The START negotiations were an initiative begun between the Soviets and the United States in June 1982. The American objective in these negotiations was to make deep cuts in the strategic arsenals of both sides. The two previous agreements-the SALT I and SALT II agreements-were agreements to limit the numbers. The importance of the START negotiations is that they will lead to deep cuts or reductions in the absolute numbers of weapons.

The principles that guide these reductions are supported by the Senate. Whatever the views of the Australian Labor Party were, I am pleased to see that it now supports and has reinforced the views that those of us on this side of the House have in relation to arms reductions. Those views are, firstly that the reductions have to be mutual; there cannot be a reduction on only one side, because unilateral reduction leads to instability and thereby increases the threat. Secondly, the reductions have to be balanced. The nature of the United States or Western deterrent capacity is different from that of the Soviets. It is not a matter of saying that we will get rid of X number of landbased ICBMs on each side; it is a matter of reducing the capability on both sides in parallel so that stability is retained. Of course, the third thing is verification. Just as verification is a problem in the INF negotiations, so too is it a problem in relation to the larger field of strategic weapons.

But there are signs that there is a growing accommodation between both blocs to allow more effective verification to take place. As intercontinental ballistic missiles move into higher technology areas they become smaller and more transportable. Weapons systems such as the SS25 with its mobile basing, which is now being deployed by the Soviets-in the view of the Americans in violation of SALT I and SALT II-poses great problems from a verification point of view because, whereas hardened silos can be under surveillance from satellite technology, if an intercontinental missile can be transported on a low loader or a train the problems of observation become that much more acute.

The second part of the motion expresses the hope that significant reductions will take place in the short term and in no way puts an embargo on further reductions taking place once the first round has been completed. The final part of the motion deals with deterrence. Deterrence is the principle that has been followed by the Western democracies to maintain a balance so that neither side gets blackmailed by the other. It has kept the peace for 43 years, the longest period for well over a hundred years in Western Europe.

The policy of deterrence is not easy. It is difficult, it is dangerous and it is expensive. But I make no excuse about that; those are the facts of life. But it must also be said that there is no better and no other way by which peace can be maintained at present. I do not happen to believe that this system will be in place in a hundred years time. I think we will have other technology that is safer and more secure. But for today the policy of deterrence is the only policy we can have.

That puts certain obligations upon us. It means that we have to run certain risks and we have to meet certain expenses. The simple emotional cries that come out from the peace movement are not only ill-informed but also positively dangerous for the peace and security of the country. Opposing the mining of uranium, the nuclear freeze, the opposition to the testing of nuclear weapons and the theory of total disarmament are all policies which operate against the success of the policy of deterrence and thereby compromise the peace and security of the present. The present campaign against the joint defence facilities in Australia and the business of trying to make Australia part of a nuclear free zone also operate against our security. I do not have time to deal with those things seriatim, but I hope we will have other opportunities in the Senate to come back to them.

This afternoon I heard a little of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) speaking in support of the joint defence facilities here. What I heard of him quite impressed me. Certainly, as honourable senators would know, the Government's support of the joint defence facilities has the full support of honourable senators on this side of the chamber because these facilities contribute to the maintenance of peace in the Western democracies. The security of the Western democracies is indivisible. Unfortunately one cannot do what Mr Lange thinks one can do-put up an invisible barrier around a country and so be free of any involvement in a nuclear war. The name of the game is to prevent a nuclear war and we do that through the policy of deterrence. The joint defence facilities that we have here are no threat to Australia. The argument that they would be attacked by the Soviets in an outbreak of war fails to recognise that war would have broken out before they attacked. If a nuclear war breaks out there is no sanctuary for Australia and no sanctuary for New Zealand. We are all involved in it. So the name of the game is to stop the breakdown of peace, to maintain peace. And our part as a member nation of the Western democracies is absolutely indivisible from the responsibilities we have to maintain peace.

There is a lot more that ought to be said on the disarmament issue because I think the numbers of conventional weapons are excessive and the range and lethality of conventional weapons today is staggering. They are no comparison to what existed in the Second World War. We have positive evidence that chemical weapons have been used in Afghanistan and certainly in the Iraq-Iran conflict. This is also very frightening. The whole matter of armaments needs far more attention than this Parliament has paid to it in recent times. I support this motion and I look forward to hearing the contributions of other honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I agree totally with the statements made previously by Senator MacGibbon and Senator Vallentine that here we have a very important issue. I believe there are five honourable senators on the speakers list who wish to speak to this issue. It is most regrettable that time is limited because this is a most important matter. I move the amendment that has been circulated in my name:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out paragraph (b), insert the following paragraphs:
``(b) notes that this historic agreement is a result of the desire of the world's people for disarmament, which has been given expression by the peace movements of East and West;

(c) acknowledges that the agreement does not address the growing threat of nuclear war in the North West Pacific, through the deployment of intermediate range nuclear armed sea-launched cruise missiles by the United States and the Soviet Union;

(d) endorses the recommendation of the 1986 Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee report, `Disarmament and Arms Control in the Nuclear Age', that the deployment of sea-launched cruise missiles be arrested; and

(e) calls on the Australian Government to take steps to bring about a freeze on cruise missile deployments, such as working for the establishment of a Pacific Conference on Disarmament and an Indian Ocean Zone of Peace Conference''.

The Senate will see that the first part of the motion moved by Senator MacGibbon, paragraph (a), has the full support of the Australian Democrats. The United States of America and the Soviet Union are to be congratulated on an historic agreement which is expected to be signed later this year. Once it is signed the intermediate nuclear forces treaty, the INF treaty as it is becoming known, will be the first ever arms control treaty to require the destruction of certain types of nuclear weapons. The major arms control treaties of the 1970s arising from the strategic arms limitation talks actually allowed the United States and the Soviet Union to build up their nuclear arsenals.

The INF treaty also sets an important precedent in the area of verification. Each side can inspect the other's military facilities to check that the treaty is being complied with. The Soviet Union has never before agreed to on-site inspections, a reluctance which the United States has regarded as a major obstacle to arms control.

As time is short, I turn to deal with my amendment. It seeks to omit paragraph (b) of Senator MacGibbon's amendment and to replace it with the four paragraphs of my amendment. In the event that my amendment fails I shall move that the two paragraphs of the original motion be voted on separately. This is because the Australian Democrats can support the first paragraph but cannot support the second because we believe very firmly that it is not the deterrent aspect that has led to this agreement but rather the peace movements throughout Europe and the United States, and indeed in the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics, which has drawn the leaders towards this agreement.

To conclude, the Australian Democrats again congratulate the United States and the Soviet Union on this unprecedented agreement. We congratulate the peace movement of the world for compelling them to achieve it. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Genotropin-Woodger's Canberra Raiders-FM Radio Licences-Torres Strait Islanders-Defence Service Home Loans Scheme

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter which has been brought to my attention by a constituent relating to the treatment of her daughter with a drug by the name of genotropin. This girl has been diagnosed as having Turner's syndrome, the effect of which is that one does not grow. The full adult height is likely to be about four feet eight inches which perhaps in itself is not so much of a problem, or can be coped with, but in addition there are other side effects in that sexually there is no development at either primary or secondary stage. At present the situation is that this child has been accepted as a candidate for the genotropin clinical trials but her candidacy is subject to her being less than 14 years old and she must in fact commence the treatment within 12 months. Delays not only will cause a setback to any improvement which might be obtained but also there could be quite serious consequences for her growth and development. The reason her mother has brought the matter to me is the delay in getting an answer from the Department of Community Services and Health as to whether this drug will be allowed into Australia for the purpose of treatment. It is a fairly new drug which supersedes a drug which has been used for this purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been somewhat unnecessary delays in finding out whether the tests by the Department are going to be concluded and when an answer will be known. The application was made earlier this year for the use of the drug in Australia and we accept that evaluation is necessary. But the mother of this girl, whose name I do not wish to mention because I do not believe it is necessary for this purpose, is feeling that time is slipping away in that she has not been able to get an answer from the Department as to when a decision will be made. The need for high standards in testing is not in dispute but there is some reason to feel that the Department may not be expediting the matter. Maybe it lacks the resources. We do not know what the problem is. Certainly, the mother of this young girl believes that as a result of the situation her daughter's future is being jeopardised in a very significant way. For whatever reason, the mother's concern is quite genuine and I ask the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) to intervene and find out what the Department is doing about it and when a decision will become available. The letter to the Minister was written on 18 September and I will write to him and identify the name and the address so that there can be no confusion about his knowing exactly what it is we are talking about. I shall not go into great detail about the genetic defect, the drug or the problem. I merely ask the Minister to please intervene in this matter and do what he can for this family to see that a very crucial decision is made quite soon.

There is another matter to which I wish to refer. I do so with the greatest sensitivity, given that you, Mr President, are occupying the chair at this moment. I want to wish the Raiders well in the match against Manly on Sunday. As I said, you may feel that you are not in a position to reply. The Raiders have done spectacularly well, particularly this year, since they came into existence. All of us in Canberra admire the way that Don Furner has developed this team, and more recently with Wayne Bennett. It is something we have all watched with great interest and pride. To save embarrassing you, Mr President, I shall not say anything more other than to wish Dean Lance and his team well when they go to Sydney and meet your team of Manly. Perhaps it would be best to conclude by saying `May the best team win'. The Raiders are assured of a very warm welcome home whether they win or lose because we will certainly know that they have done their best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the question in the Senate of the Government's decision in the Budget to commence a system of tendering for FM radio licences. I am disappointed that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, is not able to be here for this debate in order to give his answers to my questions. I am not seeking to raise the issue of the principle of either tendering or auctioning FM or any other kind, of radio licences. I am raising the question of the Budget decision as it affects those applicants for FM radio licences, of which there are four, who have already submitted applications to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and which are partly heard as all the hearings have not yet been completed. This has been the subject of a great deal of concern by those applicants. At the moment four main groups are concerned. Those applications are concerned with licences in the Gold Coast area, the Gosford area, the Shepparton area and the Geelong area.

SPEECH.PARA: There appears to be considerable confusion amongst applicants-and certainly amongst those who are observing the scheme at present-as to what exactly is the role of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in the present processes. It seemed that at about the beginning of September the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was commencing to undertake hearings and to initiate the processes to hear applicant's submissions. Consequently, that seems to have stopped as a result of the Budget announcement last Tuesday week which raised the question of whether there had been any request from the Minister or his department to the Tribunal to halt proceedings because clearly there could have been some message in the wind-something on the grapevine-about the possibility of a change of system, that is, a switch to either tendering or auctioning. Of course, that has been denied. I acknowledge that the Broadcasting Tribunal has stated that the Government has not interfered in any way with its processes. I accept that at face value. However, I have not yet heard from the Minister at all on that particular point.

Nevertheless, that is not the main point that I wish to raise tonight. The main point at issue is to try to discover just what the rules are as they presently apply during this interregnum where there is no Budget legislation brought down by the Government in respect of FM radio licence auctions or tenders and during the period in which the Broadcasting Tribunal will be proceeding to initiate hearings of applicants' submissions.

Mr President, as you would understand, the rules up until the time of the Budget were quite clear and the processes had already been established by the Tribunal. Then came the Budget announcement and apparently everything has changed. The question is what rules will apply after that date of announcement, as it seems as though legislation will be necessary to change the rules by which the Tribunal would operate in the circumstances envisaged in the Budget announcement. That being so, applicants do not know what to do next, that is, whether to proceed with hearings before the Broadcasting Tribunal or not, because they simply do not know what the processes will be.

I understand that the Tribunal is preparing to operate under the old rules but we need the Minister's assurance that that is the Government's intention since it is unclear whether those rules are the ones that will be finally tested against the applicant's submissions at the time of the allocation of the licence.

This matter is of particular concern to applicants for the new FM licence on the Gold Coast. The reason for concern is that what is known as the final direction by the Australian Broadcasting tribunal as to the determination of the submission dates, the hearings and the setting out of the processes by the tribunal has been made and expires on 16 October 1987. That means that the rules, as they have been set down by the Tribunal to date, as I understand it, are applicable to those hearings which will expire by 16 October. The problem is that, as I mentioned earlier, we have been put on notice of the changes to the law as a result of the Budget decision. Consequently, there is no clear statement from the Government as to whether the changes will be made retrospectively after the hearings have already occurred.

We can see a bit of a problem developing because the Parliament will not be sitting for at least another week and it seems virtually impossible for it to pass the necessary legislation to change the Tribunal's rules before 16 October this year. So we have a bit of a dog's breakfast and I am not clear what the Government intends. My simple request is that Senator Evans determine straight away the situation for applicants who are in the circumstances I have outlined and make a statement so that all applicants know exactly where they stand regarding the Government's future intentions on legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to speak about the most northern part of Australia and the most northern Australians-the Torres Strait Islanders who live in the Torres Strait on 17 inhabited islands, including the head island, the administrative centre, Thursday Island. These people have occupied the Strait for some 600 or 700 years, so the experts tell us. They are basically a race of Polynesians and Melanesians, yet they are fiercely Australian and very loyal subjects of Australia. Many of them fought in the Australian forces in the Second World War. These people occupy some of the most valuable real estate in Australia-the islands of the Torres Strait.

SPEECH.PARA: I was fortunate enough to be invited to the islanders' fiftieth island community council celebrations. Many came and they had their own form of sports day, dancing, singing, and the traditional island feast. The Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, and Lady Stephen were present and everyone had a wonderful time and enjoyed the celebrations. I was disappointed to see a report in one of the newspapers of that celebration commemorating the fiftieth anniversary which depicted the Islanders as I do not believe they really are. The report stated that the Islanders have health problems-I suppose they do-notably, diet-induced diabetes, hypertension and a number of other problems. I have been to the islands a great number of times and I have found these people to be as healthy as any other normal Australian. Yet the newspaper report stated:
Hoarding is a popular source of profit: buying luxury items such as cigarettes in bulk when the boat arrives, and reselling them at a killing price when the shop supplies run low.

I think this is untrue of the Islanders. Tonight I stand up to support my fellow Queenslanders, my fellow Australians, and say that this is not the case. Another section of the report written about the islands and the community celebrations on Yorke Island-its native name is Massig Island-said that the Islanders were permissive. I deny that too. I have been with the Islanders a number of times and they are very Christian people. They believe in their faith and are regular churchgoers. The whole tone of the article was deceiving and not completely within the bounds of what should have been reported.

George Mye is chairman of Darnley Island-in my opinion he is a patriot and Getano Lui is the assistant chairman. They have a 100 per cent interest in their islands and they want to maximise their local economies. They want to develop industries such as tourism and the trochus industry, which is a new one. When I was last there I saw bags of trochus being forwarded overseas. Badu Island has a dynamic crayfish industry which is owned and promoted by the islanders. It was not set up by, and did not have any help from, the white administrative service. It was established by the Islanders on their own initiative and it is bringing in something like $3m to the islands' economy and employing a great number of the Badu people. Yorke Island has a fishing-freezing works which employs a number of people.

These islands are developing. Recently they received their own deed of grant which gives them virtual autonomy of their islands. They can do with their property everything that any other Australian can do with his property except pass it to someone outside the island community. The Islanders can develop their own land, run their own vegetable farms and, at the will of their councils, pass land for development to anyone who comes forward with a project.
It concerns me somewhat that I am reported in the article as saying that George Mye is too smart to turn his back on the money that comes into the islands from the mainland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say it?

—I did. I said it in the form of a compliment. I believe that George Mye is one of the smartest of men. He knows as well as I that if the islands are to be developed, he needs the help of Australia and of the white administration. Hopefully, that help will be only temporary as the islanders develop their own industries and commerce. Already we are seeing this happen. I do not know whether Senator Reynolds has been fortunate enough to visit the Torres Strait Islands. I know that she has an interest in the islanders and the Aboriginals of north Queensland. I am sure that she would agree with me that the islands are a most delightful place-almost a paradise. I suppose that as the tourist industries develop, which is happening now at Coconut Island, a little of the magic will be lost. But that is progress. There is not much we can do about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government could be of more help to the islands, to Badu in particular, which has one telephone to go around 400 citizens. There is only one telephone on every island. These people are compulsive telephoners. It is very hard when one is up there to get on a telephone. The islanders require the provision of more services by the Federal Government of Australia. There is no television up there, although there is a good island radio service. Facilities on these islands are very primitive. This Government could do much more to provide these people with better facilities-for instance, water. Water supplies on the islands are absolutely atrocious. The islands have no sewerage system. The Federal Government could provide some assistance in developing the infrastructure that is required on the islands, such as telephones, television and water supplies, rather than giving hand-outs. Senator Reynolds will no doubt get up and bucket the Queensland Government, saying that these things are its responsibility. But I point out to Senator Reynolds that she must be honest and fair in her reply. The solar power plant which is being built on Coconut Island at a cost of $650,000 will supply electricity to only about 100-odd people on the island.

The people of these islands are decent Christian people. The fact that such an article has been written about them has disappointed them. It has taken the shine off one of the highlights of their calendar-the 50-year commemoration service of when they formed themselves into island community councils. I know from telephone calls that I have had that they were terribly disappointed. They had what they thought was a wonderful weekend. The Governor-General was present, and there was a lovely church service and competition dancing between the islands. That was the window they wanted to present to Australia, but it was not depicted that way by the article. The islanders are disappointed that what they achieved in their weekend of interisland community fellowship was misrepresented. Some prominent white guests were invited. I do not include myself in the term `prominent', but the Governor-General and his lady were there. To read in the article that the islanders were exploiting each other and were promiscuous-the article even states that an islander has died from acquired immune deficiency syndrome-is not the general impression of the islands that I have received and I am sure that it is not the impression Senator Reynolds has had when she has visited the islands. I say to the islanders: Do not be too despondent. As politicians we always have to put up with Press articles. We have to live with it. What is today's news wraps tomorrow's fish and chips.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am hopping mad about an announcement in the Budget that concerns not many of my constituents in Tasmania but a number of Senator Reynolds's and Senator Boswell's constituents. I refer to members of the defence community, a large number of whom are in Queensland and a number of other States. Veterans are also particularly upset by the Budget decision to change the defence service home loans scheme. Mr President, as you would know, for some months now I have been asking the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, what was to happen to the defence service home loans scheme. It had gone out to private tender twice. No response was ever given to the Senate as to what was happening to the tenders from the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government announced in the Budget that the existing subsidy for the $25,000 low interest loans would be changed to a $10,000, once only, tax-free hand-out for home acquisition. That in itself sounds innocuous enough, but when one does actuarial studies one finds that veterans and servicemen are being shortchanged by between $2,000 and $5,000 on the value of the loan as it is now.

Mr President, you have been in this place long enough to know that the defence service home loans scheme was regarded by everybody as being far too low in the current climate. It had not been increased for many years. The amount of $25,000 was part of the review which was being undertaken by the Government. It was hoped, at least on this side of the Parliament, that that amount would be considerably increased, and that the eligibility for the loan would be widened. We currently have two groups of servicemen-one lot is eligible for the defence service loan, whereas those who enlisted since May 1985 are not. Yet we have them serving side by side. We also hoped that the Government would find a mechanism, perhaps through the private sector, to make sure that the loans did not have the enormously long waiting list which they currently have. But we find that the Government has thrown the baby out with the bath water.

Fortunately, as Senator Reynolds no doubt already knows, there is tremendous concern in the defence and veteran communities that the Government has done a U-turn to some extent and announced that the old and the new systems will apply until 1 January next year. The Press release from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), issued on 23 September, said that it would be `business as usual' and that the Defence Service Homes Corporation would continue to accept applications. Perhaps the Government does not know that on 17 September one serviceman with 19 1/2 years service, a Vietnam veteran, was turned away and told that the system was about to be changed and that he could not get a loan. So `business as usual' does not sound too good to me. I am very concerned about what the Government is really doing. The decision was an ad hoc last minute decision. It may be one of those small programs that Senator Walsh got his way with. I do not know whether he wants to take the credit for it. I certainly would not.

The Government has said that discussions will take place with the Returned Services League and other interested bodies, but at this stage certainly the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has not had any discussions, either before the announcement or since. Honourable senators will recall that the announcement was made on Tuesday of last week. Servicemen have not been consulted. Service organisations have not been consulted. Service families have not been consulted. This very Government set up a body called the National Consultative Group of Service Spouses to talk to Government about the concerns of service families and their conditions of service and it has not been consulted.

I understand that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mrs Kelly, is going to Townsville next week. I understand that representations have also been made to the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, urging that the Minister's itinerary be widened because currently I understand that she is going to visit only the Royal Australian Air Force base, that she is not visiting the Army and that she is not proposing to see the families. I feel it is critical, if she is to do her job properly, that she widens her itinerary and sees those other people who are so desperately concerned about what seems to them at least to be one more attempt by the Government to cut into their conditions of service. One wonders why Minister Kelly was appointed if she is to preside over a diminution of the conditions of service of our service families.

There is uproar amongst service families. I understand that in Queensland about 300 men are currently considering taking their $10,000 and going. Is that what the Government wants? I thought that the Government should have been already concerned about the dramatic wastage. We have lost a third of our defence forces in the last three years. Does the Government want to pay serviceman to get out? Is this some sort of a scheme to get rid of them so that the Government can meet its defence budget, which has received a cut of one per cent? I do not know whether Minister Kelly realises it, but in the defence community she is fast developing a reputation of being totally insensitive to the very service personnel for whom she has been appointed to be responsible. I do not know whether she will achieve anything as a Minister in that portfolio but for the sake of the service community I hope she does very well. However, she has a desperately poor start. Every time she has opened her mouth she seems to have said something insensitive, inaccurate or ignorant. If she does not do her homework and then talk to these families and find out what the real situation is, she will never be any good in that job.

As I said earlier, the scheme should be reviewed and the amount of the loan should be increased. The waiting time should be reduced and the eligibility should be widened to include those who enlisted after May 1985. I believe that the scheme should also be widened for the sake of the taxpayer. Serviceman should be allowed to take more than one loan so that if they are re-posted they will be able to sell their houses and be eligible to get another loan at the new posting, thus saving the taxpayer from the expense of having to provide great capital sums for married quarters. I have said on numerous occasions in this place that people often enjoy the opportunity of providing for themselves.

Former Minister Senator Gietzelt was endeav- ouring to have this scheme taken over by the private sector. I have spoken to people in the private sector. I believe that the scheme could be very well and much better organised than it is being currently. Benefits could flow to the veterans and to the service families if that were done. We as an Opposition support that move. But we do not support the current attempt to short change our service men and women and our veterans. The Government had to take immediate action to consult them and then to improve the scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we have heard from Senator Reid, who raised her concerns about the availability of the drug genotropin. Senator Reid is obviously concerned about the availability of this drug for one of her constituents and I will certainly undertake to refer her concerns to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). There seems to have been a short delay in regard to the testing procedures that are very necessary. Drugs should not be available on the market in Australia until full testing procedures have been undertaken. However, I can appreciate the concerns of both Senator Reid and the family of the young girl involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, Senator Reid, then raised a very important matter. I think, from the look I am receiving, from you, that I had better not make too many remarks about the big match on Sunday. All I can do is endorse Senator Reid's comments and say may the best team win-and, in saying that, I will not look too closely at the President.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might make a statement myself, Senator Reynolds.

—Senator Messner was rather unkind to my good colleague Senator Evans when he talked about the auctioning of FM radio licences and described the policy as something of a dog's breakfast. Obviously, he does not have very much respect for dogs, nor for their diets. However, Senator Messner was seeking some clarification which I am sure is available but which I have not been able to get this evening. I will undertake to get some clarification for Senator Messner. I know, having spoken to a number of people on the Gold Coast, just how importantly they regard the FM radio licence auction. There will, of course, be fairly fierce competition on the Gold Coast. I am sure that we can get some detailed information from Senator Evans's office.

SPEECH.PARA: I sympathise with the concerns raised by Senator Boswell. It is a tragedy that on an occasion such as the fiftieth anniversary in the Torres Strait that was attended by the Governor-General and other dignitaries-and even Senator Boswell-a newspaper should try to denigrate the islanders and focus negatively on aspects of their society, if indeed the report be true. Senator Boswell indicated that he does not believe that it is and this is one of those rare occasions on which I would be inclined to agree with him. It is certainly very concerning when the media, a newspaper in this instance, is more preoccupied with a little sensationalism in order to sell a newspaper than taking a serious look at an historic occasion. The reporter concerned should have talked to the community leaders and tried to write an article that genuinely reflected the tremendous work that is going on in the islands and the tremendous contribution that is being made by community leaders in building up their communities and moving into tourism.

I could not agree with Senator Boswell when he spoke about the lack of commitment by this Government. I know that the honourable member for Leichhardt, John Gayler, has been a tireless worker for the Torres Strait Islanders. He has made ongoing representations and the Government has given exceptionally good commitment to the area. I suppose that whenever one is looking at improving facilities one can always put forward a case for more expenditure. I sympathise with some of the concerns that the islanders have in certain areas. Nevertheless, I do not think it is fair to suggest that the Government has not given a high priority to the Torres Strait. John Gayler has been very much to the fore in his representations. The former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Clyde Holding, has been up to the Torres Strait on a number of occasions. I know Gerry Hand, as the new Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, has just as much commitment to the Torres Strait and the people living there. So I could not agree with Senator Boswell on the second point he made. However, I certainly recommend that he write to the newspaper concerned and suggest that there are many distressed and disappointed constituents in the Torres Strait. Perhaps the newspaper in question-and Senator Boswell has asked that I not mention it by name-will care to send a journalist to the Torres Strait more frequently so that the lifestyle in the islands can be reported in a more genuine and positive manner.

Senator Newman made a contribution that really does not accord with my brief on the defence service homes scheme and the variation to the Budget announcement. I take this opportunity to run through what I have been advised by the Department of Defence Science and Personnel. The Government announced in the Budget a proposal to replace the defence service homes loan with a $10,000 non-taxable grant. This proposal was subject to consultation with the Returned Services League (RSL) and other interested parties. These consultations are proceeding.

The honourable senator's comments about the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) are completely out of context with my brief, because she will be visiting Townsville-next week, I believe-and I am sure that she will start her consultation process. I understand the honourable senator to be indicating that the Minister is not visiting the Army. I accept that that will cause some disappointment, but it is to be her first visit. I admit, as a Minister trying to cover local government throughout Australia, that it is very difficult to meet everybody at once. The Minister is going to Townsville and she will be talking with some service families.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has the biggest concentration in Australia. She should make a list of them and combine the lot.

—Sure. I will certainly check with her about when she will visit again to talk with other service wives. Coming back to the defence service homes loans scheme variation, the situation is as follows: the Defence Service Homes Corporation receives about 500 loan applications a month and the rejection rate is minimal. Since 15 September the Corporation has continued to receive applications for assistance in the form of either a loan or a grant. The Government does not intend to disadvantage members of the veterans' or service communities and believes that the consultation with the RSL and other interested parties will help it to restructure the scheme in a most efficient manner. The Corporation will continue to accept and process applications until 31 December, when the Government expects to have finalised its plans to reform the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Newman can rest assured that the Government and the Ministers responsible have the matter that she raised very much in hand. I think her comments about Mrs Kelly were totally uncalled for so early in the Minister's tenure of her portfolio, particularly when she has already travelled extensively.

TALK.START.PARA: —And said silly things everywhere.

—No, I certainly would not agree with that. She has been travelling extensively to consult and to find her way around her portfolio. She has been to Western Australia and she is travelling to Queensland next week. I think that that indicates she is totally committed to making sure that she understands her portfolio. The consultation process takes time. One cannot consult everybody within the first few weeks of accepting a portfolio. I know that from my experience with the local government portfolio. I know that Mrs Kelly is fully committed to her portfolio and fully committed to service families, and I know that they will benefit from having her as Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
